title: Phönix D.IIa
history: The Phönix D.IIa was the last in the series of fighter aircraft designed and built by the Austro-Hungarian firm Phönix Flugzeugwerke that were deployed in operational combat during World War I. The design work was completed by Phönix's chief engineer, Edmund Sparmann. The machine borrowed much from its predecessor, the Phönix D.I and externally the two looked much alike. Although widely used by the Austro-Hungarian Air Force, pilots often complained that the Phönix D.I was overweight for its power plant, giving the aircraft only mediocre performance. To produce a better fighter, Sparmann designed the D.II variant. While having the same 200 hp Hiero engine as the D.I, the D.II was lightened by nearly 176 lbs. Weight was removed from the fighter through the alteration of its internal wood framing and its fuselage. The wings and tail surfaces were also lightened. The result was a marked improvement in the fighter's aerodynamic handling. For even better performance, Sparmann and his engineer colleague, Ing Kirste, upgraded the D.II's power plant to a 230 hp engine, thus creating the Phoniz D.IIa (modeled here). Shortages of the 230 hp Hiero engines required that some 20% of the D.IIa fighters be delivered with the smaller Hiero 200 hp power plants. But even these smaller 200 hp D.IIa fighters were clearly superior to their predecessor, the D.I. The new D.IIa aircraft began supplying Austro-Hungarian fighter units in late May of 1918 and remained in operational service with both the Austro-Hungarian Army and Navy until the end of the War. While probably the best fighter built by the Austro-Hungarian Empire during World War I, the D.IIa was not the equal of the newer Albatros or Fokker fighters in service with the German Air Force during 1918. Neither was it equal to the S.P.A.D. and Sopwith fighters flying for the Allies. Model Builder's Comments: The factory fresh Phönix D.IIa modeled here was the machine flown during the final days of World War I on the Austro-Hungarian/Italian front by the Austrian pilot Karf Teichmann.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Flik (squadron) 17 J, Austro-Hungarian Air Force, Feltre Airdrome, Feltre, Austria, October, 1918.
tech:

title: Fokker B.III Light Observation Biplane
history:
As the dominance of the Fokker monoplanes began to wane in the face of new and improved machines, Anthony Fokker instructed designer, Martin Kreutzer to begin work on a biplane fighter. One of the designs Kreutzer developed was the M.17E. While the German military showed little interest in The Fokker M.17, a number of the biplanes were sold to Austria-Hungary, which re-designated the aircraft, the B.III.

The B.III was constructed of canvas-covered wood framing except for a metal cowling about its rotary engine. The small aircraft employed wing warping for lateral control and the vast majority of the machines were unarmed. Some evidence indicates that at least one B.III (modeled here) was equipped with a machine gun, though there are conflicting reports as to the weapon's placement and type.

Most B.IIIs were employed as reconnaissance scouts or trainers, though the prototype for this model was reportedly flown on the Eastern Front as a fighter by Oberleutnant, Plus Moosbrugger. World War I historical records are otherwise silent about Moosbrugger's combat exploits, or lack thereof.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Flik (Squadron) 11, Luftfahrtruppe (Austro-Hungarian Air Force), Eastern Front, June, 1916.
tech:

Power plant: One Oberursel, 7 cylinder air-cooled rotary piston engine of 80 hp (60 kW)

title: Zeppelin L 30
history: The Zeppelin L 30, modeled here, was chosen to represent Germany's fleet of wartime airships within this collection. It was the first of seventeen R-class "super-Zeppelins"-a class of airships larger than earlier machines which could carry larger bomb loads and could fly higher and faster. Five decades before the outbreak of World War I, Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin, an officer in the Prussian Calvary, ventured to the United States to serve as an Army observer during the American Civil War. There, he witnessed tethered balloons being used for battlefield observation. Deeply impressed, he returned to Germany where he began the development of the world's first rigid and propeller driven airships. So profound was the Count's influence that the name Zeppelin was commonly applied to all such aircraft. Though originally designed for civilian transport purposes, Zeppelins were soon adapted for military use. With the outbreak of World War I, many civilian airships were pressed into service. After initial sorties as tactical bombers and observation platforms proved impractical, Zeppelins were instead assigned to bomb civilian population centers, particularly London and Paris. The Zeppelin raids on these cities during World War I mark some of the first examples of strategic bombing missions -attacks against population centers intended to disrupt industry and demoralize an enemy. Lifted by multiple gas cells filled with flammable hydrogen, Zeppelins primarily relied on their ability to climb above the range of enemy aircraft and ground fire. While early raids encountered little resistance, the British and French soon modified selected fighters to fly higher and armed their machine guns with incendiary bullets. Hydrogen filled Zeppelins began to be shot from the sky in flames. Zeppelin bombing raids were also largely conducted at night, but even though they were painted black for stealth, their huge size made them easy targets. Super Zeppelins like the L 30 were developed in an effort to stay ahead of Allied defensive capabilities by climbing ever higher. Unfortunately, the continued advancement of aircraft technology met the airships step for step. Nevertheless, the L 30 had a long and successful career. It conducted 31 reconnaissance flights and 9 raids over England and was one of the few German airships to survive the war unscathed. After the War ended, Zeppelin L 30 was seized by the Allies and delivered to Belgium for examination. Model Builder's Comments: The building of this Zeppelin L 30 model was a collaboration between Dr. H. Logan Holtgrewe, and Museum of Flight volunteer, Mr. Alex "Sandy" Morton. The Zeppelin model was built entirely from scratch in 1/48 scale (one inch of the model equals 4 feet of the prototype) -the same scale as all the fixed wing aircraft models. This sameness of scale allows the viewer to appreciate the relative size of the various aircraft represented and to appreciate the huge size of the Zeppelin L30. The illuminated gondola's overhead white lights allow the viewer to see the airship's interior details. Such lighting would have been extinguished during bombing raids over enemy territory being replaced by dim red night lights -this was to enhance nighttime stealth.
deployment: This model represents an airship of the Luftschiffe (German Naval Airship Division), German Naval Airship Airdrome, Nordholz, Germany, August, 1916.

title: Hanriot HD 2
history: The Hanriot HD 2 was the maritime version of the Hanriot HD 1 and was designed and built by the French aviation firm Société Anonyme des Appareils ď Aviation Hanriot France's Aviation Militaire mostly rejected the HD 2s, though several of the planes, configured with wheels, flew from the battleship Paris at Toulon -launched from a 40ft (12m) platform above the turret of the battleship. Other countries, however, utilized the HDs during the war. The Italian Société Nieuport-Macchi company built many under license, and the HD 1 became the standard fighter of the Italian Air Force. The Belgian Air Force also flew the HD 1. Belgium's leading World War I ace Willy Coppens scored most of his 37 victories in this aircraft. The United States also purchased 10 of the HD 2s when it entered the war in 1917. They were flown from the United States Navy Facility at Dunkerque, France, in a reconnaissance-fighter role. After the war, many of the HD 2s remained in service with the United States Navy Air Service. The Naval Aircraft Factory replaced the floats with wheels, and the planes became trainers at Langley Field. One of these wheeled versions participated in early United States Navy experiments involving aircraft flights from ships. It flew off a temporary platform built over the guns of the battleship USS Mississippi.
deployment: Unidentified United States Navy Air Squadron, U.S. Navy Facility, Dunkerque, France, April, 1918.

title: Nieuport 17
history: This model represents the Nieuport 17 aircraft, which was designed by Gustave Delage, the chief aeronautical engineer of the French aircraft firm Société Anonyme des Etablissments. While large numbers of Nieuport 17s were built in France, the Nieuport-Macchi company in Italy also constructed them under license. The Nieuport 17 retained the characteristic sesquiplane wing of the previous Nieuport crafts (including the Nieuports 10, 11, and 16). This sesquiplane design made the Nieuport 17 one of the most maneuverable aircraft of the period. The Nieuport 17 was slightly larger than the Nieuport 11, had a larger engine, and included a synchronized machine gun that fired through the propeller. The Nieuport 17 entered the war on the Western Front early in 1916. It was used by the French Aviation Militaire and some of the Lafeyette Escadrille. The air services of Great Britain, Belgium, Russia, the Netherlands and the United States also employed the Nieuport 17 and The 70th Squadriglia of the Italian Air Force, flew this aircraft on the Italian-Austro-Hungarian Front in April of 1917. However, in early 1917, the French officially declared the Nieuport 17 obsolete and replaced them with the new French SPAD. Model Builder's Comments: The prototype of this model had the 70th Squadriglia's insignia (a rearing black stallion) on its top wing and on both sides of its fuselage waist. The model replicates these markings.
deployment: This model is painted in the colors of World War I Italian ace Capitanio Francesco Baracca. He achieved several of his 34 victories in this type of aircraft.

title: Morane-Saulnier Type AI
history:
The Morane-Saulnier Type AI was an aircraft which tested very well, but which ended up with a very short operational career. The AI was a high-winged monoplane, constructed from metal and spruce. The primary wing braces were further supported by auxiliary struts attached mid-span. This arrangement proved to be very sturdy and would be reflected in the company's post-war designs. The Morane-Saulnier Type AI made its first test flights in August of 1917. The aircraft's performance at these tests was looked upon favorably and the Aviation Militaire placed an order for between 1,100 and 1,300 Type AIs, which arrived at combat escadrilles beginning in early 1918.

Despite the favorable trials and large number of aircraft purchased for service, the Type AI only served in combat operations for a couple of months. Deliveries of production aircraft began in March of 1918. But by late May of that same year the Morane-Saulnier Type AIs had all been withdrawn from combat status and relegated to training duties at French flight schools. The reason for the rapid withdrawal of these aircraft is still unclear. One theory suggests that problems with the Gnome engine were to blame, while another suggests that structural weaknesses may have been the cause. Training versions of the Type AI replaced the Gnome engine with 120-135hp Le Rhône engines and a dedicated trainer variant was built with additional wing braces.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, April, 1918.

title: Nieuport 11 (XI) Bébé Sesquiplane
history:
The Nieuport 11 was the second in the lineage of fighters designed for the Aviation Militaire (the French Air Force) during World War I by the French aviation firm Société Anonyme des Établissements Nieuport and its chief engineer Gustave Delage. The Nie.11 was one of the outstanding landmarks in the evolution of fighter aircraft. The machine was built in very large numbers in France by its parent company, in Italy under license by Nieuport-Macchi and in Russia under license by Dux. It was a smaller refinement of its immediate predecessor the Nieuport X. A sesquiplane, its upper wing had twice the surface area of its lower wing. The Nie.11 was constructed of wood framing covered with fabric except for the forward fuselage and engine cowling which were covered with thin aluminum sheet. The aircraft's small size led to the acquisition of its nickname, "Bébé" (baby). 

The Nie.11 entered service with the Aviation Militaire on January 5, 1916 at a time when the French had not yet developed synchronization between a fighter's forward firing machine gun and its propeller. Thus, the Nie.11's single machine gun was mounted atop the upper wing firing over its propeller arc. By the time of the battle of Verdun, which began on February 21, 1916, nine French Fighter Escadrilles were equipped with Nie.11s. 

The fighter proved to be fast, maneuverable and more than a match for the German Fokker and Pfalz "Eindeckers" (monoplanes), which were creating what Allied airman called the "Eindecker scourge". For several months the Nie.11 brought air superiority to the Allies. Some of France's most famous aces (Guynemer, De Rosa and Nungesser, among others) scored early victories while flying the Nie.11. 

In addition to equipping French fighter units, the Nie.11 was deployed by the air forces of Great Britain (modeled here), Belgium, Russia, Romania, Serbia, the Netherlands and the Ukraine. American volunteer pilots, flying for France before the entry of the United States into the war, formed, within the Aviation Militaire, the famous Lafayette Escadrille. They also flew the Nieuport 11. 

Although it remained in active service with the Italians until the late summer of 1917, by mid-summer 1916 it was being replaced on the Western Front by its faster and better armed successor, the Nieuport 17. Following their withdrawal from active combat, Nie.11s were employed as trainers by various Allied Air Forces.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 7 Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service, Dardanelles, Middle East Theater, 1916.

title: SIA (Italy) R.2
history:
Italian aircraft manufacturer, Società Italiana Aviazione (S.I.A.) was one of several Italian aircraft manufacturers, which were subsidiaries of the Italian automobile manufacturer, Fiat during World War I. In 1918, S.I.A. became Fiat-Aviazione and produced the R.2 as its first aircraft under the new brand. Intended as an armed reconnaissance aircraft, the R.2 was essentially a redesign of the earlier S.I.A. 7.B 2. Fiat engineer, Celestino Rosatelli, developed the new aircraft in an effort to correct the structural problems suffered by the earlier 7.B 2.

Like its predecessor, the R.2 was based around the Fiat A12 six-cylinder inline liquid-cooled engine. The aircraft's framing was a mixture of wood and steel tubing. Sheet metal surrounded the forward fuselage and totally enclosed the engine. While the earlier 7.B 2 had plywood covering over its entire fuselage, the new B.2 replaced the heavier wood with fabric over the rear part of the fuselage. The center of the R.2's upper wing was strengthened to improve its structural integrity, but retained the general shape and unusual top-wing gap of its predecessor. 

After the new machine's flight trials, an order for 500 aircraft was placed with Fiat. Large-scale production of the R.2 did not begin until autumn of 1918. Nevertheless, 129 of the aircraft were completed by the time of the Armistice with a number having flown in the battle of Vittorio Veneto, less than a month before.
deployment: This model represents an armed reconnaissance aircraft of the Italian Air Force.
tech: Manufacturer: Società Italiana Aviazione (S.I.A.) title: A.E.G. G.IV
history:
The A.E.G. G.IV represents the final model in the Allgemeinen Elektrizitäts Gesellschaft (A.E.G.) line of twin-engine bombers to serve in WWI. The G.IV was the first aircraft in the line to be produced in significant numbers. The aircraft utilized the same Mercedes D.IVa powerplants as Germany's heavy bombers, the Gotha G.III and Friedrichschafen G.III, but lacked the range and carrying capacity to make it effective as a heavy bomber. As such, the G.IV was largely used for short-range tactical bombing raids.

The G.IV included a number of advanced design features. The aircraft were equipped with radios, and the pilots wore electrically heated flight suits to keep warm. The G.IV also utilized balanced controls, welded steel tubular framing and steel wing spars and tail structures. The steel construction gave the G.IV great strength but also increased its weight, which dramatically reduced its bomb load and operational range. 

A total of 542 A.E.G. G-type bombers were built. The bombers saw service in France, Greece, Romania and Italy. While they initially flew both day and night missions, as the war progressed, the G.IVs were largely restricted to nighttime operations. Fifty of the aircraft remained in service until the end of the War.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft thought to be of Kampfstaffel (battle squadron) 17, German Air Force, Western Front, December, 1916.

title: Vickers F.B.5 Gunbus
history: The Vickers F.B.5 Gunbus features a machine gun positioned in the fuselage's forward cockpit, which allows its gunner a clear field of forward fire. The pilot flew the plane from the rear cockpit and a pusher engine and propeller were positioned behind the pilot. The F.B.5 was ordered into production by the Royal Flying Corp on August 14, 1914, just two weeks after the outbreak of World War I. The first production Vickers F.B.5s reached the Western Front in early February of 1915. The following July the No. 11 Squadron was the first fighter combat unit of any air force to enter service flying a single aircraft type - the Vickers F.B.5. A total of 241 F.B.5s were built in England by Vickers. Another 99 were built in France under license by the Société Anonyme Darracq and twelve were built in Denmark by the Tojhusvaerksted. Most F.B.5s were deployed over the Western Front with a smaller number retained in England for home defense. However, F.B.5s suffered from unreliable power plants and from marginal performance, properties. These problems shortened their careers and lead to their withdrawal from the Western Front by the autumn of 1916. A few were briefly relegated to Royal Flying Corps training schools, but most were scrapped.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Royal Flying Corps, No. 11 Squadron, Western Front, France, July 1915.

title: Sopwith Cuckoo (T.1)
history:
The Sopwith T.1 Cuckoo was the first aircraft designed as a shipboard torpedo bomber. The future importance of naval aviation was set early in World War I when a British Short Type 184 Bomber successfully sunk a Turkish cruiser with an air-launched torpedo. This event prompted the Admiralty to begin converting battle cruisers and other ships into aircraft carriers. It also commissioned an aircraft capable of carrying a torpedo, which could actively attack enemy shipping. The Sopwith Company responded with their T.1 Cuckoo. The new machine needed to be light in relation to its power plant in order to carry the substantial weight of a naval torpedo. With this in mind, the Cuckoo was designed to seat a single pilot, to carry no defensive armament. The aircraft's construction consisted of light wood framing with fabric covering -except for a metal cowling about the engine. The Cuckoos' wings folded back along the fuselage to accommodate the confined spaces on the aircraft carrier's flight deck. The new torpedo bomber also had an arresting tail hook to assist in landing on a carrier's flight deck. 

Following satisfactory prototype trials in the spring of 1918, the Admiralty ordered 150 of the new T.1 Cuckoos. Only 90 had been delivered to squadrons of the Royal Naval Air Service by the War's end on November 11, 1918. Given the revolutionary and complicated nature of the Cuckoos' shipboard operations, their pilots were all still undergoing familiarization training trials at the time of the armistice. As such, none ever launched a torpedo in anger. Nonetheless, the Sopwith T.1 Cuckoo is historically important as the world's first shipboard torpedo bomber. This aircraft type would become a major factor in the naval engagements of World War II. World War I historical records do not explain how the Sopwith T.1 acquired the nickname "Cuckoo".
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 97 Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service, British Aircraft Carrier HMS Furious, Royal Naval Shipyard, Portsmouth, England, November, 1918.

title: Albatros W 4
history:
The Albatros W.4 fulfilled the need for a German Naval fighter to counter the British flying boats in the North and Baltic Seas. Inspired by the earlier Albatros D.I and D.II, the W.4 retained the fuselage and the power plant of the Albatros D.II, but included new wings and tail structures. Twin floats replaced the wheels to equip it for marine operations. Fabric covered the majority of the fighter's wooden frame, except for the engine housing and floats, which were covered with thin metal sheeting. 

Design flaws plagued early W.4s. A transparent Cellon panel, mounted in the center upper wing section to improve the pilot's vision, proved to be brittle and prone to tearing off in flight. These were soon replaced by traditional fabric. The W.4 also experienced problems with its engine's two radiators. The radiators, which were uniquely positioned on either side of the fuselage, often boiled over in warm weather. Later versions of the W.4 switched to a single flush mounted radiator located in the center of the upper wing. This arrangement proved to be more satisfactory.

The German Air Force employed the W.4 to counter naval reconnaissance and U-boat hunting missions conducted by British flying boats in the North Sea and Baltic Sea. World War I records are vague about the success or failure of the operations of the W.4. With 128 machines built in all, it can be assumed that they were reasonably successful. At the War's end, various seaplane stations on the Baltic coast still listed 65 of these machines in active service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft from Windau Air Station, German Air Force, Baltic Coast, February 1917.

title: Albatros C.III (L10)
history:
The Albatros C.III succeeded the Albatros C.I as the manufacturer's operational armed reconnaissance aircraft. Designed by Ernst Heinkel, chief designer for Albatroswerke GmbH, the new C.III resembled its predecessor with a number of refinements. The C.III was slightly smaller than its predecessor, but was equipped with the same 150 or 160 h.p. power plant, resulting in better speed and rate of climb. Like the C.I, the C.III had wood framing. The fuselage was covered with a thin varnished plywood veneer, the wings and tail with doped fabric. Metal sheet surrounded the forward fuselage and engine. 

Flight trials of the new C.III in late 1915 were highly successful and the machine was immediately placed into mass production with its operational deployment beginning in the first weeks of 1916. Demand for the C.III was so great that in addition to its parent company it was also built under license by several other German firms. After reaching the Front, the C.III served with great distinction. Allied pilots found it robust and difficult to shoot down. Later deliveries of the C.III were also fitted with a propeller-synchronized machine gun, making the C.III the first two-gun operational C-type (German armed reconnaissance aircraft) and further adding to its defensive capability.

In the early summer of 1917 the C.III began to be replaced by a series of more advanced Albatros C-types. Albatros. Yet of all these C-type variants, the C.III was built in the greatest numbers and was deployed by the most units of the German Air Force. 

Following its withdrawal from frontline service the machine continued to be manufactured. Unarmed and fitted with dual controls, these later C.IIIs were widely used as trainers at German flight schools. Their deployment in this role continued until the war’s end. Of all Germany’s World War I C-type aircraft built by Albatros and other German manufacturers, the Albatros C.III was one of the most ubiquitous and most successful.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force.

title: Siemens-Schuckert D.III
history:
The Siemens-Shuckert (SSW) D.III was a single-seat biplane fighter developed as a replacement for the earlier SSW D.I. Chief engineer, Harold Wolff designed the aircraft around the new Siemen-Halske Sh III eleven cylinder air-cooled rotary engine, the largest and most powerful rotary engine in service at the time. In early production models, the engine was completely enclosed in a circular cowling. However, persistent cooling problems lead designers to remove a large portion of the lower cowling in later units (such as the one modeled here) in an effort to improve airflow. 

The first prototype D.III flew in January, 1918 with production models arriving on the Western front later that spring. The D.III exhibited an excellent climb rate and the Sh III engine maintained its power well at high altitudes. However, the D.IIIs' speed in level flight was only 112.5 mph (180 km/hr). As a result, the machines were largely assigned to interceptor duties. Further attempts to improve engine performance and speed resulted in the new D.IV variant.

The Siemens-Schuckert fighters remained in production until almost a year after hostilities ceased. Examples of the aircraft survived in Germany until as late as 1926.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified fighter unit, German Air Force, Western Front, October, 1918

title: Sikorsky S-23 Il'ya Muromets Veh
history: Russian Aircraft Designer, Igor Sikorsky originally developed the Il'ya Muromets as a large transport aircraft. Named for a popular Russian folk hero, the Il'ya Muromets was a massive four-engined biplane built by the Russian Baltic Railroad Car Factory (R-BVZ) and came complete with an enclosed cockpit and passenger cabin. The transport version, officially designated S-22 Il'ya Muromets B, flew a series of demonstration flights in the late spring and early summer of 1914 to drum up interest. When World War I began, a number of SS-22 B transports were delivered to the Imperial Russian Army, and a new order was placed for a version modified to serve as a bomber. The new bomber, designated S-23 V included more windows in the cockpit to improve the pilot's view. It also utilized a different fuel tank configuration. Rather than individual tanks suspended above each engine, the bomber version used two large fuel tanks tucked between the top of the fuselage and the upper wing. Since Russia had no aircraft engines, the power plants, including Argus, Sunbeam, Salmson and Renault, were all imported from European suppliers. However, production delays often forced the Russian military to scavenge engines from crashed or retired aircraft. This lack of adequate engines plagued the entire line of bombers. After their first bombing raid on February 15, 1915 the Sikorsky Il'ya Muromets flew more than 400 missions against Prussia and Germany and remained in active combat service until the Russian Revolution of 1917 ended their participation in World War I. Model Builder's Comments: The nose & fuel tank configuration in this model resemble those used in the B-type transport aircraft. However, the fuselage configuration is distinctly that of the V-type bombers.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Eskadra Vozdushnykh Korablei (Squadron of Flying Ships), Russian Imperial Air Force, Eastern Poland, February, 1915.

title: Grahame-White Type XV Boxkite
history: The Grahame-White Box-kite was first developed in 1912 by Claude Grahame-White, founder of Britain's first flying school at Hendon. The aircraft served as a trainer for students at the school before being converted for military use. The Box-Kite appeared in several different variants as time progressed and there is some debate as to how that progression should be characterized. Some scholars refer to the Box-Kite as the predecessor to the Grahame-White Type XII and Type XV, while others state that all the variants of the machine were eventually renamed to the Type XV. The earliest version of the aircraft resembled the Farman biplane of 1909. It included both fore and aft elevators, a pusher engine and was controlled from an exposed position directly over the mid-point of the lower wing. Later variants, like the one modeled here, included a pilot's nacelle, more powerful engines and wings with a staggered span. In November of 1913, a Box-kite piloted by Marcus Manton participated in an air-firing test at Bisley, England. The plane was equipped with a Lewis machine gun and the gunner, Lieutenant Stellingwerf, successfully managed to hit ground targets during two passes of the target range, thus demonstrating the potential for the airplane as a weapon of war. The Grahame-White XV began equipping flight schools for the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service in December of 1913 and served as a basic training aircraft. The Grahame-White Type XV modeled here is based on a late variant in the series -likely from 1916. The aircraft depicted was based at the Royal Flying Corps aerodrome at Hendon, north of London. Model Builder's Comments: This model incorporates a compilation of features from several Grahame-White variants. The pilot nacelle and staggered wings suggest it is a later model, but the large anti-nose-over skids on the aircraft's undercarriage were mostly used in early versions. The model also shows a 9 cylinder engine consistent with the 1913 version but with an installation appropriate for the 1916 model.
deployment: This model represents a two-seat trainer, Hendon, England.

title: Brandenburg KDW
history: In early 1916, the German Navy issued a specification for a seaplane defensive fighter. The German firm Hansa-Brandenburg based at Warnemunde-Rostock responded with the Brandenburg KDW. The new seaplane was essentially a modified version of an existing land based fighter -the Hansa-Brandenberg D.I. The land-based D.I was deployed almost exclusively by Germany's ally, the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Although reasonably fast, the D.I had experienced very limited success. The aircraft suffered from poor stability and flight qualities, which rendered it inferior to its Allied opposition. Except for two pontoons in place of wheels, the new KDW shared the same construction as the D.I. Like its predecessor, the KDW utilized a unique system of intra-wing struts with four sets of triangular posts meeting at their apex giving the struts a "star-like" appearance. This arrangement eliminated the need for additional bracing wires thus reducing wind resistance and, like it did for the D.I, gave the KDW excellent speed. However, the KDW also inherited the D.I's poor stability and handling, which were only made worse by the added weight of its pontoons. When KDW seaplanes became operational in late 1916, they were able to engage reconnaissance seaplanes and large slow moving bombers with a reasonable chance of success, but they were at a distinct disadvantage in combat with contemporary land-based fighters. KDW No. 748, modeled here was the first prototype built, but records indicate it also saw operational service. This particular aircraft was based at the German Seaplane facility at Angernsee. The KDW's finest moment occurred on September 23, 1916 when No. 748 flown by Lieutenant Fritz Hammer engaged a Russian Sikorsky Ilya Muromets heavy bomber. Making repeated passes, Hammer severely damaged the bomber, forcing it to crash land in a nearby meadow. During all of World War I only two of Sikorsky's giant bombers were ever shot down, making this air victory a very historical event. The KDW was eventually replaced by the Albatros W.4 -another German seaplane fighter- which had far superior flight capabilities and armament. Of the nearly 2,500 aircraft deployed by the German Naval Air Service during the War, only 58 were Brandenburg KDWs. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts a KDW equipped with a chimney-style exhaust stack. While this was a common configuration for KDWs, aircraft No. 748 was constructed with stubbier exhaust pipes on the port side of the nose.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of I Seefliegerabteilung (I.SFA), Seeflugstation Angernsee, Baltic Coast, September, 1916.

title: LePère 11 (C-11, C II)
history:
When the United States entered World War I in 1917, it did not possess any American-built military aircraft aside from the line of maritime reconnaissance flying boats built by Glenn Curtiss. The American military instead purchased all its fighters and bombers from England and France. The LePère 11 was commissioned by the United States Army Air Service in an effort to meet the need for an American-made fighting aircraft. 

The LePère 11 -also known as the LUSAC 11-was actually designed by a French aeronautical engineer named Capt. Georges LePère who was working for the U.S. Army. According to the Smithsonian Directory of Airplanes, the name "LUSAC" stands for "LePere United States Aircraft Corp". LePère designed the machine around the American Liberty engine. A two-seat biplane, the LUSAC 11 was intended to serve as a fighter, light bomber and reconnaissance platform for the U.S. Army Air Service.

Construction of the aircraft was undertaken by the Packard Motor Car Company of Detroit, Michigan. After favorable test flights, the U.S. Bureau of Aircraft Production ordered as many as 3,525 of the machines. However, as of the Armistice only 28 LUSACs had been delivered, two of which had made it to France for operational trials. With the cessation of hostilities, the Army immediately canceled the remainder of the order.

The completed aircraft continued to fly in the Army Air Service and a specially modified LUSAC 11 set a number of altitude records at Wright Field, Ohio in the early 1920s.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft believed to have been stationed at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, November, 1918.

title: Albatros D.II (L17)
history:
The Albatros D.II represents one in a line of consistently improved Albatros fighters. The D.II modified a few features of the previous D.I including a lowered top wing with a larger cutout over the cockpit. These modifications provided better forward and upward visibility for the pilot. The D.II was designed by Herren Thelen, Schbert and Gnadig, three aeronautical engineers with Albatroswerke GmbH. The D.II was built not only by its parent company but also under license by the German company LVG (Luft-Verkehrs-Gesellschaft). 

Albatros D.IIs arrived on the Western Front in November 1916. By January 1917, over 200 had joined the fighter units of the Central Powers. To counter the D.IIs, the Allies introduced their new fighters - French SPADs and Nieuports and the new British Sopwiths. In turn, the Germans produced their new Albatros D.IIIs and Vs and Fokker fighters. These newer machines out-performed the older Albatros D.IIs, which were gradually withdrawn from frontline fighter units. 

After the withdrawal of the D.IIs, Germany sent many of these now-surplus machines to the Ottoman Empire. The Ottoman Air Force needed an aircraft to patrol the vast desert areas of the empire and to control British-backed Arab insurgencies. After a small modification, the D.II served this purpose. The original design of the D.II featured two radiators located one on each side of the forward fuselage. Operating in desert heat, these radiators would often boil over. To avoid this, the dual radiators were replaced by a single flush mounted radiator placed in the center of the upper wing.

The historical records of World War I are unclear about the success or failure of the D.IIs while serving with the Ottoman Air Force in the Middle East. It is known that they remained with Ottoman fighter units until the war's end in November 1918.
deployment: This model represents a single seat biplane fighter, Palestine, November 1917.

title: Lloyd C.V (Series 46)
history:
The design and construction of the Lloyd C.V began in early 1916. The Austrian aircraft company Ungarische Lloyd Flugzeug und Motorenfabrik developed the Lloyd C.V as an armed reconnaissance aircraft for spotting and controlling artillery fire. Some of these machines included early wireless radios for communicating with the ground artillery units for which they were spotting.

The Lloyd C.V included a number of unusual features. While most aircraft of the era were covered with a doped fabric, the Lloyd C.V's wings and fuselage were covered with a skin of fine wood veneer. This resulted in an aerodynamically efficient surface but led to condensation problems within the sealed wing structures. Condensation caused the wing structure to warp. 

Efforts to correct this problem never fully resolved the issue. The radiator for the aircraft's liquid-cooled engine was placed immediately behind the propeller in the direct line of the pilot's forward vision. As a result, the pilot was forced to lean out the side of the cockpit in order to see ahead during flight. Some Lloyd C.Vs (like the one modeled here) also included a "coffin-like" structure on the top of their upper wing, which housed a fixed forward firing machine gun. While the placement of the machine gun on the top of the upper wing was common among early World War I aircraft the addition of a surrounding enclosure was not. 

Lloyd C.Vs saw extensive service as reconnaissance aircraft with the Central Powers on the Eastern Front before Russia's withdrawal from World War I. Due to a relatively short range of operation they saw less use on the Western Front and because of poor performance at high altitudes; they saw very little service on the mountainous Italian Front. At the height of their service, 12 Fliks (squadrons) of the Austro-Hungarian Air Force were equipped with the Lloyd C. V. There were two major versions of the aircraft, the Lloyd C.V Series 46 with a 185 hp (138 kW) Daimler engine and the Series 46.5 with 220 hp (164 kW) Benz engine.

title: Voisin 3
history:
The Voisin 3 was one of the earliest flying machines to be deployed in military service and holds a number of historical "firsts" among early warplanes. Designed by the pioneering French aeronautical engineer, Gabriel Voisin, and built by his company, Société Anonyme des Aéroplanes G. Voisin, the light bomber first flew in 1913. The Voisin 3's construction consisted of a wood framework covered by fabric along its wings and tail surfaces and varnished wood veneer around its fuselage. The aircraft's design also included several unique features. Its power plant, which drove a pusher propeller, was a liquid cooled radial engine at a time when rotary air cooled engines were almost universal. The Voisin 3's undercarriage was laid out in an unusual four wheeled arrangement, which gave the machine a level horizontal stance when resting on the ground. This afforded the pilot greatly enhanced forward visibility compared to more traditional "tail dragging" aircraft. The Voisin 3 was also one of the first aircraft to be fitted with armament -in this case, a machine gun on a flexible mount in front of the forward cockpit. These features combined to make the Voisin 3 one of the heaviest aircraft in service during the early months of World War I. 

At the outbreak of war, numbers of Voisin 3 were among the 138 airworthy flying machines within the inventory of the Aviation Militaire and over 800 were eventually deployed by the French. The Voisin 3 became the standard bomber of the Aviation Militaire during the first two years of the War and was deployed in both daytime and nighttime bombing sorties. It was also the first French aircraft to achieve an air victory when, on October 5, 1914, a Voisin 3 shot down a German Aviatik biplane.  In addition to those bombers flown by France, over 100 Voisin 3s were flown by the British Royal Flying Corps and over 30 were flown by both the Belgian and Russian Air Forces. The Italian firm Societa Italinia Transaerea also built over 100 under license; these were supplied to the Italian Air Force. In total, well over 1,000 of the bombers saw service during the early stages of World War I, making the Voisin 3 one the most ubiquitous of all aircraft types flying during that period of the conflict.

title: Gotha G.V
history: The Gotha twin-engine bombers entered service in 1916 just as the German High Command realized that using large, slow-moving Zeppelins for bombing missions over England was no longer practical. The Gotha G.IV and G.V (modeled here) bombers represented a viable replacement for the airships. The Gotha bombers proved so successful that all German twin-engine bombers were commonly called "Gotha" regardless of their manufacturer. The G.IV and G.V differed little in their appearance and configuration. The chief difference between the two was the location of their fuel tanks -the IV's were located in the bottom of the engine nacelles, while the V's were in the center of the fuselage. The shift to the fuselage was to reduce the risk of fire due to the proximity of engine heat. The Gotha machines included unique defensive armament modifications. Metal screens were mounted on either side of the rear gun position to prevent the gunner from accidentally shooting into the machine's "pusher" propellers. Gothas also had a "gun tunnel" the bottom of the rear fuselage immediately behind the gun position. This opening allowed the rear gunner to defend the traditional "blind spot"- that area behind and below the aircraft. The first Gotha daylight raids on England began on May 25, 1917 and continued until September. During a single raid on June 13, 1917, Gotha G.V bombers dropped nearly 4,536 kg (10,000 pounds) of bombs on London killing 162 and wounding another 450 and causing great consternation among the British public. Early Gotha daylight raids experienced little opposition, but as Allied warning systems, anti-aircraft ground fire and fighter aircraft defenses improved, they began sustaining serious losses. Gotha operations were then shifted to night raids when opposition was less formidable. Overall, the Gotha bombers were quite successful in creating discomfort among Allied civilian populations, especially Londoners. They were deployed in this role until the War's end. Model Builder's Comments: German daytime bombers were often painted in a light blue color, night bombers in a dark lozenge pattern. This model represents an aircraft configured for daytime operation.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Bombengeschwader 3 (Bomber Wing of the Army High Command), Ghent, German Occupied Belgium, May, 1917.

title: Salmson 2 A2
history:
The Salmson 2 A2 was the best reconnaissance aircraft placed in service by the French during World War I. Its advanced design finally provided the French with the reconnaissance aircraft for which they had been searching during the first three years of the War. Upon its entry into service, the new Salmson machine quickly replaced the older British-designed Sopwith 11/2 Strutters and the French built Farman, Breguet and Dorand machines, which had previously constituted the majority of the reconnaissance aircraft deployed  by the French. 

Designed in 1917 by the French aviation Société de Moteurs Salmson, the aircraft entered service with the Aviation Militaire at the beginning of 1918. By the War's end, eleven months later, over 3,200 had been manufactured by Salmson and under license by several other French companies. The aircraft equipped no fewer than 28 French reconnaissance escadrille and some 705 of the aircraft were in service with units of the United States Army Air Force. 

The aircraft was essentially designed around the Salmson 9 cylinder 230 hp liquid-cooled radial piston engine. The machine's circular radiator was positioned immediately behind the propeller in front of the engine, giving the power-plant complex a very compact and aerodynamically efficient configuration. Not only was the Salmson 2 A2 a fine reconnaissance platform, but its aerodynamic properties and armament made it relatively competitive as a fighter or light bomber. 

Overall, the Salmson 2 A2 was a highly successful and respected aircraft. Numbers remained in service with the Aviation Militaire and with the air services of other nations into the mid 1930s.

title: LVG C.II
history:
The LVG C.II (modeled here) was designed and built by the German aircraft company Luft-Verkehrs GmbH (LVG) as an armed-reconnaissance aircraft capable of defending itself against improved allied air defenses. The C.II was constructed of standard wood framing. The cockpit was enclosed in plywood, while the rear fuselage, wings and tail surface were covered with doped fabric. This model depicts an aircraft with sheeting extending back past the cockpit. While some references hint that some LVG aircraft may have been configured with similar "armor", it is unclear if such a configuration was ever applied to a C.II. 

Perhaps the LVG line's most famous moment occurred on November 28, 1916 when a specially fitted machine flew over London and dropped six 22 lb bombs on Victory Station. Some records indicate that the aircraft involved was a C.II, while others cite it as a later C.IV model. All the LVG variants appeared similar externally, differing only in their power plants and in their internal framing. This makes it difficult for historians to distinguish between model types, and as such, considerable discrepancies exist between sources. While the attack caused considerable civilian panic and consternation, it caused little damage. 

LVG C type aircraft, of all variants, remained in front line service until the War's end. In August of 1918 no fewer than 500 LVG C types were flying for the German Air Force.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force.

title: Bristol M.1C Monoplane Scout
history:
The Bristol M.1C first flew in July 1916. As a monoplane, the Bristol M.1C was unique for its time. Virtually all of its contemporaries were biplanes or triplanes. Frank Barnwell designed this aircraft with a drag-reducing propeller spinner, few bracing wires to detract from the aircraft's speed and performance, and a smooth, aerodynamic fuselage. Barnwell also discard the wing warping method of lateral control used in previous monoplanes in favor of standard aileron control. These features created an aircraft capable of speeds up to 132 mph.

Despite its attributes, the British showed little interest in the 125 Bristol M.1Cs, perhaps stemming from a bias against monoplanes. Two other monoplane fighters were used in the war by the French and British, but neither of these achieved much acceptance with their respective air forces. The British War Office largely delegated its Bristol M.1Cs to a training role. No British Royal Flying Corps squadrons operating in France were equipped with the Bristol M.1C aircraft. The RFC No. 150 Squadron, however, flew 35 of these machines in Salonika, Greece. Still, most of the Bristol M.1Cs not sent to the Middle East spent the war as trainers, and their speed and performance were not used to their full potential.

title: de Havilland (Airco) D.H.6
history:
The D.H.6 was designed by the famous Geoffrey deHavilland, chief aeronautical engineer with the British aviation firm Aircraft Manufacturing Company Ltd. (Airco). Originally intended to serve as a two-seat trainer for the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service, many were modified into single-seat maritime patrol aircraft because of their ease of handling, flight stability and endurance. The reconnaissance version (modeled here) replaced one crew member with a long-range fuel tank and added a small bomb load. 

D.H.6 trainers entered service at flight schools in early autumn of 1917 and naval reconnaissance variants began equipping units of the Royal Naval Air Service a few weeks later; both versions were popular with their pilots. Documentation of the of the D.H.6's record against submarines and surface vessels is not available. However, they continued to be deployed by the Royal Naval Air Service until the end of the war. Although the aircraft was slow and carried a small bomb-load, the de Havilland (Airco) D.H.6 must be considered one of the most effective light coastal reconnaissance bombers of World War One.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 47 Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service, Royal Naval Air Station, Pembroke Dock, Wales, United Kingdom, June, 1918.

title: Sopwith 1 1/2 Strutter Two-Seat Fighter
history:
The Sopwith 1 1/2 Strutter was the first British fighter to have a machine gun synchronized to fire forward through its propeller arc. Designed and built by the Sopwith Aviation Company, it acquired the name of "1 1/2 Strutter" from its characteristic W shaped cabane wing struts. Though the name was originally unofficial, the Royal Navy Air Service and the Royal Flying Corps later adopted the name after it entered common usage. 

Two variants of the 1 1/2 Strutter existed -the two-seat fighter modeled here and a single-seat light bomber. The bomber version eliminated the rear crew position in order to carry a bomb load within the machine's fuselage. A total of 1,513 of both variants of the 1 1/2 Strutter were built in Great Britain during World War I. British demand for the machines eventually exceeded the ability of its parent company to supply the needed aircraft. Other companies began to manufacture it under license, including the British firms Fairey; Morgan & Co.; Hooper; Westland; Vickers; Mann & Egerton; and Ruston & Proctor. Several French aviation companies also built both the two seat fighter and the single seat bomber version under license. A total of 4,497 of both variants were manufactured by the French, more than three times the number built by the British. 

In the spring of 1916, British fighter units in the Royal Navy Air Service began flying the 1 1/2 Strutter. Later the Royal Flying Corps also ordered the machine to use on the Western Front. However, by the close of 1916, the 1 1/2 Strutter was becoming obsolete and by the middle of 1917 most of the British machines were being withdrawn from frontline combat service. 

The French continued to employ numbers of the aircraft well into 1918 and sold some of the French-built 1 1/2 Strutters to the air forces of the United States, Russia, Belgium, Romania, Japan and Greece. Many of these foreign exported machines fulfilled training roles. By the early 1920s the outdated 1 1/2 Strutters had passed from the scene.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Royal Naval Air Service No. 3 Wing, Gosport, England, October, 1916.

title: Curtiss JN-4 Jenny
history: The Curtiss JN-4, more commonly known as the "Jenny" was the most widely used training aircraft in the United States during World War I. The aircraft was stable, reliable, rugged and easy to fly -perfect for training young pilots. Virtually every American airman and many Canadian pilots who flew during World War I first learned to fly in the Jenny and over 6,400 Jennies of several different variants were produced in the United States and Canada. The Jenny combined the best features of two earlier Curtiss aircraft, the model J and the model N. The JN-4, was a biplane in a tractor configuration, like its predecessors. The Jenny was a two-seater, and could be configured with either wheels, or a float undercarriage. As such, the aircraft could provide for the needs of both the Army Air Corps and the Navy. Though the Jenny was originally designed as a military trainer, the aircraft type was used successfully in a much broader capacitiy. In March of 1916, eight early Jennies of the First Aero Squadron under Capt. Benjamin Foulois participated in the Mexican punitive expedition in search of the rebel Pancho Villa. After World War I, many of the surplus machines were sold on the civilian market to serve again as trainers, barnstormers, air show participants, crop dusters and in the air-mail service; several even starred in movies When the Air Commerce Act of 1926 established rules and regulations regarding construction and maintenance of aircraft, and the training of pilots, the Jenny could not fulfill the new stringent requirements. However, the Jenny surely remains one of the most interesting historical aircraft on record. Several still reside in places of honor in museums and private collections around the world.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Signal Corps Aviation School, United States Army, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, March 1918.
tech: Manufacturer: Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Co. title: Nieuport 23
history:
The Nieuport 23 was developed in an attempt to improve upon the very successful Nieuport 17 fighter. The Nie.23 included a new interrupter mechanism which required that the aircraft's Vickers gun to be mounted slightly off the aircraft's centerline. The aircraft also included a slightly modified rear spar and upper wing, and most Nie.23s were fitted with a larger 120 hp Le Rhône engine than the earlier Nie.17.

The Nieuport 23 entered service in early 1917, but records suggest they were plagued with problems. A notice from the General Chef de Service Aéronautique suggests that the aircraft were likely prone to losing their lower wings while performing stressful maneuvers. The notice grounded the aircraft until the lower wings were replaced by those of the Nieuport 24 and reinforced with additional cables.

Most Nieuport 23s were replaced by S.P.A.D. fighters by the summer of 1918, though some were flown in combat by the Belgian Air Force, the British Royal Flying Corps, the Imperial Russian Air Force and, on the Western Front, with the 23rd Escadrille of the Aviation Militaire and the famous Lafayette Escadrille. Although the Nieuports were relegated to a training role late in the war, designer Gustave Delage continued to improved the design and several improved models with larger engines were flown under the Nieuport-Delage name until the 1930s.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the 23rd Escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, June, 1917.

title: Rumpler Taube (Dove)
history: The Rumpler Taube was one of the earliest aircraft types in military service. In the decade following the Wright brothers' 1903 flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, numerous aircraft manufacturing companies sprouted up across Europe. Each built aircraft for sale on the civilian market supporting wealthy sportsmen in their desire to fly. While these early aircraft were not designed for military purposes, military leaders of the pre-World War I era recognized the potential value of "flying machines" as reconnaissance platforms. The German aircraft industry was very active in the design and production of civilian machines. Five German firms Albatroswerke, Etrich-Flieger-Werke, Gotha Waggonfabrik, Harlan Verkaufs und Betriebs, and E.Rumpler Luftfahrzeugban all built aircraft which, because of their overall appearance and the configuration of their wings, came to be called “ Tauben” (doves). Of these, the Albatros and Rumpler Tauben were acquired by the German Air Force. All Tauben were large single-winged monoplanes that used wing-warping for lateral control –a system which required a maze of wing-mounted cables and bracing wires. The Rumpler Taube modeled here first flew in the summer of 1913. It was built from wood framing and doped fabric covering, except for metal sheeting around the engine in the forward fuselage. Configuration of these aircraft varied considerably, even among those built by the same manufacturer, as new innovations, engines and customer desires were incorporated into individual aircraft. As a result the specification information provided below should be considered nominal rather than definitive for all Tauben. Like all of its early contemporaries, the Rumpler Taube was unarmed. Furthermore, its construction, especially its under-carriage, was poorly suited for the rigors of military service on aerodromes -which were converted from farmers' fields- and so breakage was common. Worse, absent proper hangars, the machines sat in the open when not flying. There, the elements took their toll on the Tauben' wood framing and fabric skins. Records show that a total of 60 Rumpler Tauben were built, a number of which appeared on the rosters of the German Air Force at the beginning of World War I. Tauben were noted for their stability and some quipped that a pilot could step out of the cockpit and lie down on the wing to nap and the aircraft would continue to fly along safely. However, by late 1915, Tauben were no longer listed in the German Air Force inventory of aircraft, having likely been replaced by more modern and better performing machines.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Aufklarungsgruppe 3, German Air Force, August, 1914.

title: Sopwith Salamander (2.T.F.1, T.F.2)
history:
The Sopwith T.F.2 was developed to meet the British Air Ministry's need for an armored ground attack aircraft. Though officially designated "T.F." for "Trench Fighter", the T.F.2 quickly acquired the nickname, "Salamander". The Salamander was essentially a modified version of the Sopwith Snipe fighter aircraft. The Salamader looked very similar to its predecessor, and utilized the same powerplant -the Bentley B.R.2 230 hp (172 kW) engine. However, the forward fuselage of the Salamander was an armored box surrounded by steel plates: 0.43 inches (11 mm) on the bottom, 0.31 inches (8 mm) on the front, 0.23 inches (6 mm) on the sides and 0.39 inches (10 mm) behind the cockpit. This armor protected the pilot, engine and fuel tanks from ground fire. Experimental configurations of the Salamander also carried up to eight guns firing down through the floor of the fuselage.

Despite the weight added by the armor, the Salamander's speed was not dramatically reduced. Its maneuverability was, however, adversely affected. Designers felt this was not critical given the new machine's mission. By the War's end, at least 37 Salamanders had been delivered to the Royal Air Force. The concept of aerial ground attack was new and British pilots had no experience in such operations. Air crews were still in training with their new armored Salamanders when the War ended with only a few aircraft having reached France. Production of the Salamander continued until the middle of 1919 with a total of 334 built by Sopwith and 85 by the other manufacturers. None ever saw combat but the concept of aerial ground attack proved vital during World War II and continues to be so today. The Sopwith Salamander began it all.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified squadron, Royal Air Force, England, November 1918.

title: Blériot XI-2
history: Blériot XIs equipped eight squadrons of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force) at the beginning of World War I in 1914. Constructed entirely of wood and fabric except for a small amount of metal sheeting about the engine in the forward fuselage, the Blériot XI was designed, built and first flown in 1909. The aircraft received world wide acclaim in July of that year when its designer, Louis Blériot, personally flew the machine across the English Channel from France to England -a substantial feat for the time. Several variants of the Blériot XI were built. They were all shoulder-winged monoplanes, with the exception of a parasol-winged variant designed for artillery spotting. The variants differed primarily in their power plants, their internal framing and their crew capacity. Among them were the XI-Ecole Militaire a trainer with a 35 hp engine, the XI-2 Genie (modeled here) a twin-seater with a 70 hp (52 kW) engine and the XI-3 a three-seater with a 100 hp engine. The aircraft began service with the French military in 1909. When the British Expeditionary Force was deployed to France in 1914, seven squadrons of Blériot XIs were sent in support. Blériot XIs, built under license by the Italian aircraft firm Societa Italiana Transaerea (S.I.T.), equipped six squadrons of the Italian Air Force when Italy entered World War I. Blériot XIs served primarily as reconnaissance aircraft. However, the first aerial night bombardment of the war was conducted in late 1914 by unit BL 18 who flew Blériot XIs to attack German factories at Metz. By the summer of 1915, the Blériot XI was rendered obsolete by the appearance of more modern spotter aircraft with better handling characteristics and downward visibility. Blériot escadrilles were converted to Moraine-Saulnier Type Ls or Caudron G.3s while the aging Blériots were reassigned as trainers. An authentic surviving World War I Blériot XI was filmed in the 2006 World War I Hollywood movie Fly Boys, a film centered around the exploits of American aviators flying for the French in the Lafayette Escadrille. Although not airworthy, the Blériot XI was frequently seen in the background during scenes shot in a replicated World War I French aerodrome. In addition to rental fees, a condition for its use was that the producers of the film to take out a huge insurance policy on the rare old aircraft. Model Builder's Comments: The vertical stabilizer in this model features a static upright with a movable rudder attached. Production Blériot XIs typically had a single-piece stabilizer that rotated on a pivot point.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, August, 1914.

title: Radley-England Waterplane
history: The Radley-England Waterplane was one of three aircraft originally entered to compete in the 1913 Daily Mail waterplane race around Britain. Built by early aviators, James Radley and Gordon England, the Waterplane faced stiff competition from machines built by Sopwith and the Short Brothers. Unfortunately, the Radley-England team was forced to withdraw before the race due to engine problems. The Radley-England design utilized a common overall configuration for seaplanes of its time. The craft was a biplane with two pontoons and a "pusher" propeller. The aircraft did, however exhibit a couple of very unique features. Rather than including a standard cockpit or flying-boat hull, the Radley-England's pilot and passengers occupied separate cockpits positioned in the center of each pontoon. The aircraft was first configured with a single cockpit in each pontoon with the pilot and one passenger occupying the right float and up to three passengers in the left. This configuration was later scrapped in favor of two smaller, tandem cockpits in each pontoon. In addition to the unusual seating arrangements, the Radley-England Waterplane also utilized a highly unique engine configuration. The aircraft was designed to make use of three 50 hp Gnôme engines mounted in tandem to drive a single propeller. This unusual configuration was later replaced by a more conventional 150 hp Sunbeam engine. While the Radley-England Waterplane was created at a time when the British Navy was becoming interested in seaplanes for military use, there is no evidence that this plane was mass produced, nor that it ever participated in World War I. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts the Radley-England Waterplane in British naval markings. The source for this paint scheme is unclear. The model also depicts the aircraft equipped with a single Gnôme engine and small cockpits in each pontoon, each capable of carrying a single person. Again, the source material for this configuration is unclear, but may represent a blend of the aircraft's two known revisions.
deployment: This model depicts the Radley-England Waterplane in British naval markings.

title: Sopwith 11/2 Strutter Single-Seat Bomber (1.B1)
history: In 1916, the bomber and army cooperation escadrilles of the Aviation Militaire were flying outdated Farman and Caudron and Voisin aircraft. While design work was progressing on improved replacement for these machines, delivery of production aircraft was not scheduled to begin until the middle of 1917. To better meet the needs of its bombing and army cooperation units, France ordered a number of Sopwith 1 1/2 Strutters from its British allies and began building the aircraft under license. Two variants of the 1 1/2 Strutter existed -a two-seat fighter and a single-seat light bomber (modeled here). The bomber version, which the French re-designated the 1.B1, eliminated the rear crew position in order to carry a bomb load within the machine's fuselage. The French-built aircraft included a smaller empennage (tail section) which resulted in improved low-altitude performance. A total of 4,497 of both variants were manufactured by the French, more than three times the number built by the British. The French continued to employ numbers of the aircraft well into 1918 and sold some of the French-built 1 1/2 Strutters to the air forces of the United States, Russia, Belgium, Romania, Japan and Greece. Many of these foreign exported machines fulfilled training roles. By the early 1920s the outdated 1 1/2 Strutters had passed from the scene. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts an aircraft armed with a forward-firing Lewis gun mounted on the top wing. However, other sources indicate that the bomber variants were more commonly equipped with a propeller-synchronized machine gun mounted on the forward fuselage.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Escadrille SOP 107, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, June, 1917.

title: AGO C.II
history:
Built by the German firm AGO Flugzeugwerke, the  AGO C.II, was among a group of flying machines designed and built in immediate response to the out break of World War I. Three variants -the AGO C.I, C.II, and C.III- were built by AGO Flugzeugwerke. All were similar in their external appearance, but the C.II was the most successful and was built in the largest numbers. All  AGO variants had wood framing with a varnished wood veneer covering the central gondola-like fuselage and the two laterally placed tail booms. The wings and tail were fabric covered. The machine was a "tail dragger" but had a pair of wheels forward of the fuselage to counter the possibility of a "nose-over" when taking off and landing on the rough surfaces of the airfields from which it operated. 

The AGO C.II was one of the few German aircraft types with a "pusher" configuration -the engine being at the rear of the machine's fuselage with its propeller pushing the aircraft through the air. German aircraft designers largely regarded this configuration as being inferior to the "tractor" type in which the machine's engine and propeller were positioned at the front of the aircraft thus pulling the machine through the air. 

The AGO C.II worked well, and proved to be maneuverable and relatively fast with a good operational range. Its crews, in general, regarded it favorably. Like all of the aircraft deployed during the earliest phases of the War, the C.II served as a reconnaissance platform. But the AGO C.II differed from other aircraft of the time in that it was armed with a machine gun in its forward cockpit manned by its observer. This was unique because, during the early phases of World War I, almost all military reconnaissance machines were unarmed. 

AGO C.IIs operated over the Western and Eastern Fronts during the later half of 1915 and most of 1916. By late 1916 they began to be replaced by more modern reconnaissance aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the German Air Force, Western Front, August, 1915.

title: Phönix D.I (Type 8) (Imperial Navy)
history:
In 1917, the Austrian arm of the Albatros Company changed its name to Phönix Flugzeugwerke AG. The firm's senior engineer, Edmund Sparmann, designed the Phönix D.I in an effort to provide the Austro-Hungarian Air Force with an improved fighter. The D.I incorporated several unusual features for a fighter aircraft of the time. These included inward-sloping intra-plane struts on the wings, a 200 hp (149 kW) engine and dual forward-firing machine guns which were completely enclosed in the fuselage. The first production machines entered service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force in February of 1918. Their performance proved adequate but not truly outstanding. Despite a more powerful engine, the aircraft still suffered from a poor power to weight ratio, which contributed to their poor performance characteristics. Nonetheless, the fighter became the favored aircraft for several Austro-Hungarian air aces during 1918. The D.I's production was limited to only 140 machines -120 for the K.u.K. Luftfahrttruppen (the Austrian Air Force) and 20 for the Austrian Navy. Production of the Phönix D.I was terminated in mid 1918 in favor of the Phönix D.II and D.IIa. Both aircraft had lighter structures, and substantially improved performance. The The D.IIa was also fitted with a more powerful 230 hp (172 kW) engine. After World War I, Edmund Sparmann developed a series of Phönix fighters for the Swedish Air Force, which would prove even more successful than his World War I Phönix fighters. The most colorful Phönix D.Is (like the one modeled here) were those in service with the Austro-Hungarian Navy. The Navy variants were deployed from a base at Altura in the defense of the Austro-Hungarian naval bases at Pola and Cattaro, which were frequent targets of Italian bombers.
Model Builder's Comments: Like many Austro-Hungarian aircraft of World War I, the prototype of this Navy Phönix D.I model had red and white wing and tail stripes, replicating the colors of the monarchy's coat of arms, a copy of which is displayed on the rudder of the aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified Austro-Hungarian Naval Flik (Squadron), Altura Airdrome, Austria, June, 1918.

title: Sopwith Tabloid (S.S.)
history: On October 8, 1914, just two months after the outbreak of World War I, Lieutenant R.L.G. Marix of the Royal Naval Air Service, destroyed the German airship Zeppelin Z.IX and its storage shed at Dusseldorf while flying a Sopwith Tabloid. This event marked the first significant bombing attack by a British aviator. Marix dropped two small incendiary bombs causing the airship's hydrogen filled gas cells to ignite turning the Zeppelin into an inferno. The Tabloid began as a racing and demonstration aircraft in 1913, well before World War I. During its official trials at Farnborough, the aircraft returned performance figures that surpassed aircraft of the time. After a seaplane version blew away the competition at the Schneider Trophy race in April of 1914, the British military took interest. Both the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service placed orders for the aircraft. Tabloids saw extensive service over the Western Front during the early weeks of the War. During this early period military aircraft were usually unarmed with pilots employing their personal pistols and rifles in aerial combat. In the very early spring of 1915 machine guns were fitted to Tabloids in some squadrons. They served with distinction on the Western Front but were also used in the Mediterranean and Middle East theaters of operation. Production of Tabloids ended in the spring of 1915 as they were phased out and replaced by more capable machines. However, a numbers of Tabloids remained deployed on the home front as Zeppelin interceptors and as trainers while others were employed as reconnaissance aircraft on the Western Front and in the Middle East. Some had lingering careers in civilian life following the War. Model Builder's Comments: The prototype for this model was a Royal Naval Air Service Tabloid, which was fitted with a Lewis gun, mounted on the starboard side of the cockpit to fire through the propeller arc. Metal plates on the propeller deflected any bullets that struck it.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 1 Squadron, Royal Naval Flying Service, Gosport, England, April 1915.

title: Nieuport VI
history:
The Nieuport VI, modeled here, was one of the first aircraft deployed in war. The VI was, however, originally designed and built for civilian purposes. French aviation company, Société Anonyme des Établissements Nieuport, hoped to sell the new machine to wealthy sportsmen, smitten by the flying craze which swept Europe after the Wright brothers successful flight. First flown in late 1910, the VI was a shoulder-winged monoplane which employed wing-warping for lateral control. This arrangement required extensive wire cables on the upper and lower surfaces of its wing. It had a relatively clean, aerodynamic contour for its time and was constructed of wood framing with a fabric covering -except for sheet metal about the engine and forward fuselage. 

On June 21, 1911, Nieuport sponsored a promotional air show in an effort to boost weak sales of the aircraft. During the show, the VI set a new world speed record of 83 mph (134 km/h). Sales of the VI soared and the aircraft became very popular on the civilian scene. The Nieuport's record-setting flight also drew the attention of the French military. Leaders recognized the potential value of a fast aircraft, which could fly over enemy territory and report on positions and troop movements. With this in mind, the Aviation Militaire purchased a number VI aircraft. No significant modifications were required for their military service and all of the VIs were placed into a single reconnaissance escadrille. When World War I broke out in August of 1914 the escadrille was immediately placed into operation on the Western Front. 

The VIs were as successful in their military role as they had been when flown for sport. However, they had very brief careers. By the autumn of 1915 new German fighter aircraft, which were faster than the VIs, appeared over the Western Front. Worse, the new fighters were equipped with synchronized machine guns. The unarmed VIs were totally outclassed and by late 1915 had all been withdrawn from French service. The VI kept flying somewhat longer with two of France's allies -Italy and Russia. Both countries continued to deploy the aircraft until early 1916 when they too retired their VIs.

title: Aviatik (Berg) D.I
history:
The Aviatik D.I was the first single-seat fighter entirely designed, built and produced in large quantity by the Austrians. The work of Julius von Berg, chief engineer of the Vienna firm Österreichisch-Ungarische Flugzeugfabrik Aviatik, the D.I was often referred to as the "Berg Scout" in recognition of its designer. A fighter intended for operations on the Italian Front, the Aviatik fighter was developed to replace the unpopular Hansa-Brandenberg D.I, which had earned the ominous nickname, "The Flying Coffin". 

The new Aviatik D.I utilized conventional construction techniques for the time -wood framing with a thin plywood veneer covering of its fuselage and doped fabric covering of its wings and tail surfaces. However, Berg also incorporated some unusual design features into the aircraft. When it became apparent early on that two side-mounted radiators were insufficient to cool the D.I's engine, Berg shifted to a large car-type unit built in the nose. The pilot also sat relatively high in the cockpit, placing his eye-line just below the upper wing, affording him good all-around visibility.

Initial trials of an unarmed Aviatik D.I prototype were conducted on January 24, 1917 and showed the machine to have considerable promise. It was ordered into production by the Austro-Hungarian High Command with the first armed production aircraft entering service with Fliks (squadrons of the Austro-Hungarian Air Force) during the spring. Over 700 of the type were eventually manufactured by Aviatik and under license by other Austrian aviation firms, including Lohner, Lloyd, and Thöne und Fiala.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Flik 18, Luftfahrtruppe (Austro-Hungarian Air Force), Western Front, November, 1917.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2c
history:
The Royal Aircraft Factory (R.A.F.) B.E.2c developed from a series of experimental aircraft designed by Edward Teshmaker Busk in an effort to develop an inherently stable airplane. The first B.E.2c flew in the months immediately before the outbreak of World War I. When England entered the conflict, large orders for B.E. 2s were placed by both the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service for use as reconnaissance aircraft. The numbers ordered were so enormous that production, under license, was spread among a number of British aviation companies- Bristol, Vickers, Ruston Proctor, Armstrong Whitworth and Wolseley. 

The B.E.2c was a two-seat biplane of standard wood and fabric construction. The B.E.2c had some success as a reconnaissance and bombing platform. However, the appearance of the Fokker monoplane, which was equipped with a propeller-synchronized machine gun, exploited the B.E.2's weak-points -its lack of armament and poor maneuverability. As air-to-air combat became more common, many attempts were made -mostly by the pilots- to mount machine guns on the B.E.2c. One method (modeled here) involved mounting a rear-firing Lewis gun between the cockpits. This arrangement proved particularly impractical as the observer/gunner seated in the front cockpit had to fire directly over the head of the pilot.

Losses of the aircraft became severe enough that the machines were largely withdrawn from solo reconnaissance duties and were deployed in force as bombers usually with a fighter escort. Others were deployed in Homeland Zeppelin interdiction with at least three Zeppelins having been destroyed by B.E. 2s. By late 1917 B.E. 2s had been largely replaced in all combat roles by more modern aircraft. A few labored on as trainers until the end of the War. A single World War I RAF B.E. 2c remains in existence today on display in the Imperial War Museum in London, England- the sole survivor of some 2,600 produced during the Great War.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No.14 Squadron, Royal Flying Corps, British Expeditionary Force, Arabian Theater, March, 1917.
