title: Hannover CL.IIIa
history: In the early summer of 1917 the Idflieg (German Inspectorate of Flying Troops) issued a specification to the German aircraft industry for a new "CL" class of aircraft which could serve as escorts for the larger C-class reconnaissance planes. The Hannover based firm Hannoversche Waggonfabrik AG responded with a new machine designated the Hannover CL.II. Two further variants of the aircraft soon followed and differed only in their engines and wingtip design. These were the CL.III and the CL.IIIa (modeled here). The CL.IIIa was a compact, two-seat biplane. It featured a plywood-covered fuselage that was highly resistant to battle damage. The aircraft's wings and tail structures had wood framing with a doped fabric covering. The Hannover aircraft also included an unusual biplane tail. This configuration was adopted to reduce the span required when only a single tail plane was employed. The tail design reduced blind spots and gave the observer/gunner a broader field of fire. The crew's visibility was also aided by the position of the top wing, which was almost level with the top of the fuselage. Prototype flight trials were completed in November of 1917. While the new machine had average speed, its robustness, handling, and rate of climb were outstanding. The new model was given rave reviews by its test pilots and manufacture of the aircraft was immediately ordered by the Idflieg. Production aircraft equipped schutzstaffeln (protection squadrons) of the German Air Force by January of 1918. Allied pilots often mistook the two-seat escorts for single-seat fighters, not realizing their mistake until the rear gunner fired off a stream of bullets from his Parabellum machinegun. The CL.IIIa proved to be a formidable opponent even after the allies knew what they were dealing with. The aircraft's plywood skin made it bullet resistant and very difficult to shoot down. Although they arrived quite late on the scene, 537 CL.IIIa's were placed into service with the German Air Force during the final ten months of the War. During that interval they were among the most numerous reconnaissance and escort aircraft deployed by the Germans on the Western Front, the only theater over which the Hannover CL.IIIa operated.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Flieger Abteilung 7, German Air Force, Western Front, October, 1918.

title: Curtiss N-9
history:
The N-9 seaplane, which began development in late 1916, was essentially a float-equipped variant of the JN-4 Jenny training aircraft. The N-9 was a quite large machine for a training aircraft of the World War I era. Built of wood framing, it had a plywood veneer over its fuselage with doped fabric covering of its wings and tail surfaces. A thin metal alloy surrounded the engine. Its central pontoon and bilateral wing floats were also of metal construction. Aside from the floatplane undercarriage, The N-9 differed from its landplane equivalent primarily in its wingspan and the shape of its airfoil -the wing having been extended to generate the extra lift necessary to compensate for the weight of the float.

Four hundred-fifty N-9s were produced during World War I. Entering service at United States Navy flight schools in April, 1917 they served as the standard seaplane trainer. In its initial configuration, the N-9 proved adequate for basic training. However, in order to meet the power needs for advanced gunnery and bomber training, later models were outfitted with a more powerful Hispano-Suiza engine. After World War I, the N-9 remained the Navy's principle seaplane and flying boat training aircraft for the next decade. 560 aircraft were produced before the type was retired.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the United States Navy Flight School, United States Naval Air Station, North Island, San Diego, California, August 1918.

title: Sopwith 1 1/2 Strutter Single-Seat Bomber
history: The Sopwith 1 1/2 Strutter was the first British aircraft to have a machine gun synchronized to fire forward through its propeller arc. Designed and built by the Sopwith Aviation Company, it acquired the name of "1 1/2 Strutter" from its characteristic W shaped cabane wing struts. Though the name was originally unofficial, the Royal Navy Air Service and the Royal Flying Corps later adopted the name after it entered common usage. Two variants of the 1 1/2 Strutter existed -a two-seat fighter and a single-seat light bomber (modeled here). The bomber version eliminated the rear crew position in order to carry a bomb load within the machine's fuselage. The single-seat variant was used primarily by the Royal Naval Air Service, though some were delivered to the Royal Flying Corps. A total of 1,513 of both variants of the 1 1/2 Strutter were built in Great Britain during World War I. British demand for the machines eventually exceeded the ability of its parent company to supply the needed aircraft. Other companies began to manufacture it under license, including the British firms Fairey; Morgan & Co.; Hooper; Westland; Vickers; Mann & Egerton; and Ruston & Proctor. Several French aviation companies also built both the two seat fighter and the single seat bomber version under license. A total of 4,497 of both variants were manufactured by the French, more than three times the number built by the British. In the spring of 1916, British units in the Royal Navy Air Service began flying the 1 1/2 Strutter. Later the Royal Flying Corps also ordered the machine to use on the Western Front. However, By the close of 1916, the 1 1/2 Strutter was becoming obsolete and by the middle of 1917 most of the British machines were being withdrawn from frontline combat service. The French continued to employ numbers of the aircraft well into 1918 and sold some of the French-built 1 1/2 Strutters to the air forces of the United States, Russia, Belgium, Romania, Japan and Greece. Many of these foreign exported machines fulfilled training roles. By the early 1920s the outdated 1 1/2 Strutters had passed from the scene. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts an aircraft armed with a forward-firing Lewis gun mounted on the top wing. However, some sources indicate that the bomber variants were more commonly equipped like their fighter counterparts with a propeller-synchronized machine gun mounted on the forward fuselage.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 76 Squadron, Royal Flying Corps, Western Front, June, 1917.

title: Harlan Taube
history: Germany's first mass-produced military aircraft were called Tauben (Doves) -so named because of the bird-like shape of their wings. Austrian designer, Igo Etrich developed the first prototype Taube, before licensing the design the Rumpler aircraft. Variants of Etrich's design were soon being produced by at least 54 German and Austrian aircraft firms, including Harlan-Flugzeugwerke (modeled here), which produced at least four known variants. This aircraft was in that group of "flying machines" which were a part of the German Air Force when World War I erupted in August of 1914. Most Tauben featured a single aileron and unique split rudder configuration. Most variants, including this Harlan model were two-seat monoplanes. The Taube modeled here was likely an early variant from 1911. The aircraft includes a long bracing girder beneath the wing, which was absent in later Harlan designs. The Harlan Taube flew unarmed except for sidearms carried by pilots and served primarily in a reconnaissance role. The German Air Force acquired several of these machines in 1913 and they were available at the outbreak of World War I. The precise number of Harlan Taube aircraft deployed by Germany is unknown -probably very few because the initial 1913 acquisition was never augmented. It is known that during the first days of War, Germany flew Tauben during reconnaissance sorties in support of advancing German ground troops. The aircraft proved to be poorly suited to the rigors of combat service and their careers were very short lived. Their frail wood and fabric construction could not hold up to the rough fields and cow pastures from which they operated. Undercarriage damage and mechanical failures were common. By early 1915 the Harlan Taube had disappeared having been replaced by far better, more modern and more robust reconnaissance aircraft. Model Builder's Comments: Most Harlan Tauben displayed the manufacturer's name in large letters on the fuselage. This model depicts an aircraft repainted for military use.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Aufklarungsgruppe 3, German Air Force, Belgian and French Fronts, August/Early September, 1914.

title: Handley Page O/400 (H.P.12)
history:
The Handley Page O/400 and its predecessor, the O/100 were the principle British heavy bombers of World War I. British interest in acquiring a large bomber capable of carrying a heavy bomb load over long distances began in 1914 before the outbreak of World War I. The Royal Navy wished to monitor the movements of German U-boats and warships, which could interfere with the shipping lanes through which the greater part of England's food and raw materials were delivered. The aircraft firm, Handley Page Ltd. responded with a twin-engine machine designated the O/100, which proved successful as both a naval patrol aircraft and a land bomber.

Handley Page continued to improve the design of the O/100 and, in 1917, installed a new fuel system. The new system moved the aircraft's fuel tanks out of the engine nacelles, placing them instead in the fuselage and upper wing. This new version was re-designated the Handley-Page O/400 (modeled here). Like the 100, the 400 had wings that folded back against its fuselage, allowing storage in existing hangers. Other improvements and changes were structural in nature and were largely confined to the interior of the aircraft. The biggest difference between the two bombers lay in the more powerful engines of the 400. 

The O/400 first saw combat service in the spring of 1917. It flew U-Boat patrols and bombed German military depots and industrial targets. Over 400 Handley Page O/400 bombers entered service with the British Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Flying Service before the Armistice but only one British O/400 was ever based outside England or France. A single machine was sent to Palestine in July of 1918 to support the campaigns of Colonel T. E. Lawrence -better known as "Lawrence of Arabia". 

The American firm, Standard Aircraft Corporation, was also contracted to build 1,000 Handley-Page O/400s for the United States Army Air Corps. Instead of British Rolls-Royce power plants, the American O/400s were fitted with American Liberty engines. The day before their production began, WWI ended. As a result, the majority of the order was cancelled and only 107 aircraft were completed. The vast majority went straight into storage to be scrapped years later. However, seven were refurbished in 1920 and used in General Billy Mitchell's bombing trials on former German World War I warships anchored in the Chesapeake Bay -trials intended to prove the value of air power in naval warfare.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 97 Squadron, Royal Air Force, Stonehenge Aerodrome, England, September 1918.

title: Lebed VII
history:
Though Russia had the largest air force among the belligerent nations at the start of World War I, it also had the least developed aircraft industry, having relied primarily on imported designs to build its forces. With the onset of war, the country continued to import foreign aircraft and focused on building proven British and French airframes under license.

The Russian aircraft manufacturer, Aktzionernoe Obshchestvo Vozdukhoplavania V.A. Lebedeva (V.A. Lebedev Joint-Stock Aeronautics Company), which was founded by Vladimir A. Lebedev was just one of the firms producing foreign designs for the Russian Air Force. The Lebed VII modeled here was one such design and was based on the Sopwith Tabloid aircraft.

Lebedev modified Sopwith's original design for the Lebed VII. Realizing that his aircraft would be flying from rough and poorly maintained landing fields, he increased the strength of its internal framing and fitted their undercarriage with anti-nose over struts. The aircraft was otherwise very similar to its British counterpart. Like the Tabloid, the Lebed VII featured biplane wings of equal span and chord; it employed wing-warping for lateral control, and included the same distinctive engine cowling. The exact number of Lebed VII aircraft produced is unclear, though the manufacturer ordered and received sixteen tachometers from the Sopwith Company, which suggests that the production run was quite limited. 

The aircraft flew unarmed and was deployed strictly for reconnaissance and training purposes. A few may have been fitted with a machine gun thus theoretically making them reconnaissance fighters, but no official documents or photographic evidence has been found to support this claim. Records indicate that several Lebed VII aircraft crashed during takeoff and landing resulting in non-combat losses. The aircraft served with the Imprial Russian Air Force from 1914 until early 1916 and were removed from service by the time of the 1917 Russian Revolution.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of 21st Corp Detachment, Imperial Russian Air Force, Grodnensky Fortress, Eastern Front, June, 1915.

title: Fokker D.II (M 17ZF, M 17ZK)
history:
Design of the Fokker D.II began in early 1916 when Fokker aeronautical engineer, Martin Kreutzer, began developing an aircraft to replace the Fokker monoplanes. His machine, a biplane designated the M.17, was built in two variants. The single-bay variant was primarily deployed by the Austro-Hungarian Air Force which re-designated the aircraft B.III. The two-bay variant (modeled here) became the Fokker D.II.

The D.II was a slab-sided biplane powered by a 100 hp Oberursel rotary engine. It retained the comma-shaped rudder and wing warping used by the earlier monoplanes. The fighter was armed with one propeller-synchronized machine gun. 

D.IIs began equipping operational fighter units of the Bavarian and German Air Forces on the Western Front in July of 1916. Reflecting the markings on their fuselages, numbers of the machines acquired the nickname "black and white tails". Despite this endearing nickname, the Fokker D.IIs' operational careers were short lived. By early 1917 they had been relegated to flight schools as trainers, having been replaced by far superior Fokker and Albatros fighter aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Kest (Fighter Squadron) 4 D, Bavarian Royal Air Force (a division of the German Air Force), Freiburg, Bavaria, August, 1916.

title: Dorand Type A.R.2 A2
history:
In the early spring of 1916, Colonel Dorand of the Section Technique de l'Aéronautique (STAé) issued a specification to the French aviation industry for a new armed reconnaissance aircraft to replace the obsolete Farman "pusher" machines. The Farmans, which had been the main reconnaissance platforms for the French since the outbreak of World War I, were unable to defend themselves from the German and Austro-Hungarian fighters that had begun patrolling the skies over the Front. 

After being turned down by the Société Henri et Maurice Farman, which was first offered the contract for the new aircraft, STAé turned to aircraft engineer, G. Lépere. The aircraft Lépere created was a tractor biplane, which received the designation A.R.1.

The A.R.1 utilized conventional construction for the time -a biplane of mixed wood and steel framing, doped fabric covering and metal about the engine and forward fuselage. The aircraft's wings, however, were laid out in a unique negative-stagger configuration. The upper wing was placed slightly aft of the lower wing. Furthermore, the lower wing was not fixed to the fuselage but was, rather, suspended below on four heavy, wooden intra-wing struts. A later variant, re-designated the A.R.2 (modeled here) featured a more powerful engine and a slightly smaller wing surface.

Flight trials of the new Dorand A.R.s were completed in September of 1916 and the first production models arrived at the Western Front the following February. The new aircraft performed marginally better than the old Farmans, though not as much as initially hoped. As such, French air crews, while grateful to be rid of their old Farmans, never gave the newer Dorands anything more than grudging approval. 

Both the A.R.1 and A.R.2 flew side by side and were widely used throughout 1917. At one point they equipped 18 observation units flying over the Western and Italian Fronts. However, by 1918, the A.R.s began to be replaced by more advanced SPADs and Salmsons. After the War the A.R.1 and 2 were deemed redundant. Aside from a few which were sold to other countries and several which were sold on the civilian market, they were scrapped.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Escadrille AR 41, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, November 1917.

title: Caudron Type R.11 (R XI)
history:
The Caudron Type R.11 was designed by Paul Deville of the French aviation firm Société Anonyme des Avions Caudron to meet the Aviation Militaire's requirements for a long-range escort fighter. Some evidence suggests that the R.11 may have originally been intended as a multi-purpose reconnaissance, light bombing and escort platform, but operational units used the aircraft exclusively as an escort fighter.

The R.11 was of standard wood and fabric construction except for its engine housings and the forward and dorsal aspects of its fuselage, which were covered with aluminum sheeting. A biplane, the R.11's two engines were completely enclosed in unusual triangular housings mounted between its wings. The R.11 had three crew cockpits. The pilot flew the plane from the center position below the wing, while the two gunners occupied the fore and aft positions. The R.11's twin gun emplacements allowed the aircraft to bring considerable firepower to bear on attacking fighters without having to take evasive maneuvers.

The aircraft first entered service in early 1918, though production delays slowed delivery of the aircraft. R.11s were often assigned to specific groupes de bombardement (bomber groups) to provide escort services. It is unclear how successful the aircraft were against German fighters, but the at the time of the Armistice six escadrilles were each equipped with 15 Caudron Type R.11 aircraft. This suggests that they proved to be a useful asset.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Escadrille C 46, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, October, 1918.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory R.E.8
history:
The Royal Aircraft Factory (R.A.F.) R.E.8 was designed and built to address the shortcomings of its predecessor, the B.E.2c reconnaissance aircraft. Although over 2,000 B.E.2cs had been built they, suffered from poor handling characteristics and armament, which made them an easy target for enemy fighters. The new R.E.8 included a more powerful engine and much improved armament. The R.E.8 also reversed the cockpit positions -placing the pilot in the forward cockpit- this allowed the observer to act as a gunner as well. The B.E.2 had these positions reversed, which proved impractical once the necessity of defensive armament became apparent. Interestingly, however, the R.E.8 retained the inherently stable characteristics of its predecessor, which made evasive maneuvering more difficult.

Like its predecessor, the R.E.8's engine had a rather unique method of cooling. Its inline piston engine was air cooled instead of having a liquid cooling system with an external radiator which was common on most inline aircraft engines of the time. A large air scoop on top of the engine compartment channeled air across the cylinders. 

Production of the R.E.8 began in August of 1916 and the aircraft began equipping the Royal Flying Corps the following month. No fewer than 16 reconnaissance units eventually employed the machines. In addition to serving on the Western Front, the R.E.8 was used by two British squadrons based in Italy, two in Mesopotamia, two in Palestine and three home defense squadrons. Following its introduction into service, the R.A.F. R.E.8 quickly acquired the rhyming nickname "Harry Tate" after the British comedian. 

Despite its improved armament, the R.E.8 proved to be vulnerable to German fighters which necessitated its withdrawal from reconnaissance duties over enemy territory unless accompanied by a fighter escort. As the War progressed, many R.E.8s were diverted to ground attack and bombing operations. Others became trainers. Although some R.E.8s remained in service until the end of the War in various roles, by the last year of the War they had been largely replaced by superior Sopwith 11/2 Strutter aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 12 Squadron, British Royal Flying Corps, Western Front, December, 1917.

title: Fokker E.III (M 14)
history: Dutch aircraft designer, Anthony Fokker drew inspiration for the Fokker E-series of Eindecker (monoplane) aircraft from the French Morane-Saulnier Type H monoplane. After the outbreak of World War I in August 1914, the German High Command ordered numbers of Fokker's new aircraft for the German Air Force and designated them Fokker E.Is. The Fokker E.I was followed by new E.II, E.III and E.IV variants. The E.III (modeled here) was produced in the largest numbers. While all the Fokker monoplanes retained a similar appearance, the E.III had a more powerful engine than its predecessors. The Fokker E-series possessed a new and revolutionary device -a propeller synchronized machine gun. Rods connected the aircraft's rotary engine to the gun, which allowed it to fire without risk of hitting the propeller. Fokker called his new device "Stangensteuerung" - or "push-rod control." The accuracy afforded by this device gave the Central Powers an advantage in air power on the Western Front. Though only about 300 of the Fokker Eindeckers were built, they proved so effective that the Allies came to call these aircraft "the Eindecker Scourge." Despite their successful introduction, the service careers of the Fokker monoplanes were brief -extending from July 1915 to early 1916. By 1916, the Allies had introduced new, better performing machines that could compete with the Eindeckers. The E-series was soon retired from frontline fighter units, though a few lingered on briefly as trainers. By 1917 they had disappeared.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Feld Flieger Abteilung 53, German Air Force, Eastern France, October 1915.

title: Pfalz D.IIIa
history:
The Pfalz D.IIIa was a single bay biplane designed by Rudolf Gehringer, the senior engineer at the German firm, Pfalz Flugzeugwerke. The D.IIIa added modified wing tips and a new and more powerful engine to the original D.III model. The D.IIIa also somewhat resembled the earlier German L.F.G. Roland D.I and D.II fighters. 

The D.IIIa's structure allowed for an aerodynamic, efficient, and sturdy aircraft. The craft's wooden fuselage frame was covered by a thin wood veneer, allowing for a smooth, varnished finish. The machine's wings and tail also incorporated wood framing. These components, however, were covered with a doped fabric - a common construction technique of the time. 

The Pfalz D.III served as one of the main German fighters from late 1917 until summer 1918. The D.IIIa did not enter service until 1918. The D.IIIa reached its peak deployment on the Western Front in April 1918. At that time, German fighter units employed 433 of these machines. These aircraft, however, were gradually phased out in favor of the vastly superior Fokker D.VII. About 600 D.IIIs were manufactured during World War I, and about 350 remained in service in August 1918.

The aircraft modeled here was flown on the Western Front during the last months of World War I by Carl von Degelow, a member of the Jadgstaffel (squadron) 40, Germany Air Force.

title: Halberstadt CL.II
history: The Halberstadt CL.II was unique among its World War I contemporaries. In late 1916 the Idflieg (the German Air Force General Staff) conceived a machine which could function as a reconnaissance platform (a C-type), an infantry support aircraft (a J-type) and at the same time have sufficient attributes to be completive as a fighter (a D-type). Such an amalgamation of features was an ambitious order for aeronautical designers of the time. But German firm, Halberstädter Flugzeug-Werke GmbH, created an aircraft that exceeded expectations. The CL.II was constructed of wood framing with a thin plywood veneer covering its fuselage. Plywood also covered the center section of the upper wing which contained a flush-fit radiator for the machine's liquid-cooled engine. All of its other surface areas were covered with a doped fabric. The CL.II had a powerful engine and aerodynamically smooth appearance. The plane had only two sets of thin metal intra-wing struts and a minimum of bracing wires. This greatly reduced wind resistance and gave the CL.II outstanding performance. After wildly successful flight trials on May 17, 1917 the CL.II was ordered into production. It entered service on the Western Front in August of 1917 where it achieved immediate acclaim due to its excellent maneuverability, speed and climb rate. These features combined with the wide field of fire provided by the configuration of the machine's design, allowed the rear gunner to effectively engage enemy single seat fighters on equal terms. The CL.II also became the mainstay of the Schlachtstaffeln (close air-support squadrons). Seven-hundred CL.IIs were built by Halberstadt and demand for the aircraft became so great that a further 200 were produced, under license, by the German firm Bayerisvhe Flugzeugwerke (BFW). The machines remained in active front line service until the War's end. The colorful Halberstadt CL II modeled here was unit #14277/17 which on June 4, 1918 crashed on takeoff at its aerodrome in Bissenghem, Germany, seriously injuring its pilot, Paul Schwarze, and killing its gunner, Franz Schumm. Although not airworthy, a single World War I era CL II survives today on display at the Polish Aviation Museum in Cracow, Poland.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Schlachtstaffel (infantry-support squadron) 26b, Bissenghem Airdrome, Bissenghem, Germany, June, 1918.

title: Caudron Type G.4
history:
The Caudron brothers developed the G.4 to meet the Aviation Militaire's need for a more powerful "cooperation" aircraft -so-called because it's primary mission was to cooperate with ground forces by providing reconnaissance and spotting for artillery. The G.4 was a maze of bracing wires with twin tail booms and an armed gunner-observer compartment forward of the cockpit. The aircraft's two engines were housed in streamlined nacelles suspended between its upper and lower wings. Caudron developed several variants of the G.4 for different missions -the A2 for reconnaissance, the B2 for bombing (modeled here) and the E2 for training.

Caudron built a total of 1,358 G.4s during the course of World War I, which began operational service during the summer of 1915. Blériot, S.P.A.D. and Italian manufacturer A.E.R. also built the G.4 under license. The Italians found that the G.4's strong rate of climb and high ceiling made it well suited to operations over the Alps. The British Royal Naval Air Service also acquired several G.4s and assigned them to raids against German seaplane and Zeppelin bases in Belgium. However, the aircraft's inability to defend against attacks from behind soon led the Aviation Militaire to order a better armed reconnaissance aircraft. Some of the bombers remained in Italian service in the later months of the war but by 1918 they disappeared from the Western Front. None were operational outside Europe.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the 3rd Bomber Escadrille, Aviation Militaire, Western Front, December, 1915.

title: Borel Aeroyacht Type Denhaut I
history: The Borel Aeroyacht was one of several flying boats designed by French aviation pioneer, Francis Denhaut. He developed the Aeroyacht in 1912 for the French firm, Etablissements Borel, which entered the aircraft in the 1913 Paris-Deauville competition. The competition consisted of a race along the river, Seine from Paris to the city of Deauville on the English Channel followed by sea trials. It was set up to select two seaplane designs to enter production for the French Navy. The Aeroyacht, one of two Borel aircraft entered in the competition, featured a wood-framed hull covered with a varnished wood veneer. The aircraft's two crewmen sat side-by-side in its open cockpit. The sesquiplane wings and tail surfaces were framed in wood and had a doped fabric covering. Two outrigger stabilizing pontoons were mounted beneath each lower wing tip. A single 100 h.p. engine was mounted high on a steel framework behind the upper wing in a position intended to help avoid sea spray during takeoff and landing. Publications from the time indicate that the Aeroyacht was considered quite advanced and expectations were high. Unfortunately, the Aeroyacht's performance at the Paris-Deauville trials did not live up to expectations. The aircraft failed to finish the race and was subsequently disqualified from the sea-trials portion of the event. In the aftermath of the Aeroyacht's poor performance, Denhaut was fired from Borel. Two years later, however, he formed his own company, Donnet-Denhaut in partnership with Jerome Donnet. This endeavour proved more successful and the new firm went on to produce a series of seaplanes for the French Navy. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts an Aeroyacht as it might have looked in service with the French Navy. The model's configuration most closely resembles plan drawings of the Borel Aeroyacht Type Denhaut I, which appeared in 1913 issues of the aviation journals, Flugsport and Aero and Hydro. Photos of the Aeroyacht taken at the Paris-Deauville competition suggest the design had been further modified by the time of the race. These later versions are often referred to as Type II and III, respectively.
deployment: This model depicts an aircraft painted in the markings of the Aviation Maritime (French Naval Air Service), 1915.

title: de Havilland (Airco) D.H.4
history:
The de Havilland D.H.4 was the first British aircraft specifically designed for use as a daylight bomber. In January of 1916 Geoffery de Havilland, chief aeronautical engineer of Aircraft Manufacturing Company, Ltd. (Airco), responded to an official request by British military leaders for such an aircraft and the D.H.4 was the result. Geoffery de Havilland's new machine made its maiden flight in August of 1916 under the control of the designer himself. The powerplant originally specified for the D.H.4 was a 160 hp Beardmore water cooled engine. By the time the D.H.4 design was being prepared, however, this engine had been replaced by a larger, 230 hp version. The first production D.H.4s received this upgraded engine, or a 250 hp Rolls Royce V12, called the "Eagle". The D.H.4s, with their new power plants, fulfilled all performance expectations and in aviation circles the machines quickly acquired the name of its designer. 

The first production D.H.4s were delivered to No. 55 Squadron of the Royal Flying Corps deployed on the Western Front in March of 1917. They immediately gained popularity among their crews and came to be judged the best single-engine bombers then in service. Even with a full bomb load they retained excellent speed and handling qualities. After release of their bombs they could compete on equal terms with enemy fighters. The success of the D.H.4 created a demand that exceed the resources of Airco, and several other British aircraft firms began building the machine under license. Many were also built under license in the United States. The American models were fitted with the American 400 hp (298 kW) Liberty engine leading to their nickname "Liberty Planes".They served with the British Royal Flying Corps, the British Royal Naval Air Service, the Royal Canadian Air Service, the United States Army Air Force and the air services of South Africa and New Zealand. The ubiquitous D.H.4s were widely deployed in a multitude of roles on the Western Front and in other far-flung theaters of operation during the last two years of the War. 

Following World War I the machines were employed by both the Bolsheviks and the White Russians during the Russian Civil War of 1919. Post-war, more than 400 D.H.4s were modified for civilian service and used as transports and mail planes. In these roles they remained flying until 1932. The Airco D.H.4 was, without question, one of the finest and most successful aircraft of the era.

title: Avro 503 Seaplane (Type H)
history: The Avro 503 Seaplane was designed in early 1913 by the British aeronautical engineer, Alliot Verdon Roe, the founder of the Manchester-based aviation firm A.V. Roe & Company Ltd (Avro). At least three production aircraft were purchased by the Royal Naval Air Service, and were active when World War I began in August of 1914. The 503 was a two-seat biplane of standard wood and fabric construction. The seaplane undercarriage consisted of two pontoons covered with rubber-proofed cloth and sprung with rubber cord. The tail float attached directly to the bottom of the rudder and would move as the pilot steered. The 503 was able to be quickly dismantled for shipping -a common consideration in Avro designs. Interestingly, the prototype for the Avro 503 was sold to Germany prior to the start of World War I. The aircraft became the basis for the German, Gotha WD.I seaplane, which appeared in early 1914 and spawned a line of subsequent German seaplanes. Germany's Avro also became the first aircraft to fly between the German mainland and the small archipelago of Heligoland, located on the North Sea. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts an aircraft equipped with a 150 hp engine. While later Avro models, including the 510 seaplane sported engines of this type, the standard powerplant for the 503 was a 100 hp Gnôme engine.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 4 Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service, British Royal Navy Base, Scapa Flow, Orkney Islands, March, 1916.

title: Macchi M.9
history:
The Macchi M.9 (modeled here) was the last flying boat produced by Nieuport-Macchi during World War I. The M.9 was intended to provide the Italian Naval Air Service with a new long-ranged armed reconnaissance bomber which could patrol the Adriatic and Mediterranean Seas keeping track of, and attacking, the naval assets of the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman Empires.

Design of the new flying boat began in early 1918 and borrowed much from previous Macchi aircraft, particularly its immediate predecessor, the M.8. The hull-shaped fuselage was formed from wood framing covered by a plywood veneer. The area above the waterline was finished with a high gloss varnish, the area below the waterline with anti-fouling paint. The aircraft's wings and tail surfaces had wood framing with doped fabric covering and outrigger stabilizing floats positioned beneath the wingtips. The machine's single engine was enclosed in a metal housing mounted above the fuselage on a steel framework. Its enclosure and elevated position were intended to protect it from sea spray during takeoff and landing. 

Unfortunately for the Allies, Macchi M.9 aircraft did not begin equipping Italian naval squadrons until the autumn of 1918, only a few weeks before the end of hostilities. As a result, they saw very limited action and their contribution to the war effort was minimal. Military production of the M.9 was terminated with the end of the War, by which time only 30 had been completed and delivered. However, Macchi converted the aircraft type for civil transport with the M.9 bis variant. The civilian version had a range of 340 miles and included an enclosed cabin capable of seating a pilot and four passengers.

title: AGO Pusher Seaplane (1914)
history:
In early 1913, the German aviation company, AGO Flugzeugwerke (AGO) designed and built a reconnaissance seaplane for the German Navy. Its mission, in case of war, was to patrol the North Sea and follow the movements of the British Home Fleet based at Scapa Flow in the Orkney Islands. 

The AGO Seaplane is historic. It was probably the first aircraft to ever be constructed with amphibious capabilities. Positioned beneath each of its two pontoons were a pair of wheels and beneath its two tail pontoons were tail skids. These features allowed the AGO seaplane to take off and land from either land or sea. The aircraft was able to taxi into and out of the water on a concrete ramp. This ability proved advantageous by allowed the machine to quickly escape the corrosive effects of sea water when it was not flying. 

A large aircraft, the AGO Seaplane had typical construction for the time. Fabric covered the wood- frame of the aircraft's wings and tail surfaces while its fuselage and pontoons were covered with wood veneer. Two large petrol tanks were suspended beneath the upper wing endowing it with substantial operational endurance. 

At the outbreak of World War I in August of 1914, AGO Seaplanes of II.SFA patrolled the North Sea from their base at Wilhelmshaven. The patrols provided the German fleet -also based at Wilhelmshaven- intelligence on the movements of the British Navy, which was then the most powerful naval force in the world. Records indicate that during the opening weeks of the War, AGO Seaplanes played a role in following British ships involved in the naval blockade of Germany. 

The operational effectiveness of the AGO Seaplanes is unclear. Neither, is there reliable information available as to their duration of service. However, it is known that as of 1917, AGO Seaplanes were no longer listed in the inventory of operational German Naval aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of II Seefliegerabteilung (II.SFA) German Naval Seaplane Base, Wilhelmshaven, Germany, August, 1914.

title: Brandenburg C.I
history:
Early in World War I both Germany and its ally, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, designated their reconnaissance aircraft as type "C" machines. This policy extended throughout the War. The Brandenburg C.I was one of the more successful of these reconnaissance aircraft. It was designed in late 1915 by Ernst Heinkel the famous German aeronautical engineer. Upon completion of its design, production was shifted to the Austrian firm Phönix Flugzeug-Werke A.G. and the Hungarian, Ungarische Flugzeugfabrik A.G. One of the earliest production variants of is modeled here. 

Production aircraft entered service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force in early 1916. During the entire production run of the aircraft, which extended to the end of the War, no less than eighteen different variations of the machine were built. Externally all the variants appeared identical differing only in minor structural details and their increasingly more powerful engines. Framing of all the variants was of wood with a varnished wood veneer covering the fuselage and an aluminum casement around the engine. Intra-wing struts were metal, not wood, and were cantered inward - both were uncommon features for aircraft of the era. 

The machines were widely deployed in reconnaissance, observation, artillery-spotting and light bombing duties along all sectors of the Western, Italian and Russian fronts. They were highly regarded and became the favorites of their crews due to their excellent handling, agility, durability and dependability. The installation of ever more powerful engines continually improved the performance of the successive variants - a factor which engendered even greater crew approval. The Brandenburg C.I continued in constant service and became the "reconnaissance work horse" of the Austro-Hungarian Air Force until the War's conclusion in November of 1918.

title: Nieuport 21
history: The Nieuport 21 was one aircraft in the continuing lineage of machines designed and built during World War I by the French aviation company Société Anonyme des Établissements Nieuport. The aircraft incorporated the airframe of its predecessor, the Nieuport 11 and the wings of the Nieuport 17, but was equipped with the smaller, less powerful Le Rhône 9C 80 hp (60 kW) engine. The smaller engine was included because the Nieuport 21 was never intended to be a combat fighter. Rather, it was designed and built as an advanced trainer for fighter pilots. Most Nieuport 21 aircraft were employed by the French Aviation Militaire in its flight schools, however a few were assigned to front line units alongside Nieuport 17s. Beginning in early 1917 the French supplied substantial numbers of Nieuport 21s to the Imperial Russian Air Force, which used the aircraft as front-line fighters. Sixty-eight additional machines were built under license by the Russian firm, Dux, in St. Petersburg. The Nieuport 21 was the most numerous Nieuport aircraft serving with the Imperial Russian Air Force. The machine was very popular with Russian pilots despite its relatively small power plant, due to its excellent maneuverability and reliability. In addition to their French and Russian service, one hundred ninety-seven Nieuport 21 aircraft were purchased by the United States Army Air Force for use as trainers, while five aircraft were briefly deployed by the British Royal Naval Air Service. The prototype of this model was an active fighter with the Imperial Russian Air Force on the Eastern Front during the weeks immediately prior to the Russian Communist Revolution, an event which forced Russia's withdrawal from World War I. Following the Russian revolution, the machines remained a part of the Red Air Force and were not retired until 1926. Model Builder's Comments: This model replicates the insignia and markings employed by the Imperial Russian Air Force during its involvement in World War I.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the Imperial Russian Air Force, Eastern Front, January 1917.

title: Voisin 10 BN.2 (Type LAR)
history:
The Voisin 10 LAR was a successful night-bomber developed by French aeronautical engineer, Gabriel Voisin. Like the series of Voisin aircraft that preceded it, the Voisin 10 utilized a unique four-wheeled landing gear configuration. Two forward wheels were mounted on a delicate frame protruding in front of the fuselage nose, while the aircraft's two main wheels were positioned beneath the rear of the fuselage gondola. With this configuration, the aircraft remained horizontal while on the ground or during take-off and landing. This gave pilots greater visibility compared to a "tail dragging" aircraft.

The Voisin night bombers included a number of features designed to aid them in their mission. They were typically painted in an overall dark, flat gray or black for nighttime camouflage. To make night-flying easier, the Voisin 10 LARs also included nose-mounted landing lights, red and green wing tip recognition lights and an illuminated pilot instrument panel. Such lighting was unusual for World War I aircraft since most flying took place during daylight hours. Equally unusual for a World War I military aircraft were the two large torpedo-shaped petrol tanks suspended beneath the upper wing on either side of the fuselage. The machine's bomb load was carried beneath the lower wings.

Voisin-equipped escadrilles provided air support by attacking enemy troop formations and industrial targets during several battles, including Picardie, Flanders, Aisne, Santerre and Saint Mihiel. After the War, however, the Voisin 10 was soon replaced by more advanced aircraft.

title: Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI
history:
The Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI represents the largest fixed-wing aircraft of World War I. It could carry two 2,200 lb bombs; no other bomber had been capable of carrying even one before that time. Its wingspan measured over 138 feet. It weighed over 12 and a half tons when empty, requiring 12 or, on some machines, 16 wheels to support this weight. Each of its four engines powered an enormous 14 foot 5 inch propeller.

The Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI was designed to bomb major Allied cities, especially London. The bomber was huge, relatively slow and not very maneuverable. To make its missions more effective, the R.VI operated at night when it would be less vulnerable to Allied attack. Its paint scheme consisted of an overall dark mottled blue or a dark lozenge pattern, designed to camouflage the machine during night operations. Even the German black iron-cross insignias were applied without their usual white backgrounds to enhance the machine's stealth. 

With their large size, the Zeppelin-Staakens were time-consuming and costly to manufacture. Only 18 were built in all. Of those 18, the last two of the series added a fifth engine to the original design. Mounted in the fuselage behind the enclosed crew cabin, the fifth engine powered superchargers for the aircraft's four propeller-driving engines. This new revolutionary advance allowed these two Zeppelin-Staakens to reach a height of almost 20,000 feet even when carrying a full bomb load. Since Allied fighters and anti-aircraft ground fire could not function efficiently at such altitudes, the five-engined R.VIs were almost immune to Allied defenses. This model represents one of these five-engine versions.

Despite their few numbers, these bombers caused considerable damage. During the final months of World War I, Zeppelin-Staaken R.VIs flew 52 raids over London dropping 2,772 bombs weighing a total of 196 tons. On the night of February 16, 1918, a Zeppelin-Staaken dropped the first 2,200 lb bombs ever deployed in warfare. One hit the Royal Hospital in Chelsea, killing or injuring much of the medical staff and many of the institution's patients, the majority of whom were wounded soldiers from the Western Front. To date, the Zeppelin-Staaken R.VI remains the largest bomber ever to have attacked England.
deployment: This model represents a heavy bomber of the Reisenflugzeugabteilungen 500, German Flying Corps, operating from Northern Occupied France.

title: Fairey Campania F.22
history: The Fairey Campania, built by the British aviation firm Fairey, was the first aircraft to be specifically designed for service on an aircraft carrier. The British Royal Navy was the first to undertake the development of aircraft carriers. One of the earliest of these ships was HMS Campania, a converted Cunard transatlantic passenger liner for which Fairey's aircraft was named. The new aircraft was a large, single-engine floatplane. Due to shortages of the Rolls Royce Eagle V engine, the first production models were instead equipped with a Sunbeam Maori II powerplant. However, some Campanias, like the one modeled here, would eventually be upgraded to the Rolls Royce Eagle VIII, the most powerful aircraft engine built in Great Britain during the War. The 345 hp (257 kW) engine turned a monster propeller over 12 feet (3.81 m) in diameter. The aircraft was intended to launch from the carrier's deck, riding on a wheeled trolley. Upon returning to the carrier, the Campania would land on the water to be hoisted aboard by crane. A steel ring mounted in the center of the upper wing served as an attachment point for the aircraft's retrieval. Only 62 Campania aircraft were built before their production was terminated with the end of the War. They operated from the Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers, from shore facilities along England's coastline and from the Royal Naval Base at Scapa Flow in the Orkney Islands. A late arrival minimized their impact on World War I, but Campanias helped usher in a new concept in naval warfare-ship-based offensive aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Royal Air Force, Aircraft Carrier HMS Campania, Royal Naval Base, Scapa Flow, Orkney Islands, October, 1918.

title: Albatros C.X (L25)
history:
The Albatros C.X represents the pinnacle of a successful lineage of "C" class reconnaissance aircraft developed by German manufacturer, Albatroswerke. From the first weeks of the War until the Armistice, the series of Albatros reconnaissance aircraft was deployed in large numbers on all fronts by the German and Austro-Hungarian Air Forces. As the lineage progressed, its successive variants were equipped with ever more powerful engines, improved internal framing, along with increases in weight, size, and wing span. Despite these alterations, all the variants retained the same general appearance and the same excellent flight characteristics.

The C.X entered service in 1917 on the heels of its predecessor, the C.VII. The C.X included a larger fuselage, which provided space for the installation of an oxygen system in the pilot's forward cockpit, and radio equipment in the rear cockpit. The aircraft was powered by a 260 hp Mercedes engine -a significant increase in power over its predecessor. The C.X's wingspan was also extended, and ailerons were added to all four wingtips in order to maintain its level of maneuverability.

By October of 1917, some 300 Albatros C.Xs were in operation with multiple German reconnaissance units. The aircraft continued to operate until the end of the War. The final variant in the Albatros lineage, the C.XII began to appear in late 1917. However, because the C.XII provided only minor improvements over the C.X and because the earlier aircraft had a substantially longer operational career, the C.X has been chosen to represent the entire Albatros lineage in this collection.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified reconnaissance unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, June, 1917.

title: Short Bomber
history:
The Short Bomber claims the distinction of being the first aircraft, by itself, to attack and destroy a warship. In the early months of World War I, Britain lagged behind other countries in the construction of large heavy bombers capable of carrying large bomb loads over great distances. To address this deficiency, the British aircraft company, Short Brothers, created its "Short Bomber" as a transitional or "stopgap" aircraft. These machines filled the void until the British aircraft industry could produce true heavy bombers like the Handley-Page and Vickers machines. For a "stopgap" aircraft, the Short Bomber had an excellent career, especially considering its construction. With its single-engine design, the Short Bomber closely resembled an oversized fighter. 

Early in the war, the Short Bomber achieved a noteworthy place in the history of military aviation. On August 15, 1915, a land-based Short Bomber of the Royal Navy Flying Service torpedoed and sank a Turkish cruiser in the Dardanelles. This action represented the beginning of the transition of naval power from the large caliber heavy guns of battleships and cruisers to weapons carried and delivered by warplanes.

Nine hundred Short Bombers were built for the British Royal Navy. Most served as torpedo bombers and a few as horizontal bombers and reconnaissance aircraft. The Short Bomber performed well enough that the British Royal Flying Corps took 89 of the machines for use as bombers on the Western front. By the middle of 1917 the Short Bombers were being replaced on the Western Front by more modern and capable multiple engine bombers. The naval variants, however, remained in service until the war's end in November 1918.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory F.E.2b
history:
The Royal Aircraft Factory's F.E.2b was designed to provide the British Royal Flying Corps with an armed reconnaissance platform which could also perform as a fighter. Designed in 1914 in the era before engineering technology had established a means for firing a machine gun through a propeller arc without destroying the propeller, the R.A.F. F.E.2b was configured in a "pusher" configuration with the propeller mounted behind the cockpit. The aircraft had its twin machine guns positioned in its forward observer cockpit. The pilot was positioned in the rear of its fuselage, just ahead of the engine and propeller. 

The machine first flew on January 26, 1915, only a few months after the outbreak of World War I. It entered service with squadrons of the Royal Flying Corps the following summer. Interestingly, the Royal Aircraft Factory, which designed the machine, built only 47 of the aircraft out of a total production of over 1,900. The vast majority were built under license by six other British aircraft firms. 

Perhaps the F.E. 2b's greatest moment in World War I came on June 18, 1916 when an F.E.2b shot down the famous German air ace, Max Immelmann. Despite the large number manufactured, the F.E. 2b's operational career as a reconnaissance fighter was relatively brief. By the latter part of 1916 it was becoming painfully clear that the pusher type of aircraft was inferior to that of fighters which had a "tractor" engine which pulled them through the air. The appearance of German Albatros fighters with this tractor configuration vividly proved this point. As a result, after little more than a year's service on the Western Front in the role for which they were designed, the machines were withdrawn to England for home defense or were relegated to night bombing. Despite their obsolescence, numbers of R.A.F. F.E.2bs remained in active duty with the Royal Flying Corps in these secondary roles until the Armistice on November 11, 1918.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 25 Squadron, Royal Flying Corps, Western Front, November 1915.

title: de Havilland (Airco) D.H.2
history:
This machine was one of the earliest aircraft of World War I designed specifically as a fighter. The D.H.2 was produced by the British firm, Aircraft Manufacturing Company Ltd. (Airco). The aircraft acquired the name, "de Havilland", after its designer, Geoffery de Havilland, who would subsequently go on to develop and head one of England's most distinguished aircraft companies; a company which produced military and civilian aircraft throughout the twentieth century. 

The D.H.2 was a direct descendent of the D.H.1, a two seat reconnaissance machine also designed by de Havilland. The smaller, single-seat D.H.2 was otherwise very similar in both appearance and construction to its predecessor. Its fuselage and wings consisted of fabric stretched over wood framing. The aircraft had a single forward-firing Lewis machine gun in the nose with the engine and propeller in a "pusher" position behind the pilot, thus giving the machine gun a free field of forward fire. 

The first prototype D.H.2 flew on June 1, 1915 and the first production models entered service on the Western Front a month later with the 5th Wing of the British Royal Flying Corps. The D.H.2 proved to be a stable, durable and successful fighter. A machine of No.24 Squadron achieved the first Western Front D.H.2 air victory on August 9, 1915. A total of just over 400 were built and delivered to the Royal Flying Corps. Of these, 266 were deployed with the British Expeditionary Forces in France. By late 1916 and into 1917 these machines were gradually retired from active combat service, having been replaced by more modern and more heavily armed fighter aircraft. The D.H.2s labored on throughout the remainder of the war as training aircraft at Royal Flying Corps flight schools.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 24 Squadron, Royal Flying Corps, Western Front, September, 1915.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.12b
history:
The R.A.F. B.E.12b represents the final aircraft designed by the Royal Aircraft Factory (R.A.F.) during World War I. The aircraft's immediate predecessor, the B.E.12, was designed as a single seat fighter. The B.E.12 utilized essentially the same airframe as the earlier B.E.2c, but modified to accommodate a larger engine and better armament. Unfortunately, without further modifications to the airframe, the first B.E.12s proved sluggish in the air, making them ill-suited for fighter missions. The R.A.F attempted, but failed to significantly improve on the 12's performance with the updated 12a and, by early 1918, the poorly competitive B.E.12s were withdrawn from the Western Front and returned to England for home defense. 

In 1917, the Royal Aircraft Factory made one last effort to upgrade its B.E.12-with the B.E.12b. The most powerful aircraft in the series, the "b" model featured the new 200 hp Hispano-Suiza engine, which was the same used in the highly successful S.E.5a fighters. Unlike its predecessors, the B.E.12b was designed primarily for home defense. It was equipped with twin Lewis guns mounted on the upper wing, including one with a Hutton illuminated sight. 

B.E.12bs finally entered service in February of 1918 as interceptors defending London against German Zeppelins and bombers. By this phase of the war, German Zeppelin air raids were rare and so the B.E.12bs had few targets. Seeking to utilize the machines, the British Air Ministry outfitted most of the B.E.12bs with bombs and employed them in anti-submarine patrols along the coast. This model replicates one of these coastal defense B.E. 12bs. By War's end, well over a hundred 12bs were built, but only 39 ever reached their units, 36 of which were employed in home defense.

title: Sopwith Baby
history: With the outbreak of World War I, the Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS) realized a need for a fast, single-seat seaplane. To meet this need, the RNAS adapted the winner of the 1914 Schneider Trophy (a seaplane race) for military use. The winning aircraft, which was a seaplane variant of the Sopwith Tabloid, became known as the "Schneider". The aircraft was deployed in naval reconnaissance missions, and as a zeppelin interceptor. In September of 1915, a new version of the Schneider was developed. The variant, which was nicknamed the Sopwith Baby, included a more powerful 110 hp engine and redesigned forward fuselage characterized by its horseshoe-shaped engine cowling. The Baby also differed from its predecessor in its armament. While Schneiders were typically equipped with a single Lewis gun, angled to fire above the propeller arc, the Babies utilized a propeller-synchronized machine gun. Some later models were also provided a second machine gun. A number of Babies were equipped with Rankin explosive darts in place of guns for making anti-shipping attacks and at least one (the prototype of this model) was armed with 10 Le Prieur rockets. In this last configuration, five rockets were attached to the outboard bracing struts of the machine's wings. A total of 286 Babies were manufactured in Great Britain during World War I. Of these, 195 were built, under license, by the British aircraft firm Blackburn. Although identical to the Sopwith machines, they were often referred to as "Blackburn Babies". The Baby was also built, under license, by the Italian firm Ansaldo. Babies saw wide service throughout the War. They operated not only from costal bases, but were among the first aircraft to be deployed from capital ships and from Great Britain's early seaplane tenders and aircraft carriers. Babies were employed in a wide variety of mission roles -as fighters, reconnaissance platforms, anti-submarine and anti-shipping aircraft, and Zeppelin interceptors. The careers of the Babies essentially ended at the conclusion of World War I with a few lingering on in secondary service -all were all gone by 1920. Model Builder's Comments: The corrosive effect of sea water caused severe weathering of seaborne aircraft, especially to their undersurfaces and pontoons. This model attempts to replicate these changes in a Baby which had seen extensive service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified squadron, Royal Naval Flying Service, British Home Islands, October 1915.

title: Albatros D.III (L20)
history:
British pilots nicknamed April of 1917, "Bloody April" in reference to the incredibly high losses they suffered during the course of the month. The German Albatros D.III fighter played a significant part in the British air losses that April. Several German aces flew the D.III that April, including Manfred von Richthofen -better known as, "the Red Baron"- Werner Voss, Ernst Udet, Eduard von Schleich and Bruno Lorzer.

The Albatros D.III was designed as a successor to the D.II and was built by its parent company Albatroswerke GmbH at Schneidemuhl, Germany. The project utilized data gathered from captured Nieuport Scouts and was launched in an effort to restore air superiority to the Central Powers.

Design and production of the new Albatros machine took place under the direction of Robert Thelen, an Albatros senior engineer. He adapted the sesquiplane style 11/2 V-strut wing of the highly successful French Nieuport Nie.17. He combined this wing with the semi-monocoque varnished plywood fuselage of his earlier Albatros D.II and installed within his new D.III fighter the Mercedes D.IIIa supercharged engine. The new engine gave the D.III excellent power and performance at high altitudes. 

The prototype D.III first flew in August of 1916, but wing failures due to excessive flexibility of its lower wing required structural alterations. These delays meant that the new aircraft did not reach operational combat units until the following December. The first unit to receive the D.III was Jasta 1, commanded by Manfred von Richthofen. By the spring of 1917, thirty-seven Jasta had been supplied with the D.III. The presence of the new aircraft shifted the balance of air superiority to the Central Powers. 

Production of the D.III continued until early 1918 after some 800 had been built. Manufacturing at Albatros was then shifted to their newer Albatros D.V and D.Va variants. Although given an even more powerful engine and improved aerodynamic styling, the D.V and D.Va were only marginally better than the D.III from which they were derived. The Albatros D.III remained competitive and served alongside its successors until the last day of World War I.
deployment: This model represents a fighter of Jadgstaffel (Jasta) 5, Western Front, March, 1917.

title: Otto C.I
history:
The Otto C.I is an aircraft which has been largely lost in the annals of World War I history. Reports indicate that somewhere between three and nineteen C.Is were manufactured. As such, their obscurity is understandable. 

The Otto C.I was a "pusher" type biplane (with its engine and propeller at the rear), designed and built by Gustav Otto and his aviation company, Flugmaschinen-Werke Gustav Otto, based in Munich, Bavaria. Indeed, Bavaria had its own Air Force- the Royal Bavarian Flying Corps and was somewhat independent of Germany. The Otto C.I prototype's framing and inter-plane struts were made of duralumin, not wood -advanced for the time. But most unusual were the Otto C.I's twin booms supporting its tail surfaces. The first prototype flew in May of 1915 with production aircraft being delivered to the Royal Bavarian Air Corps shortly thereafter. 

The planes were immediately unpopular with their crews due to very sluggish performance and lack of mobility when attempting to evade enemy fighters. This was primarily the result of the substitution of steel for intended duralumin in the construction of the production models. The added weight this substitution inflicted was significant. 

Otto C.Is had very brief combat careers and were quickly withdrawn from operational service by the Bavarian Air Corps, which modified some into training aircraft. The majority of the remaining C.Is were transferred to Germany's ally, Bulgaria, who initially deployed them in their intended role of reconnaissance However, by the spring of 1917, the Bulgarians also recognized the machines' deficiencies and restricted them to training duties.

title: Felixstowe F.2A
history:
The Felixstowe F.2A was one of the largest flying boats of World War I. Its design and construction borrowed heavily from the American Curtiss H-12 and H-16 flying boats. Despite being complicated, time-consuming and expensive to build, the British Royal Flying Corps received 170 Felixstowe F.2As from November 1917 through March 1918.

The Felixstowe F.2A provided Britain with a long range maritime reconnaissance aircraft. It patrolled the North Sea, monitoring the German High Seas Fleet and attacking German submarines. World War I historical records contain little about the operational successes or failures of the machines overall. Although the outcome of the attack is obscure, Felixstowe F.2A No. 4543 (modeled here) attacked a German U-boat with its bombs on July 9, 1918.

Improvements in German naval fighters, however, threatened these large, slow flying boats. The fighters exploited a flaw in the F.2A's defenses. Machine guns in the rear fuselage could not fire to the rear least they damage the aircraft's tail. British engineers later corrected this defensive "blind spot" by installing an additional dual machine gun mount in the middle of the upper wing. A special cupola provided this upper wing gunner with an ideal 360 degree field of fire.

The Felixstowe F.2A impacted the design of later British aircraft. It represents the first military-built "fortress boat." Its defensive design established a basic formula for British flying boats through World War II. The Felixstowe F.2A's incredibly reliable engines also inspired the design of later British powerplants. These engines were the forerunner of the World War II Rolls-Royce Merlin engines, which powered numerous British aircraft including the Supermarine Spitfire, the Hawker Hurricane, the de Havilland Mosquito and the Avro Lancaster.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 230 Squadron, British Royal Flying Corps, North Sea, August 1918.

title: Vickers Vimy F.B.27A
history:
Despite its limited use during World War I, the Vickers Vimy represents the beginning of a long line of British Vickers bombers which served through World War II and even the "Cold War" of the late 20th Century. The Vimy, which was designed to have a range capable of bombing Berlin and other major German cities, entered development in the spring of 1917. The Vimy achieved its long range by relying on two Rolls-Royce engines which could function for hours without difficulty.

The first Vimy prototype flew on November 30, 1917 and the British Air Ministry immediately placed an order for 150 machines and later increased it to1,130. Given the size and the expense of the Vimy, this order was extraordinary. The Royal Flying Corps received only three Vimys, however, prior to the German capitulation in November 1918. These were still completing training with their new crews when the War ended and no Vimys carried out operational bombing raids during the War. After the War's conclusion, the Air Ministry reduced its large wartime order for Vimys to only 221 aircraft. 

No longer needed for the war effort, the Vimy participated in many post-war endurance flights, including the first non-stop trans-Atlantic flight. In June 1919, British pilots John Alcock and Arthur Whitten-Brown flew a specially modified Vimy 1,890 miles (3,042 km) from St. Johns, Newfoundland, to Clifden, Northern Ireland. Six months later, in December 1919, the Australian pilots and brothers Ross and Keith Smith flew a Vimy from England to Australia in a multiple segment flight of 11,130 miles (17,912 km).
deployment: This model represents an aircraft from an unidentified bomber squadron of the British Royal Flying Corps, September 1918.

title: LFG Roland C.II Walfisch (Whale)
history: The LFG Roland C.II represents a versatile German aircraft built by the aviation company LFG Roland. Just prior to the outbreak of World War I, the German aircraft company, Luftfahrzeug Gesellschaft (LFG), adopted the trade name “Roland” in order to avoid any confusion with another German aircraft firm Luft-Verkehrs GmbH (LVG). Prior to the name change in 1915, the LFG engineers designed and built the LFG Roland C.II, a revolutionary and streamlined biplane meant to serve as a reconnaissance aircraft. The C.II, however, was armed and could also function as a fighter. This unique craft was nicknamed “Walfisch" (German for "whale"). Unlike most biplanes of the era, both wings of the LFG Roland C.II attached directly to the fuselage. This arrangement eliminated the need for center section struts and reduced the wing’s rigging requirements, thus achieving reduced drag and a strengthened upper wing. The C.II also featured a special semi-monocoque fuselage. Each half of the fuselage was formed in a mold with alternate layers of a thin spruce veneer and fabric, each applied at an acute angle and glued one to the other to create the fuselage. The result was a light and very strong structure. The machine, however, did possess a few problems. Because the space between its wings was narrower than usual, the aircraft stalled easily. The Roland C.II’s thin wings were also prone to break under severe stress. Despite these drawbacks, the Roland C.II became highly successful as a long range reconnaissance craft during the early months of World War I. With its mounted machine gun, it could serve for both defense and offense at a time when many of the aircraft of both sides were either poorly armed or unarmed. Given its speed and successful performance, a fighter version of the C.II Walfisch was later designated, the LFG Roland D.I. This machine had only one seat, was slightly smaller, and included two fixed forward firing synchronized LMG 08/15 machine guns. By 1917, the LFG Roland C.IIs became obsolete in the face of improved Allied fighters. They were withdrawn from active reconnaissance roles and were transferred to German flight schools where they served as duel seat trainers for the remainder of the War. Model Builder's Comments: The C.II modeled here replicates the one piloted by Oberleutnant Ritter von Schleich. It displays a stylized whale mouth and eyes on the forward fuselage.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Feld Flieger Abteiling 2b, German Flying Corps, Western Front, April 1916.

title: Brandenburg W 29
history:
The Hansa-Brandenburg W 29 seaplane was developed as a replacement for the earlier W.12, which had seen some success during combat patrols over the North Sea and English Channel. The W 29 made use of the W 12's fuselage, but switched to a low-winged monoplane configuration. The prototype W 29's also sported a new 195 hp Benz engine. This was replaced in production models by the 150 hp Benz, which powered late-model W.12s. The W 29's fuselage was of wood framing covered with a smooth plywood veneer. Thin metal alloy surrounded its engine and radiator. Its wings and tail surfaces were fabric covered and its pontoons were metal. Like its predecessor the W.12, the W 29 had an unconventional inverted rudder, designed to provide the gunner with a clear rearward field of fire.

Despite its unorthodox appearance, the seventy-plus known W 29 floatplane fighters, which were manufactured, delivered very impressive performance and became a significant factor in the skies over the North Sea. W 29s flying from Zeebrugge disabled the British submarine C25, sank several torpedo boats and downed a number of British flying boats. These successes lead Allied flying boat crews to regard the Hansa-Brandenburg W 29 with a healthy respect.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Seeflugstation, German Naval Air Station Flanders, North Sea, May 1918.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2a
history:
The Royal Aircraft Factory (R.A.F.) at Farnborough was established from the H.M. Balloon Factory to design, build and test new aircraft. However, the facility drew a great deal of criticism because it often created its "new" designs by essentially rebuilding salvaged aircraft from other manufacturers. During World War I, Geoffrey de Havilland designed a series of "B.E." designated aircraft. The "B.E." acronym stood for "Blériot Experimental", because the aircraft were based on the designs of the famous French aviation pioneer, Louis Blériot. 

The B.E.2 was the second aircraft in the series, but differed little from its predecessor, the B.E.1. The B.E.2a modeled here had wood framing with doped fabric covering except for varnished plywood about the cockpit and metal sheeting about the engine. It employed wing warping for lateral control. The aircraft also
featured an air-cooled inline engine. This saved substantial weight and improved performance over aircraft with liquid-cooled engines. 

The B.E.2a first flew in the second week of August, 1912 when it took part in the British Military Trials on Salisbury Plain in England. It outperformed all its competition and British military leaders immediately placed production orders. Although over 3,100 B.E.2 aircraft were built by the end of World War I, only five prototype B.E.2a's were built by the R.A.F. The majority of the type were built under license by other British aircraft firms, including Armstrong Whitworth, Handley Page, British Colonial and Vickers. 

At the outbreak of World War I, B.E. 2a reconnaissance aircraft were sent to France along with the British Expeditionary Force. Among these was B.E. 2a No. 336, modeled here. A Vickers built machine, it went to France on August 13, 1914 and was one of the first aircraft of the War fitted with wireless communication equipment. 

By late 1916 the B.E.2a had been replaced in France by newer and far more competitive aircraft. Among these replacements were several newer R.A.F. machines designed by Geoffrey de Havilland. The B.E.2s returned to England where they were deployed in home defense and as trainers. By 1918 they had largely disappeared from military service. Some lingered on following the War in a variety of civilian uses.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 4 Squadron, British Royal Flying Corps, Western Front, August, 1914.

title: Farman (Maurice) M.F.7
history:
When World War I broke out in August of 1914, the French Aviation Militaire had 138 airworthy flying machines in its inventory. Among these were a number of Maurice Farman M.F.7 aircraft. These aircraft were designed in early 1913 by the young French aeronautical engineer, Maurice Farman. Although they were originally intended for sale on the civilian market, the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force) bought a number of the machines to serve as reconnaissance aircraft.

The M.F.7's construction was similar to that of many aircraft designed in the years immediately prior to the war. The plane was designed as a biplane with a forward canard wing, which connected to and acted in concert with its tail control surfaces. A central gondola-like fuselage seated the crew and housed a copper petrol tank and the aircraft's pusher engine. Its framing was made entirely of wood and it was covered with doped fabric except for the top of its gondola which was covered with a varnished wood veneer. The machine was a maze of wooden spars and struts, steel bracing wires and control cables. This gave the M.F.7 a fragile appearance, although it was a rather robust machine. 

Six escadrilles fielded the M.F.7 at the start of the War. While the aircraft began as reconnaissance machines, some escadrilles also used them as bombers and even fighters. The M.F.7 remained in front-line service until early 1915 when is began to be replaced by the improved M.F.11. Many of the aircraft, which were known for their easy handling, were redeployed as trainers and served in this capacity until 1917. The Maurice Farman M.F.7 remains noteworthy in the annals of military aviation history because it was one of the first aircraft to be deployed in warfare.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Aviation Militare (French Air Force), Western France, August, 1914.

title: Fokker D.VIII (E.V)
history:
In April of 1918, the German High Command held a competition to select a new single-seat fighter. German firm, Fokker Aeroplanbau GmbH submitted a modified version of Reinhold Platz's prototype, the E.V as their entry. The High Command selected Fokker's parasol-winged monoplane to enter production, and ordered 400 of the fighters. 

The first E.Vs joined the fighter squadron, Jagdstaffel 6 on the Western Front during the last week of July in 1918. Unfortunately, these initial units were plagued with structural problems. The machines' cantilevered wings began breaking up in midair, resulting in pilot deaths. All Fokker E.Vs were grounded on August 24, 1918, and a panel of inquiry was formed. Two theories for the wing failure developed. One suggested that extra reinforcement added to the wings reduced their flexibility and caused them to fracture under stress. The other suggested that, after the wing spars were attached, the joints were smoothed down too far, weakening the attachment points.

To address these problems, the wings of the existing machines were retrofitted, and changes were instituted in the manufacturing of new aircraft. The aircraft was re-designated the Fokker D.VIII and returned to combat just 3 weeks prior to the armistice. Given its brief career, the D.VIII achieved few combat victories. 

Following the war, the terms of the Treaty of Versailles denied these planes to Germany. At least two became a part of the newly created Polish Air Force and saw action against the Bolshevik Red Army. Other of these aircraft were evaluated and deployed by France, Canada, and the Netherlands. Single aircraft were tested, but never used, by Italy and the United States.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 8, Western Front, November 1918.
