title: A.E.G. D.I
history:
The German firm, Allgemeine Elektizitäts Gesellschaft (A.E.G) designed the D.I as a new fast and highly maneuverable fighter aircraft for the German Air Force. The new machine was the product of a collaboration between George Konig, A.E.G.'s chief design engineer, and Walter Hohndorf, a decorated German World War I ace and famous test pilot who brought his considerable flying and combat experience to the project. 

The A.E.G. D.I incorporated a number of unique features in its design. Its airframe was built entirely of steel tubing, rare at a time when almost all aircraft framing was wood. Further, a single steel spar supported the entire length of its wings making it possible to greatly reduce the supplemental wing bracing so common on other contemporary biplane aircraft. At Hohndorf's insistence, the aircraft also included an enormous exhaust pipe exiting the engine along the starboard side of the fuselage and extending behind the cockpit. The pipe was included in order to reduce distracting and deafening engine noise. 

The new fighter made its first appearance in May of 1917 and formal flight evaluations began at the German Air Force's test facility at Adlershot, Germany on June 28, 1917. The aircraft exhibited excellent maneuverability coupled with a speed of nearly 130 mph in level flight -among the fastest of all World War I aircraft. On August 21, 1917, in the course of its evaluation, a prototype D.I was placed into strenuous flight maneuvers by the highly skilled test pilot Lieutenant Julius Hendricks. During these maneuvers the machine went into a steep uncontrolled dive and crashed, killing Hendricks. Since the new fighter had displayed significant promise, testing of the D.I continued despite the crash. 

To further evaluate the A.E.G. D.I under actual combat conditions on the Western Front, at least one prototype was sent to Jasta 14, a fighter unit commanded by Hohndorf himself. On September 5, 1917, when flying the fighter he had helped design (No. D 4400 modeled here), Hohndorf crashed and was killed. An investigation revealed he crashed due to a mechanical failure of the aircraft. 

With the death of two outstanding and experienced pilots blemishing its record, Idflieg (the German Air Force High Command) canceled the A.E.G. D.I program. The remaining airframes were relegated to German Air Force flight schools as grounded hulks in the training of maintenance crews -an inauspicious end to the racy little fighter, which had initially looked so promising.
deployment: This model represents a WW I single seat biplane fighter, which underwent flight testing with Jagdstaffel (squadron) 14.

title: DFW C.V
history:
Early in World War I both Germany and its ally, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, designated their reconnaissance aircraft as "C-class" machines, a policy which extended throughout the War. In late 1915 the German aircraft manufacturing company Deutsche Flugzeug Werke (D.F.W.) began designing a new C-class reconnaissance platform -the D.F.W. C.V. The new aircraft first flew in May of 1916 and began equipping operational units of the German Air Force the following summer. The success of the machine can be best judged by the fact that about 1,000 were built during the War -the most of any single German aircraft type. 

The C.V was constructed with wood framing covered by a doped fabric skin, but its engine was enclosed in a rounded aerodynamically smooth metal cowling. The cowling was unusual at a time when the cylinder heads of inline engines were usually open and exposed to an aircraft's slip stream. The D.F.W. C.V was highly regarded by its crews and respected for its speed, maneuverability, toughness and reliability. In the hands of a skilled pilot the D.F.W. C.V was agile enough that it could escape most Allied fighters. This meant it could operate independently without the need of a fighter escort -a distinct advantage. The machine saw extensive service and became the "workhorse" of German aerial reconnaissance. Not until the late summer of 1918 did more modern reconnaissance aircraft begin to replace it. However, the sheer numbers of D.F.W. C.Vs in service made the transition a slow process. Further, many German airman preferred the older C.V to newer machines.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified reconnaissance unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, Summer, 1917.

title: Nieuport X Sesquiplane
history:
The Nieuport X (Nie. X) was the first aircraft in a lineage of fighters developed by the French aviation firm Établissements Nieuport. The Nie. X was not originally designed as a military aircraft but was, rather, intended to be the French entry in the 1914 International Gordon-Bennett Air Race. When the race was cancelled at the outbreak of World War I, Nieuport modified the aircraft into a fighter. Despite the War, the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force) initially showed little interest in the Nie. X, but the British Royal Naval Air Service did. The British purchased and placed 24 of the machines into service. 

The first military versions of the Nie. X were two seat aircraft with a pilot and an observer/gunner. The airframe consisted of fabric-covered wood framing except for a thin metal cowling about the engine and forward fuselage. The aircraft was of sesquiplane design -its lower wing having less than half the area of its upper wing. Nieuport eventually converted the Nie. X into a single seat fighter with a single machine gun mounted atop the upper wing to fire over the propeller arc. With the development of the single-seat version, and after the pressures of war had clearly demonstrated the need for fighter aircraft, the Aviation Militaire changed its attitude and placed a sizeable order for the single-seat Nieuport X. 

The Nieuport X not only equipped British and French squadrons, but was also flown by the Belgians, Italians and Russians who built the fighter under license. However, the "heyday" of the Nie. X was brief. It entered combat service in May of 1915, but was gradually being replaced by its immediate successor, the Nieuport 11, by the early months of 1916. Nevertheless, the Nieuport X holds a special place in the historical annals of World War I as the first in the distinguished lineage of famous Nieuport fighters. 

The Nie. X modeled here was flown by Flt. Commander Reginald Bone, commanding officer of RNAS Detling. While flying his Nie. X, on March 19, 1916, Bone shot down one of the six German Friedrichshafen bombers that were attacking the English coastal cities of Dover, Deal and Ramsgate. For this action he received the Distinguished Service Order.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Royal Naval Air Station (RNAS) Detling, Royal Naval Air Service, March, 1916.

title: Ansaldo S.V.A. 5 (SV.5)
history:
In the summer of 1916 Italian aircraft designers Umberto Savoia, Rodolfo Verduzio and Celestino Rosatelli set out to design a new high-performance fighter aircraft for the Italian Corpo Aeronautico Militare. The task of manufacturing the aircraft was assigned to the Societa Giovanni Ansaldo. When the single-seat biplane was finished, it received the designation Ansaldo S.V.A. 5 (Savoia-Verduzio-Ansaldo) in recognition of its manufacturer and chief designers.

The first S.V.A. 5 flew on March 19, 1917. Biplanes with wood framing, the S.V.A. had varnished plywood covering the fuselage, doped fabric covering the wings and tail surfaces and a metal alloy surrounding the engine. The aircraft's intra-wing bracing arrangement was unusual and employed a Warren truss triangular configuration of thin steel struts, devoid of bracing wires. 

The new S.V.A. aircraft exhibited exceptional speed but lacked the maneuverability desirable in combat fighters. However, it was recognized that they would make exceptional high speed reconnaissance bombers, a role to which they were immediately assigned and in which they excelled. Despite carrying a bomb load, two machine guns and two reconnaissance cameras, the S.V.A. 5 was one of the fastest aircraft of War and was probably one of the conflict's finest reconnaissance platforms. Its speed alone made it largely immune to interception and once released from its bomb load, it became competitive with Austro-Hungarian fighters. 

Of the 1,248 aircraft of the S.V.A. series manufactured during the War, the Ansaldo S.V.A. 5, modeled here, was built in the largest numbers. A two-seat variant of the S.V.A. 5 was soon developed and designated the S.V.A. 9 The Ansaldo S.V.A.'s greatest moment came on August 8, 1918 when 10 S.V.A. 5's lead by a single S.V.A. 9 over-flew Vienna, Austria for over a half hour dropping bombs and leaflets all while taking photographs of the city. This constituted a nonstop round-trip flight of over 6 hours, covering 620 miles (998 km) from their base in Pelagio, Italy -an exceptional feat for the time. Ansaldo S.V.A. 5 aircraft rendered impressive service until the end of the War and numbers of them continued flying with the Italian Corpo Aeronautico Militare until the mid-1930s.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Squadrigilia 87a, Corpo Aeronautico Militare (Italian Air Force), Pelagio, Italy, August, 1918.

title: Blackburn Kangaroo (R.T.I, Reconnaissance Torpedo I)
history:
During World War I, Great Britain was slow in the production of large heavy bombers. While its chief enemy Germany and even its Russian ally had such machines in operation in the early weeks of the conflict, it was not until the middle of the War that England had it's first big bombers (The Handley Page O/100 and O/400) and not until the end of the that the Blackburn Kangaroo was put into service.

In retaliation for air raids over English cities, the British High Command was intent on obtaining even better long range bombers which could attack German cities and the German industrial complex. Near the end of the War the Blackburn Kangaroo bomber was designed and built in response to these British War Office specifications. The Kangaroo developed from the earlier G.P. and S.P. seaplanes built by the British Blackburn Aeroplane & Motor Company for maritime reconnaissance. The Kangaroos utilized wheeled undercarriages in place of the seaplanes' pontoons. The Kangaroo had a long and slender fuselage which did not allow for crew movement from one position to another. This was a design concern should the pilot become incapacitated during flight. In this configuration, Kangaroos were delivered to both the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service. Eleven of fifteen Blackburn Kangaroos were placed into active service prior to the War's end. 

Kangaroos were primarily deployed in maritime patrols over the North Sea. On such missions, Kangaroos were reported as having sunk one German submarine and having heavily damaged four others. The machines also deployed to Belgium with a bomber squadron tasked with attacking land targets within Germany. Many of these aircraft survived the War and were subsequently converted into civilian transports. They were all retired by the late 1920s.

title: Albatros J.II
history: German aircraft manufacturer, Albatros developed a ground attack aircraft in 1917 to meet the needs of the expanding German Infanterieflieger (close air-support units). The new machine, designated the Albatros J.I, utilized the same wing configuration as the C.XII reconnaissance aircraft, but replaced the C.XII's graceful fuselage with a partially armored body designed to repel ground fire. A later version of the aircraft, designated the J.II (modeled here) further expanded the armor plating to encompass the engine compartment. The weight of the extensive 5mm steel plate armor made the J.II ungainly to take off and fly. Nevertheless, ground-attack aircraft like the Albatros J.II made life difficult for allied ground troops from the autumn of 1917 through the end of the War. By the end of August 1918, there were a total of sixteen Albatros J.Is and nineteen J.IIs in operation. These were accompanied by nearly 600 other J-type ground attack aircraft produced by other German manufacturers including A.E.G. and Junkers.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, August, 1918.

title: Standard E-1
history:
When the United States entered World War I in April of 1917, it lacked any domestically produced combat aircraft except for a line of flying boats built by Glenn Curtiss. The U.S. instead equipped its pilots with French and British models, while working to develop its domestic aviation industry. American military leaders put out a call for an American built fighter. Two firms responded with original designs: the Packard Motor Car Company of Detroit, Michigan with their LUSAC-11, and the Standard Aircraft Company of Elizabeth, New Jersey with the Standard M-Defense. 

The Standard's design began in May of 1917. Two prototypes of the new fighter, called the Standard M-Defense, were delivered to the Army Air Corps the following summer. During preproduction flight trials it became apparent that the new aircraft lacked the performance characteristics necessary for a fighter. It was underpowered, slow, lacked maneuverability and had a sluggish rate of climb. The little biplane would be unable to compete with the latest German fighters then in service on the Western Front. 

With minor changes the aircraft was instead adopted as an advanced trainer, the Standard E-1 which is modeled here. 168 production E.1s were manufactured and assigned to flight Schools within the continental United States. A total of 130 E-1 aircraft were eventually produced for the U.S. Army Air Corps.

After the War, Lawrence Sperry converted a number of E.1s to unmanned "aerial torpedoes" as part of a series of military tests now recognized as one of the earliest manifestations of guided-missle technology.

title: Morane-Saulnier Type AC (Mo.S.23)
history:
The Morane-Saulnier Type AC, modeled here, was the last in a series of shoulder-winged monoplanes built by Morane-Saulnier during World War I. Unlike some of the manufacturer's earlier aircraft, which were first developed for civilian use, the Type AC was designed specifically as a fighter. While retaining the shoulder-positioned monoplane configuration of its predecessors, it differed from them by employing ailerons instead of wing-warping for lateral control. Free of the need for wing-warping, the aircraft's single wing had rigid bracing on its underside. The new Morane-Saulnier Type AC was very aerodynamically clean by standards of the time. Its fuselage was faired to a circular cross section, a large, smooth spinner held its two bladed propeller and its control cables were all internal and a single machine gun was mounted atop the forward fuselage. The first Type AC prototype flew in the late summer of 1916. Its performance was felt to be competitive with that of any Allied fighter then in service. 

The Aviation Militaire ordered thirty production models, which began equipping French fighter Escadrille in late 1916. The Morane-Saulnier Type AC had excellent performance but had the misfortune of entering service at the same time as the new S.P.A.D. S.VII biplane fighter. The AC was deemed slightly inferior to the new S.P.A.D. and so only the original thirty machines were ever manufactured. World War I aviation records are vague about the operational history of the Morane-Saulnier Type AC fighters but it is known that they remained in active combat service until the spring of 1917.  They were then replaced by S.P.A.D. S.XIII fighters, which had joined S.VIIs and Neuports, as the principle fighter aircraft of the Aviation Militaire. It is further known that two ACs were supplied to the British Royal Flying Corps for evaluation but there is no record that either were deployed operationally.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified fighter escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, December, 1916.

title: Macchi M.5 Mod
history:
In 1917, the Societa Anonima Nieuport-Macchi began developing a single-seat flying boat fighter to compete with Austrian maritime fighters. The new aircraft, designated the M.5, featured a boat-shaped fuselage made of wood framing with a smoothly sanded plywood veneer. The aircraft used the same sesquiplane wing and v-strut configuration as its land-based Nieuport contemporaries. To avoid sea spray, the M.5's engine and radiator were mounted between its wings on a tubular steel frame above the pilot's cockpit. Later refinements to the M.5 design resulted in the M.5 Mod (modeled here). The new variant featured a more powerful engine and redesigned wingtip floats.

The M.5 proved to be fast, maneuverable and very competitive with the best Austro-Hungarian naval fighters then in service. A total of 350 were produced and issued to five different squadrons of the Italian Naval Air Service. Italian ace, Orazio Pierozzi achieved five of his six confirmed kills while flying an M.5. The aircraft had brilliant careers and were so highly regarded that they remained in service for years after the War. When the World War I Italian Navy "Regia Marine" was reorganized and merged into the new Italian Air Force the "Regia Aeronautica" in 1923, sixty-six Macchi M.5 Mod flying boat fighter aircraft were still in active service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the 260a Squadriglia, Regia Marina (Italian Naval Air Service), Venice Seaplane Base, July 1918.

title: Blackburn Triplane (Pusher, 1916)
history: The Blackburn Triplane was designed as a Zeppelin interceptor and based largely on the earlier-model Air Department (A.D.) Sparrow, for which the Blackburn Company served as contractors. The A.D. Sparrow and the Blackburn Triplane were easily two of the strangest aircraft of the time. Both machines were configured in a pusher configuration with the propeller behind the cockpit. Even more striking, however, the lower wing was located below the nacelle. The most notable structural difference between the two aircraft was that the Sparrow was a biplane while the later Blackburn model was a Triplane. Nevertheless, the histories of these two aircraft have often been confused and blended. The Triplane configuration was intended to enhance the aircraft's maneuverability when taking evasive maneuvers around Zeppelins. A gun port in the nose of the nacelle, clearly indicated that the aircraft was meant to be armed -most likely with a Davis recoilless quick-firing gun like its predecessor. However, only one prototype Triplane, N502, was ever built and it is doubtful the gun was ever mounted. The prototype Blackburn Triplane was accepted by the British Admiralty on 20 February 1917, but was removed from service only one month later due to unsatisfactory performance. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts the Triplane as it would have looked had it been armed for operational service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft received for evaluation by the Royal Naval Air Service, Unidentified Royal Naval Air Station, England, early March 1917.

title: Morane-Saulnier Type N (Mo.S.5)
history: The Morane-Saulnier Type N was among the first operational single seat fighters in the world. Its maiden flight was in May of 1914, three months before the outbreak of World War I. Originally designed for sale on the civilian market to wealthy sportsmen who wanted to "fly", the advent of World War I prompted the French military to order numbers of the machines for the Aviation Militaire. The Morane-Saulnier Type N had its military operational debut on the Western front when flown in the early summer of 1915 by the famous French pilot Eugene Gilbert. The Type N was a shoulder-wing monoplane, unusual at a time when most airplanes had multiple sets of wings. It employed wing warping for lateral control requiring its wings to have multiple bracing wires on both its superior and inferior surfaces. On later production aircraft, the solitary machine gun was positioned on the upper forward fuselage and was fixed to fire through the propeller arc. To avoid damage, the back of the propeller was fitted with steel plates which deflected those bullets striking it during firing. This approach was first installed, tested and flown in combat by Roland Garros in a Morane-Saulnier Type L. The French dubbed the Type N fighter "Le Vengeur" (The Avenger). The Morane-Saulnier Type N saw substantial service with the Aviation Militaire, both as an observation platform and as a fighter during 1915, but by the end of that year it began to be phased out in favor of more modern and better aircraft. However, the Type N remained in active combat for some months thereafter in the hands of France's allies. Between March and June of 1916 twenty-four Morane-Saulnier Type N aircraft were placed into service by the British Royal Flying Corps where they acquired the nickname "Morane Bullets". The Russian Military Air Fleet also deployed Type N aircraft which were sent to Russia by France following their removal from front line service by the Aviation Militaire. Britain and Russia retired all of their Type N machines by early 1917.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unknown escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, summer of 1915.

title: SPAD XIII (S.13)
history:
The SPAD XIII achieved incredible success during World War I. Louis Bechereau, the chief engineer of Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés (SPAD), designed several successful aircraft in this line, beginning with the SPAD VII. The new S.13 employed many of the same features of the S.7. Both aircraft included single-bay, interplane bracing, rod-and-crank aileron control, and a circular radiator located immediately behind the propeller. The new S.13 also made several improvements to the original design of the S.7. The S.13 was larger and faster. It possessed a more powerful engine, heavier armament and a completely different internal structure which made it far more robust. The S.13 prototype first flew on April 4, 1917. It performed exceptionally, and production began immediately.

By April of 1918, the French Aviation Militaire had 372 S.13s in operation. The fighter proved to be highly successful and more than a match for Germany’s Albatros and Pfalz fighters. The S.13 performed so highly that it replaced most of France’s older S.7s and many of its newer Nieuport fighters. By the final months of the War, it equipped 80 French fighter escadrilles on the Western Front. 

The SPAD S.13 also proved successful in the services of other countries. Eleven squadrons of the British, Belgian, Italian and American Air Forces adopted the new French fighter. It even replaced Sopwith fighters in some British units. Only the Italians retained numbers of the older S.7s in their air service, as some Italian pilots preferred their S.7s to the newer and heavier S.13s. 

Overall, the demand for the new S.13 was so great that no less than eight French aviation companies, in addition to its parent firm, built the machines. Total production reached 8,472 aircraft. Several Allied aces flew the S.13 on their way to fame in the skies over France. The S.13 was the final SPAD fighter designed during World War I and concluded this highly successful line of aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, August 1918.

title: Pfalz Dr.I
history:
The Pfalz Dr.I was a single-seat triplane, which represented Pfalz Flugzeugwerke's answer to the German Idflieg's (Inspectorate of Flying Troops) call for triplane fighters -the same request which resulted in the infamous Fokker Dr.I. Inspired by the success of the British Sopwith Triplane, German designers hoped that adding a third wing to an aircraft would improve its lift, climb rate and maneuverability.

The new Pfalz machine was essentially a D.VII fitted with a third wing. The two aircraft shared the same armament and the same 160 hp Siemens-Halske rotary engine. The middle wing of the Dr.I was half the cord of the upper and lower wings, and unlike the clean lines of the Fokker triplane, retained an array of bracing wires. The Pfalz Dr.I otherwise exhibited typical World War I construction with wood framing throughout. A smooth plywood veneer covered its fuselage and fabric covered its wings and tail surfaces. 

Flight trials of the first prototype yielded sufficient promise that a preproduction batch of ten machines was ordered by the German High Command. These arrived on the Western Front in early April of 1918 but their pilots found them to have little to no advantage over the latest variants of the German Albatros and Fokker fighters already in service. There is some indication that the Pfalz triplane possessed a better climb rate than the Fokker Dr.I -making it best suited for bomber intercept missions. However, a lack of improved performance combined with frequent engine problems halted production after the first batch. 

Despite their shortcomings, the existing ten aircraft served in German fighter units until the Armistice ended World War I on November 11, 1918 -just seven months after the Pfalz Dr.I's introduction into service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 15, German Air Force, Western Front, late April, 1918.

title: Brandenburg W 12
history:
The Brandenburg W 12 was a two-seat seaplane fighter which began replacing the single-seat Albatros W.4 beginning in the spring of 1917. Designed by Ernst Heinkel, for aviation firm, Hansa und Brandenburgische Flugzeugwerke , the W 12 was distinguished by its unique tail configuration -the vertical stabilizer on the W 12 extended below the fuselage instead of above. This configuration provided the aircraft's gunner with a clear field of fire. This unorthodox tail structure would be repeated on several later seaplane designs.

The W 12 first appeared in early 1917 and began equipping the German seaplane station at Zeebrugge, Belgium where they engaged in patrols over the English Channel. On December 11, 1917 a W 12 piloted by station commander, Friedrick Christiansen downed the British Airship C27. 

A total of 145 W 12s had been built when production ended in June of 1918. They remained in combat until the last day of WWI. They remained in combat until the end of the War later that year.

title: Rumpler C.X (Type 8C14)
history:
The Rumpler C.X was to be the last in a line of "C" type reconnaissance aircraft built for the German Air Force by the firm E. Rumpler Flugzeug-Werk. Gustav Budig, Rumpler's chief design engineer for the entire "C" series, designed the C.X with a unique x-shaped wing strut, which reduced the need for additional bracing wires. The C.X incorporated a pine wood frame covered with a fabric skin, except for the metal sheeting around the forward fuselage. The aircraft was powered by a 240 hp Maybach Mb IV engine, and was designed to carry a forward-firing Spandau machinegun and a movable Parebellum gun. Overall, the two seat biplane exhibited clean lines and was a light, aerodynamically efficient machine.

The C.X made its maiden flight in 1918. Unfortunately, after the prototype was seriously damaged in a collision on the ground, further design and production was cancelled. The end of the War later that year, eliminated the need for further aircraft development, marking the end of Rumpler's "C" type lineage.
deployment: This model represents the prototype Rumpler C.X, Germany, 1918.

title: Avro 504K
history:
The Avro 504 represents the only military aircraft of World War I to serve in frontline combat from the first to the final day of the War. The 504 was designed by the British aviation pioneer Alliot Verdon Roe, founder of the A.V. Roe & Company, Ltd. (Avro). It first flew in 1913 as a participant in a number of air races and in 1914 set a new unofficial altitude record of 15,000 feet. Small numbers of this craft were initially ordered by both the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Navy Air Service. With the outbreak of World War I, demand for the highly successful aircraft was so great that several additional British aircraft firms besides Avro began production. 

Variants of the Avro 504 encompassed several different roles, serving as a reconnaissance craft, light bomber, trainer, fighter and night fighter. It was built in more different variants than any other British type. In all, over 10,000 were built-more than any other type of British warplane. The largest numbers of 504s served as trainers and in reconnaissance. These were two-seat machines. The fighter and bomber variants had their forward seat removed to allow for increased fuel capacity and to accommodate the added weight of a machine gun and its ammunition, or the weight of a bomb load. The K variant (modeled here) was fitted with universal engine-bearer struts allowing it to accept most of the new more powerful rotary engines which were becoming available.

The Avro 504 participated in several important milestones of the War. On August 22, 1914, an Avro 504 of No. 5 Squadron became the first British aircraft to be brought down by enemy fire. In November of 1914, 504s became the first British aircraft to bomb the Zeppelin sheds at Friedrichshafen, Germany. The 504 also represents the first British machine to function as a dedicated night fighter combating the German nighttime Zeppelin raids over London.

At the end of the War, the Royal Flying Corps possessed 2,999 Avro 504s in active service, more than any other British aircraft type. Following World War I, no fewer than 17 countries acquired and deployed Avro 504 aircraft in their air forces. Some of these aircraft even continued service into World War II. Several machines are airworthy to this day and are part of civilian historical aircraft collections or museums.
deployment: This model represents a night fighter of the Royal Flying Corps, May 1918.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5a
history: The Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5 and the later variant, the S.E.5a (modeled here), was a single-seat biplane fighter, known for its speed and durability. The aircraft was of standard construction for the time -wire-braced wooden box-girder fuselage and fabric-covered wings. It was armed with a Lewis gun mounted on the top wing, and a propeller-synchronized Vickers machine gun in front of the cock-pit. The S.E.5 was originally designed to carry the Hispano-Suiza 150 hp engine, which first appeared in 1915. Further development of the engine produced a 200 hp model in 1916. The more-powerful engine was installed on a modified version of the S.E.5, which was redesignated the S.E.5a. Unfortunately, the larger engine proved problematic. Production delays and frequent failures in the larger engines resulted in supply shortages. Engine failures in front-line aircraft, also had an adverse effect on pilot morale. Nevertheless, the S.E.5a proved to be a formidable aircraft in combat. Though it was less maneuverable than its contemporaries, the machine's durability allowed its pilots to push the aircraft's capabilities without fear of structural failure. The S.E.5a notably served as the mount for several of Britain's top aces. The prototype for this model was an R.A.F. aircraft flown on the Western Front by William A. (Billie) Bishop; a Canadian who became one of Great Britain's highest scoring aviators. He was credited with 72 victories. By the middle of 1918 the S.E.5a equipped 25 squadrons on the Western Front, three in Macedonia, two in Palestine, one in Mesopotamia and four in England for homeland defense. A total of over 5200 aircraft were produced. Thirty-five S.E.5a's were also given to the American Expeditionary Force, which flew them on the Western Front during the final months of the war. Soon after the war the British retired the S.E.5a in favor of the Sopwith Snipe, but it continued to serve in the United States Army Air Force until the mid 1920s. A number of the American machines were finally sold to civilians for use in "barnstorming shows" and "flying circuses". Several of the S.E.5a's also starred in the Hollywood movie Hells Angels.

title: SAML S.2
history: In the first week of 1917 the Italian Direzione Tecnica dell'Aeronautica Militaria (the Technical Directorate of Military Aviation) sent a specification to the Italian aircraft industry for a new high-performance reconnaissance aircraft which would be armed and capable of carrying a bomb load. The Italian firm Società Aeronautica Meccanica Lombarda (S.A.M.L.) responded with a new design drafted by two of its engineers, Umberto Savola and Rodolfo Verduzio. This duo and their team had previously designed the very successful Ansaldo S.V.A. reconnaissance aircraft which was deployed in large numbers with the Italian Air Force. The initial version of the new aircraft, designated the SAML S.1, was based on Italian-built versions of the German Aviatik B.I. The aircraft was built around a six-cylinder liquid-cooled inline engine built by the Italian automotive manufacturing firm, Fiat. The SAML retained the Aviatik's "heart-shaped" horizontal stabilizer and mounted the engine "German-style" with the cylinders protruding above the engine housing. A short-spanned variant of the aircraft, designated the SAML S.2 (modeled here) followed soon after and, after successful flight trials, began equipping units of the Italian Air Force in the late summer of 1917. Although they lacked blazing speed, the SAML aircrafts' performance was otherwise satisfactory and the machines came to be highly regarded by their crews as robust, reliable and easy to fly. Over six-hundred SAML aircraft were produced and served with sixteen different reconnaissance units of the Italian Air Force during the War. The aircraft operated over the Italian, Austro-Hungarian, Albanian and Macedonian Fronts and remained in active frontline service until the end of World War I. The fuselage sides of the SAML S.2, modeled here, display not only the traditional Italian recognition roundels but also its squadriglia (squadron) number (105) and a red rooster, the pilot's personal marking. Model Builder's Comments: The aircraft depicted here is painted in the markings of 105a Squadriglia. This unit is absent from some lists of S.A.M.L.-equipped squadrons, so it is unclear if the unit ever flew this aircraft type.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of 105a Squadriglia (Squadron), Macedonian Front, November, 1917.

title: Pomilio E (PE)
history:
Designed in early 1917 and built by the Italian firm O. Pomilio and Company, the Pomilio PE became the primary reconnaissance platform for the Italian Air Force during the last year of the War. The PE was a refinement of the earlier Pomilio PC and PD models and corrected some of their stability problems.

The aircraft's construction was of wood framing with fabric covering except the area about the forward fuselage which had steel tubular framing covered with metal sheet. The Pomilio PE was, as fast as most fighter aircraft of the time. It was agile and had a high rate of climb. These attributes allowed it to conduct its reconnaissance sorties without a fighter escort -a distinct advantage. Early Pomilio PE's were equipped with 260 h.p. Fiat liquid-cooled engines. Later units were provided with upgraded 300 h.p. Fiat powerplants, giving them even better performance. 

The PE was manufactured in very large numbers with some 1,071 being built. This was in addition to the 545 PC and PD models built. Indeed, demand for the machine was such that besides its parent company the Pomilio PE was produced under license by several other Italian aircraft firms. 

The Pomilio PE had a distinguished career and was widely deployed for reconnaissance and artillery spotting. It remained in active service over the Italian Front until the War's end. It equipped 30 reconnaissance units of the Italian Air Force.

title: Bristol Scout C
history:
The Bristol Scout series of aircraft, originally designated the Scout "A", began as a sporting aircraft designed by Bristol's chief engineer, Frank Barnwell prior to the outbreak of World War I. The Scout was a single-seat biplane built from conventional wood framing covered with doped fabric and an aluminum sheet over the forward fuselage. The first Scouts deployed with the Royal Flying Corps received the designation Scout "B", though they differed from the "A" model in detail only. Similarly, the "C" model (displayed here) differed from its predecessor only in its internal arrangements and the reinforcement of its engine compartment. 

The Scout C was dispatched to the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service beginning in March of 1915. There they provided protection for two-seat reconnaissance aircraft. Because synchronized machine gun technology was not yet available, the Scout was officially unarmed. However, pilots carried pistols and rifles; Ranken darts were also carried to be dropped on the enemy. Captain Lanoe G. Hawker won the first Victoria Cross for air-to-air combat when he downed three machine gun-equipped enemy aircraft in a Scout C armed with only a single shot carbine rifle mounted on the starboard side of the fuselage. The later "D" model Scout was the first of the line to carry machine guns.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the British Royal Naval Air Service, Eastchurch, Isle of Sheppey, England, March, 1915.

title: Gotha LE 3 (Taube)
history: Germany's first mass-produced military aircraft were called Tauben (Doves) -so named because of the bird-like shape of their wings. Austrian designer, Igo Etrich developed the first prototype Tauben, before licensing the design the Rumpler aircraft. Variants of Etrich's design were soon being produced by at least fourteen German and Austrian aircraft firms, including Gothaer Waggon-Fabrik (modeled here). The Gotha Tauben were designated LE 3 by the manufacturer and A.I by the German military. The Tauben featured a single aileron and unique split rudder configuration. Most variants, including the LE 3 were two-seat monoplanes. The LE 3 flew unarmed except for sidearms carried by pilots and served primarily in a reconnaissance role. Gotha delivered twenty LE 3s to the German Army in 1914. However, as the War began to accelerate military aircraft design and production, the Tauben were soon replaced by newer-model reconnaissance aircraft. A few served as trainers until 1917 when they were all retired.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, August, 1914. Model Builder's Comments: The tail structure in this model deviates from the standard split rudder configuration found on most Taube aircraft.

title: FBA Model C
history:
Prior to World War I, Franco-British Aviation (F.B.A.) acquired the patent for the Donnet-Lévêque flying boats from which the company developed a series of maritime patrol aircraft. The first of these aircraft, the F.B.A. Model A, was heavily influenced by the earlier Donnet-Lévêque. Developed prior to World War I, the Model A did not see extensive military service. However, the F.B.A. Model B and Model C (modeled here) were produced in significant numbers for the French and British navies.

The F.B.A. Model B and C were larger, two-seat versions of their predecessor, The B and C differed only in their powerplants. The Model B employed a 100 hp Gnôme engine, while the Model C utilized a more powerful 130 hp Clerget engine. Both aircraft were two-seat biplane flying boats with their respective engines in a "pusher" configuration. The lower wing of the F.B.A. flying boats did not mount directly to the fuselage. Rather, it was elevated on four steel struts which dramatically raised the wings above the body of the craft.

First produced in France, manufacture of F.B.A. flying boats was also carried out under license by the SIAI company in Italy and the Lebedev factory in Russia. During the course of the war no less than 982 F.B.A. flying boats were built, the largest number of any World War I flying boat type. The machines were widely used and saw most of their service with the French and British navies. A few were also sent to Russia where they were primarily deployed over the Black Sea to monitor the assets of the Ottoman Empire. This model replicates one of these Russian F.B.A. flying boats. 

Little is known about the operational history of the Russian F.B.A. flying boats, but they apparently remained in active service with the Russian Navy until the Russian Revolution and the overthrow of the Czar; events which took Russia out of World War I.
deployment: This model represents an unidentified unit of the Imperial Russian Naval Air Force, Odessa, Black Sea, February, 1917.

title: de Havilland (Airco) D.H.9
history: The D.H.9 was the last in a series of aircraft designed by Geoffrey de Havilland, chief aeronautical engineer of the Aircraft Manufacturing Company, Ltd. (Airco). Intended to improve upon de Havilland's highly successful D.H.4 bomber, the new D.H.9 was created in response to the British Air Board's plans to expand the country's air forces from 108 to 200 squadrons. The D.H.9 differed from its predecessor only in its engine and cockpit configuration. The new bomber positioned the pilot closer to the gunner's position, which greatly improved the crew's ability to communicate in flight. The engine selected for the aircraft was the new new Armstrong Siddeley Puma engine. The new powerplant was originally rated at 300 h.p., but soon downgraded to 230 h.p. after experiencing problems defective cylinder blocks. This downgrade meant that the D.H.9 -intended as an improvement over the D.H.4- actually had less power than its predecessor. Following their introduction in January of 1918, fifty D.H.9s were promptly shot down and another 100 were damaged beyond repair, due in large part to their insufficient power. The disparity between the aircraft's original design and its operational performance prompted Major-General Hugh Trenchard, Chief of the British Air Ministry, to initiate an official inquiry. Despite deficiencies and combat losses, D.H.9s remained in front line service until the War's end. In an effort to correct the power problem, de Havilland installed the American built 400 hp (298 kw) 12 cylinder Liberty engine into the D.H.9 airframe. Dubbed the D.H.9A, the new variant achieved the performance de Havilland, Airco and the British Royal Flying Corps had been seeking. Unfortunately, the new variant did not reach service until the autumn of 1918 -too late to have an impact on the War. Over 2,500 D.H.9As were built, the vast majority during the decade following World War I. Post-War, D.H.9As not only flew for the British but were also sold to the air forces of the United States, Belgium, Canada, Estonia, Latvia, Chile, Peru, Poland, Spain, Switzerland, Ireland, Greece and Romania. D.H.9A's were also deployed by both White and Red Russian forces during the 1917-1919 Russian Civil War. Some South African D.H.9As remained in front line operational service until 1938. Model Builder's Comments: The D.H.9 modeled here (#B 7620) has white fuselage recognition stripes, the markings of No. 211 Squadron Leader J.A. Gray who was shot down over Holland on June 17, 1918 while on a bombing mission in northwest Germany.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 211 Squadron, British Royal Air Force, Pedre Synthe Aerodrome, Northern France, Western Front, June, 1918.

title: Morane-Saulnier Type L (Mo.S.3)
history: The Morane-Saulnier Type L developed from the pre-war Type G to serve as an artillery spotter and reconnaissance aircraft. The Type L maintained the slab-sided fuselage, wing shape and wing-warping control method of its predecessor. However, the Type L switched to a parasol-style wing, which afforded better downward visibility for the aircraft's observer. Early in World War I, the Type L quickly became the preferred mount over the Types G and H. Once operational, the aircraft was employed as an artillery spotter, light bomber and a fighter. The Type L's intended armament consisted of a single Lewis gun operated by the observer. In 1914, however, French pilot, Roland Garros became the first recorded pilot to mount a machine gun atop the fuselage to fire through the propeller. Garros used steel deflection plates to protect his propeller from the bullets. in April, 1915 Garros shot down three enemy aircraft in as many weeks. More than 600 Morane Saulnier aircraft operated in combat with multiple Escadrilles over the Western Front before being replaced by more modern Nieuport and S.P.A.D. aircraft in late 1916. Many of France's leading aces, including George Marie Guynemer, experienced their first combat in the Morane-Saulnier Type L and it is considered by some to be the grandfather of fighter aircraft. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts a modified Type L with a forward-firing machine gun. The model is also a single-seat aircraft while the standard Type L was a two-seater.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified fighter escadrille of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, April, 1915.

title: Phönix C.1
history:
The Phönix C.I was developed as a replacement for the Hansa-Brandenburg C.II armed reconnaissance aircraft. Construction was typical for the era, consisting of wood framing throughout with a thin wood veneer covering the fuselage, sheet metal surrounding the engine and fabric covering over the remainder of the craft. The machine's rudder was unique. Most of the surface area of the rudder was below the horizontal tail. The rudder area above the horizontal tail was small, unobtrusive and gave the rear gunner an excellent field of fire.

Preproduction flight trials in late 1917 proved the new Phönix C.I to be fast, tough and maneuverable with an outstanding rate of climb and excellent handling properties. The aircraft was especially effective when flying at high altitudes, an attribute which lead to its extensive deployment in high-altitude photographic reconnaissance sorties. 

Production aircraft began equipping units of the Austro-Hungarian Air Force in the late spring of 1918. Flying largely over the Italian front, the C.Is immediately received praise from their crews. In June of 1918, a  Phönix C.I flown by Feldwebel (Sergeant) Max Kauer with Arnold Barwig as observer/gunner was attacked by a SPAD XIII fighter flown by Italy's leading air ace, Major Francesco Barraca. In the ensuing engagement the Italian was shot down and killed. This event proved that the Phönix C.I was not only a fine reconnaissance platform but also a dangerous opponent for the Allies' best fighter aircraft even when flown by their best aces. 

Production of the Phönix C.I was terminated at the end of the war by which time just over 100 had been delivered to the Austro-Hungarian Air Force. Terms within the Armistice demanded that Austria-Hungary surrender all of its Phönix C.I aircraft to the victorious Allied nations.

title: Harlan Pfeiltaube
history: Germany's first mass-produced military aircraft were called Tauben (Doves) -so named because of the bird-like shape of their wings. Austrian designer, Igo Etrich developed the first prototype Taube, before licensing the design the Rumpler aircraft. Variants of Etrich's design were soon being produced by at least 54 German and Austrian aircraft firms, including Harlan-Flugzeugwerke (modeled here), which produced at least four known variants. This aircraft was in that group of "flying machines" which were a part of the German Air Force when World War I erupted in August of 1914. Most Tauben featured a single aileron and unique split rudder configuration. Most variants, including this Harlan model were two-seat monoplanes. The Taube modeled here was a Pfeiltaube (Arrow Dove) variant, likely designed during 1912. Pfeiltauben were distinguished by their swept-back wings. The Harlan Taube flew unarmed except for sidearms carried by pilots and served primarily in a reconnaissance role. The German Air Force acquired several of these machines in 1913 and they were available at the outbreak of World War I. The precise number of Harlan Taube aircraft deployed by Germany is unknown -probably very few because the initial 1913 acquisition was never augmented. It is known that during the first days of War, Germany flew Tauben during reconnaissance sorties in support of advancing German ground troops. The aircraft proved to be poorly suited to the rigors of combat service and their careers were very short lived. Their frail wood and fabric construction could not hold up to the rough fields and cow pastures from which they operated. Undercarriage damage and mechanical failures were common. By early 1915 the Harlan Taube had disappeared having been replaced by far better, more modern and more robust reconnaissance aircraft. Model Builder's Comments: Most Harlan Tauben displayed the manufacturer's name in large letters on the fuselage. This model depicts an aircraft repainted for military use.
deployment: This model represents an early civil aircraft adapted to use in WW I as a Reconnaissance Aircraft.

title: Nieuport 16
history:
The Nieuport 16 was essentially a transitional model between the Nie.11 and the Nie.17. The only structural difference between the Nie.16 and its predecessor was the inclusion of a more powerful 110 hp Le Rhône engine. The increase in engine power improved the Nie.16's performance characteristics over the Nie.11. However, because the two aircraft had the same dimensions, the Nie.16's larger engine created greater wing-loading and, in the even of engine failure, would cause the aircraft to nose over during a crash landing. The Nie.16 retained the same standard armament of the Nie.11 -a single Lewis machine gun mounted on the upper wing- though some later aircraft utilized the Alkan synchronizing mechanism to allow guns, mounted forward on the fuselage, to fire though the propeller. 

The Nie.16 began replacing the earlier Nie.11 on the Western Front in 1916. In addition to the Aviation Militaire, it served with the Belgian Air Force (modeled here), the British Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service. They were also flown by the famous Lafayette Escadrille. A number of the aircraft were also built under license by Russian firm, Dux. These aircraft served with the Russian Air Service until the revolution of 1917.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified fighter escadrille of the Aviation Militaire Belge (the Belgian Air Force), Western Front, March, 1916.

title: Farman (Brothers) F.40 Horace (1915)
history:
The Farman F.40 merged many of the signature design features of the two Farman Brothers, Maurice and Henri. The cockpit placement and sesquiplane wing design were reminiscent of Maurice's earlier M.F.7 and M.F.11 aircraft, while the tail structure resembled Henri's earlier designs. This amalgamation of design features earned the F.40 the nickname, "Horace." 

The F.40 was designed as a replacement for the earlier M.F.11. Like its predecessor, it was a single-engine two-seater with a "pusher" propeller located behind the cockpit. However, unlike the biplane M.F.11, the F.40 was a sesquiplane, with a lower wing that was significantly shorter than the upper. The forward fuselage was a metal gondola with a long, thin nacelle holding the pilot in the rear seat and the observer/ gunner in the forward position. The inline engine, duel radiators and fuel tank occupied the aft portion of the gondola just ahead of the pusher propeller. The aft fuselage back to the tail surfaces was a maze of open struts and wire bracing. The wings and tail planes were of wood framing with fabric covering.

The F.40 entered service as an infantry and artillery spotter with the Aviation Militaire in late 1915. As manufacturing commences, as many as ten aircraft a day were produced in several variants. Variant aircraft differed primarily in engine type, though a float plane version was constructed as well as a variant equipped with searchlights, and one designed to carry Le Prieur rockets for attacking balloons. A number of F.40s were also configured as bombers, but were deemed unsuccessful in that role. The machines suffered from poor engine performance and were defenseless if attacked from behind. By 1916, the bomber variants were restricted to night-time operations, and were soon phased out entirely.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified escadrille of the French Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, 1915.

title: Junkers J 9 (D.1)
history:
The Junkers D.1 represents the pinnacle of aeronautical design achieved during World War I. At a time when virtually all aircraft were built of fabric-covered wood framing, the Junkers D.1 was of all metal construction -built with aluminum tube framing covered by a skin of stressed corrugated duralumin. The metal construction also eliminated the need for bracing wires on the D.1's wings. The clean lines and all-metal airframe afforded the aircraft great speed, strength and durability both in combat and, perhaps more importantly, in the face of the inclement weather conditions often encountered in the field -conditions which lead to the deterioration of wood and canvas. 

The Junkers D.1 -initially designated J.9- was designed and manufactured by Junkers Fleugzeug-Werke, which supplied aircraft to Germany during both World Wars. Though its design began many months before, the D.1's first flight was not until April of 1918. A total of 41 D.1s were built and at least some were delivered to the front, though it is uncertain whether any saw combat before the armistice.

In the spring of 1919 numbers of Junker D.1s flew combat sorties in support of the Baltic States in their armed struggle against Russian Bolshevik insurgents. Their performance proved to be outstanding. The design and construction concepts of the Junkers D.1 continue to be embraced in the fighter aircraft of today, making the little machine the direct ancestor of the generations of fighters that followed.

title: Bristol Fighter F.2B (Brisfit)
history:
The Bristol F.2B, designed by Bristol's chief designer Frank Barnwell, first entered service with the Royal Flying Corps in April 1917. The aircraft served as a fighter and artillery spotter/reconnaissance aircraft. It performed so successfully that eventually all of the Royal Flying Corps reconnaissance squadrons were equipped with the aircraft. 

After the Royal Air Force was established in April 1918, the aircraft was renamed the Bristol F.2 Mk III. Production of these fighters continued for nearly a year after the conclusion of World War I. In all, 4,747 were eventually built. Some of these reconnaissance fighters continued on active duty with the RAF until the early 1930s.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft flown by No. 139 Squadron, British Royal Flying Corps in Italy during August 1918.

title: Caproni Ca.46 (Military Ca.5)
history: The Caproni Ca.46 (modeled here) was the last heavy bomber built for the Italian Air Force during World War I by Italian aircraft company, Caproni. The aircraft was part of a series of three-engined biplane bombers commonly referred to as the Ca.5 series. The Ca.46 was the last land-based model in the series and was distinguished from its predecessors by its American, Liberty engines and frontal radiators. The Ca.46 featured a twin-boom tail structure with a central gondola-style fuselage containing a forward gun position and pilots' cockpit and internal bomb bay. The aircraft utilized a unique three-engine configuration with two tractor engines suspended between the wings and a rear positioned "pusher" engine on the back of the fuselage. The aircraft had two defensive machine guns, the traditional nose mount and a second gun position above the pusher engine aft where the gunner stood at his gun exposed to the elements and gunfire from enemy aircraft. Although the aircraft were costly and time consuming to build, 200 Ca.5 series bombers were built late in the war. Production licenses were granted to the United States, France and Great Britain. Given their late arrival, the combat careers of the Ca.46s were brief. Though the Ca.5s were significantly more advanced than the Ca.3 series they were intended to replace, they were scrapped soon after the War in favor of their predecessors due to the difficulty of maintaining the complex machines. Model Builder's Comments:This model depicts an aircraft equipped with Fiat A12 bis engines. This was the standard powerplant for the Ca.44, an earlier model in the Ca.5 series. Ca.46 aircraft were usually equipped with American-made Liberty engines.

title: Rumpler C.IV (Type 6A5 & 6A7)
history:
The German aircraft firm E. Rumpler Flugzeugwerke GmbH built the C.IV as a long range reconnaissance platform to replace the earlier C.I model. The C.IV was a single-engine, two seat aircraft; it was larger than the C.I and was equipped with a more powerful engine. Aside from the size of the airframe and engine, the C.IV's construction did not differ much from its predecessor. Solidly constructed of metal and wood framing with a fabric covering, it could withstand considerable damage and remain airworthy. The C.IV also exhibited excellent performance characteristics and was able to outrun most allied scouts while flying at 15,000 feet.

Aside from its parent firm, the C.IV was also produced under license by the German company Pfalz. Although they were exactly the same aircraft, the Pfalz machines were given the designation Pfalz C.I. Their considerable virtues and excellent performance not withstanding, only 100 of both the Rumpler C.IV and the Pfalz C.I variants were ever built. The excellent performance of the C.IV allowed the aircraft to remain in service until the Armistice. For several years following WWI, modified C.IVs functioned as mail planes and small civilian passenger transports. By the mid 1920s they had all disappeared.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified reconnaissance unit, German Air Force, Western Front, October, 1917.

title: Phönix D.I (Type 8) (Imperial Aviation Troops)
history:
In 1917, the Austrian arm of the Albatros Company changed its name to Phönix Flugzeugwerke AG. The firm's senior engineer, Edmund Sparmann, designed the Phönix D.I in an effort to provide the Austro-Hungarian Air Force with an improved fighter. The D.I incorporated several unusual features for a fighter aircraft of the time. These included inward-sloping intra-plane struts on the wings, a 200 hp (149 kW) engine and dual forward-firing machine guns which were completely enclosed in the fuselage. 

The first production machines entered service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force in February of 1918. Their performance proved adequate but not truly outstanding. Despite a more powerful engine, the aircraft still suffered from a poor power to weight ratio, which contributed to their poor performance characteristics. Nonetheless, the fighter became the favored aircraft for several Austro-Hungarian air aces during 1918. The D.I's production was limited to only 140 machines -120 for the K.u.K. Luftfahrttruppen [the Austrian Air Force] and 20 for the Austrian Navy. 

Production of the Phönix D.I was terminated in mid 1918 in favor of the Phönix D.II and D.IIa. Both aircraft had lighter structures, and substantially improved performance. The The D.IIa was also fitted with a more powerful 230 hp (172 kW) engine. After World War I, Edmund Sparmann developed a series of Phönix fighters for the Swedish Air Force, which would prove even more successful than his World War I Phönix fighters. 

The Air Force and Naval versions of the Phönix D.1 were each painted in distinct ways. The Naval Phönix D.1 (included elsewhere in this collection) incorporated red and white stripes on its wings and tail-the colors of the Austro-Hungarian coat-of-arms. The Air Force version (like the model displayed here) used a camouflage paint scheme of stippled brown on its upper surfaces.

title: Sopwith Pup
history: The Sopwith Pup was designed by Sopwith engineer Harry Hawker as a fighter/interceptor with the first prototypes flying in late February, 1916. It closely resembled the 11/2 Strutter aircraft from which it was partly derived. The Sopwith Company had named the aircraft "Sopwith Scout," but an unofficial nickname was quickly given to the new aircraft of "Pup." This affectionately applied nickname stuck, and the machine was forever called "The Sopwith Pup." It remains unclear how this nickname transpired since the "Pup" was no smaller than several other fighter aircraft in operation at the time. One story suggests that its crews felt it was the offspring of the 11/2 Strutter. The Pup was made of wooden framing throughout, with a doped fabric covering and thin metal sheeting over its forward fuselage and metal engine cowling. Designed as a biplane, its wings were of equal cord and length, but were slightly staggered. Production models were fitted with an 80 hp Le Rhône engine, and a single Vickers gun synchronized to fire through the propeller. The Pup began equipping combat fighter units of the Royal Flying Corps on the Western Front in September of 1916. Its performance was outstanding and it remained in active frontline fighter service until the late autumn of 1917. Most Pups were then withdrawn from the Western Front and were returned to England where they were deployed in homeland defense against the German bombers and Zeppelin airships. In an effort to improve their speed and performance in this home-defense role, most Pups underwent an engine change and were given 100 hp Gnôme Monosoupape engines. Some Pups were also fitted with Le Prieur rockets, which had proven to be superior to machine guns in destroying German Zeppelins. Production of the Sopwith Pup continued through the summer of 1918 with a total of 1,770 being manufactured. A number of Pups were deployed by the Royal Naval Air Service aboard the British aircraft carriers Campania, Furious and Manxman. As such, they were among the first aircraft to fly from a warship.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 54 Squadron, Royal Flying Corps, Le Hameau, France, April, 1917.

title: Friedrichshafen G.III
history: The Friedrichshafen G.III was a large, fixed-wing bomber used to carry out nighttime bombings of Allied cities and military installations. The German aviation firm Flugzeugbau Friedrichshafen GmbH manufactured a total of 338 of these large machines. Unlike most bombers of the era, both of its engines were "pusher" mounted rather than the more common "tractor" type. The G.III could also carry a heavier bomb load than most aircraft of the era. The G.III was developed as an alternative to the lighter-than-air Zeppelins first used on strategic bombing missions of Allied cities. The Allies responded to the early airship raids by developing night fighters capable of intercepting the slow-moving Zeppelins. The highly flammable airships proved to be easy targets for the fighters and German planners were forced to rethink their approach. Heavy bombers, like the G.III, as well as the Gotha G.V and the Zeppelin Staaken were created to replace the more vulnerable airships. The Friedrichshafen G.III first went into service with three bomber groups of the German Air Force in February of 1917. The G.III achieved considerable success in the nighttime bombing of Allied supply depots at Dunkirk, France, which disrupted Allied efforts on the Western Front. Model Builder's Comments: The prototype of the Friedrichshafen G.III modeled here was painted in a stippled dark overall coloration for its role as a night bomber.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Kampfgeschwader der Obersten Heeresleitung I, Western Front, June 1918.

title: Albatros D.I (L15)
history:
The Albatros D.I was introduced in an attempt to wrest air superiority from the Allies' Nieuport 11 and D.H.2 fighters. The design of the D.I continued to refine Albatroswerke's pioneering development of all-wood fuselages. The aircraft exhibited very clean lines, broken only by the boxy radiator protruding above the engine. The fuselage was made of a semi-monocoque plywood construction, the surface of which was coated with a glossy varnish finish. Its wings and tail surfaces were of wood framing with fabric covering but intra-wing struts and wire bracing were kept to a minimum. The result of these features was a marked reduction in wind resistance. Powered by a large 160 hp engine, the D.I could carry the weight of twin machine guns and was very fast for the time. However, a rather high wing loading detracted from the aircraft's maneuverability. 

Following trials in August of 1916 the German High Command ordered 50 of the new machines, which began equipping fighter units on the Western Front the following November. Though it is unclear exactly how many D.Is entered service, reports indicate that total numbers on the front declined steadily from the initial delivery in November 1916. The Albatros D.I was almost immediately overtaken by its successor the Albatros D.II, the design and construction of which had begun very shortly after that of the D.I. Indeed, D.II production aircraft were arriving at the front only weeks after the arrival of the D.Is, and the latter aircraft soon appeared in much greater numbers. The two fighters differed only slightly in their external appearance, their performance, their speed and their firepower. However, the D.IIs were preferred by pilots due to the improved visibility afforded by their reduced intra-wing gap. 

Although manufactured in relatively small numbers, the Albatros D.I was a significant aircraft of World War I, if for no other reason, than it was the first in the lineage of the fine Albatros fighters, which became a mainstay of The German Air Force throughout the War.
deployment: This model represents and aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 16, German Air Force, Western Front, December, 1916.

title: Hanriot HD 1
history:
The Hanriot HD 1 machine was the first fighter designed and built by the French aviation firm Avions Hanriot & Co, where Pierre Dupont served as the chief engineer. The small machine first flew in the summer of 1916 and proved to be an agile, maneuverable and excellent fighter. By this time, however, the French Aviation Militaire (the French Air Force) had already committed itself to the mass production of SPAD and Nieuport fighters. The French showed little interest in the Hanriot HD 1 as a result. Italy, however, did adopt the machine. Under license, the Italian firm Società Nieuport-Macchi supplied 125 HD 1s to the Italian Air force in 1917 and an additional 706 in 1918. The Italian Air Force later adopted the Hanriot HD 1 as its standard fighter aircraft. At the time of its greatest use, the Hanriot HD 1 equipped no less than 16 of 18 Italian fighter units. 

Belgium also expressed interest in the Hanriot fighter and acquired 79 of the aircraft from its parent company in France. The machine achieved equal success when it entered service with Belgian forces in August 1917. Belgian airmen even preferred the Hanriot HD 1 to the newer Sopwith Camel. When offered Camels in early 1918, they rejected them in favor of the HD 1s they were already flying. The brilliant Belgian ace Willy Coppens de Houthulst also operated an HD 1. He achieved most of his 37 victories in this machine.

The Hanriot HD 1 gave an outstanding account of itself during combat. One battle in particular exemplifies the worth of the Hanriot HD 1. At the air battle of Istrana on December 26, 1917, Hanriots of the Italian 6th group shot down 11 German reconnaissance aircraft without loss. Numbers of the Hanriot HD 1s remained in active service long after World War I with the Italian, Belgian and Swiss Air Services-the Swiss having purchased 16 war surplus aircraft following the war. Some HD 1s remained with front line units of these three nations until 1930, a testimony to the excellent performance of this machine.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the Italian Air Force, Northern Italian Front, 1917.

title: Dunne D.8 (1912)
history:
Aeronautical engineer, John William Dunne experimented heavily in the design of aerodynamically stable aircraft, which would maintain level flight without direct contact with the controls. Many of Dunne's designs took the form of tailless "flying wings" like the one modeled here.

Over the years, Dunne developed numerous versions of his flying wing design. His company, the Blair-Atholl Syndicate often licensed its designs to other aircraft firms for production. The aircraft modeled here most closely resembles the Dunne D.8, a variant from 1912 which was produced under license by the Short Brothers and the French firm, Nieuport. While the fuselage layout and long nose-over skid on the model are suggestive of the D.8, the twin propellers and four-wheeled undercarriage more closely resemble its immediate predecessor, the D.5. The experimental and constantly evolving nature of Dunne's designs has lead to many conflicting historical accounts.

Though various militaries took an interest in Dunne's designs, it is unlikely any reached operational service. One D.8 was tested by the Royal Flying Corps in 1914. A few units of a later American-built variant, commonly referred to as the Burgess-Dunne Flying Wings, were delivered to the United States Army Air Service, the United States Navy and the Canadian Aviation Corps. The Canadian aircraft may have even shipped to Europe to participate in the War, but records indicate it was damaged in transit and never used.

In August of 1913, Commandant Felix flew a D.8 from Eastchurch, England to Villacoublay, France where he made demonstration flights for the French Aeronautics Corps. Felix also over-flew Paris later that month. A production license was issued to the French firm, Nieuport, which exhibited a variant of the D.8 at the Paris Aero Show that year. However, it is unlikely that the French-built Dunne was ever produced for the military. The aircraft modeled here speculates on how a Dunne flying wing might look configured as a bomber.
deployment: This model speculates on how a Dunne flying wing might look configured as a bomber of Escadrille 2, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), 1914.

title: A.E.G. C.IV N
history: The A.E.G. C.IV N was developed in 1916 to meet the Idflieg's (the German Air Force High Command) requirement for a nachtflugzeug (night bomber). The Idflieg believed that nighttime missions would be safe from intercept missions given the inherent difficulties of air defense in the darkness of night. The German aviation firm Allgemeine Elektricitäts Gesellschaft (A.E.G.) responded to the challenge by modifying an existing reconnaissance aircraft already in its inventory –the A.E.G. C.IV. The new night variant retained the general lines and form of the older aircraft but included a number of modifications. To accommodate the weight of a larger bomb-load, the wing span was lengthened by 7 feet 4 inches (2.24 m) and converted to a three-bay intra-wing bracing design. Triangular bracing was also added atop the center of the upper wing and the forward firing machine gun was removed (leaving only a flexible weapon in the rear cockpit). To equip the machine for night time operations, a long exhaust stack was installed to direct exhaust flames above the aircraft thus preserving the pilot’s night vision. The instrument panel was illuminated and navigation lights were installed, along with two powerful, forward-focused landing lights in the leading edge of the upper wing. Many of the machines were also painted in a dark, two-tone night camouflage with suppressed insignia devoid of the usual white border or white field surrounding the black cross. This was done to enhance their nighttime stealth. Satisfactory flight trials of the new machine took place in September of 1916 and the Idflieg immediately issued a production order for the new night raiders. From October of 1917 through August of 1918 one hundred A.E.G C.IV N aircraft were deployed in nighttime bombing attacks by regular daytime bombing units of the German Air Force. The night bombers remained in operational service until the Armistice at the end of the war. In the last months of the War a small number were shifted to German flight schools where they served as two seat trainers. Following the War a few survivors also saw brief civilian use.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified bomber unit, German Air Force, Western Front, January, 1918.

title: Martinsyde F.4 Buzzard
history:
The Martinsyde F.4 Buzzard was probably the best and most advanced fighter aircraft built in Great Britain during World War I. Yet, only a small number were manufactured and of these even fewer were deployed in combat. As a result, the Buzzard has been essentially lost in the historical annals of the War. 

In the autumn of 1917 the British Air Ministry issued a specification for a new fighter, which could counter Germany's new Fokker and Albatros machines. The British firm, Martinsyde, Ltd. responded with a new aircraft, the F.4 Buzzard. The aircraft's design paid special attention to aerodynamics. In an effort to reduce wind resistance it was given only a single pair of intra-wing struts, reducing the need for bracing wires. Even the aircraft's two machine guns were enclosed within the engine cowling. They fired through gun tubes which traversed the radiator located immediately behind the propeller. The Buzzard's aerodynamically clean airframe was coupled with a 300 hp (224 kw) Hispano-Suiza engine, one of the most powerful aircraft power-plants then available. The result was a fighter which possessed great speed, great maneuverability and a remarkable rate of climb. 

After very successful flight trials in the summer of 1918, the British Air Ministry ordered the building of 50 pre-production aircraft. The United States also contracted to build 1,500 for the Army Air Force. But events doomed the Buzzard, Several months before the Buzzard's test flights, the British Air Ministry settled on the Sopwith Snipe as the Royal Flying Corp's new standard fighter aircraft. By the time the Buzzard completed its flight trials, Snipes were pouring off the assembly lines. 

Some Buzzards were sent to France in the autumn of 1918 but were largely limited to familiarization training flights. Only the original 50 machines were built for the RAF prior to the end of the War, after which, production was discontinued in favor of the Sopwith Snipe. The huge United States order was also canceled. Following the War, some of the aircraft were purchased by Finland, Spain, Portugal and post-revolutionary Russia.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified fighter squadron of the British Royal Air Force Aerodrome, western France, November, 1918.

title: Breguet Type H-U.2 Seaplane (Canton-Unné 9 Cylinders)
history:
In 1912, French aircraft manufacturer, S.A. des Ateliers d'Aviation, Louis Breguet entered into an agreement with the French Navy to create a floatplane version of the Breguet U.2 biplane. Like its land-based counterpart, the new float plane had a skinny, rounded fuselage, which was covered with aluminum -an unusual design choice for the time. These features led the British Breguet Plane Company to nickname them "tin whistles". The H-U.2 and its land-based counterpart also utilized an unusual engine. The liquid-cooled radial engine was uncommon at a time when most aircraft had air-cooled rotary power-plants. A pair of radiators protruded above either side of the forward fuselage to cool the engine during flight.

The aircraft's designer, Louis Breguet was one of the most prominent French aviators and aircraft designers in the decade leading up to World War I. The Paris-based company, which he founded, built a number of flying machines which saw service with both the Aviation Militaire (the French Air Force) and the French Navy during World War I. Among these flying machines were seaplanes like the one modeled here. 

The Breguet H-U.2 was one of at least three Breguet aircraft to appear at the first Schneider Cup race in April of 1913. While originally listed among the entrants in the race, the H-U.2 withdrew before competition began.

It is unclear how many of the aircraft were eventually delivered to the French Navy, or how long they served. The land-based U.2s proved unpopular with their crews and had been replaced by newer models by the end of 1914.
deployment: This model represents an early WW I two-seat floatplane painted in the colors of the French Naval Air Service.

title: Breguet BR.5
history:
With a wingspan of nearly 60 feet (18.3m), the Breguet BR.5 was exceptionally large for a single engine machine of the era. Louis Breguet and his company SA des Ateliers d'Aviation Louis Berguet began design of an aircraft in late 1914 with the specific purpose of providing France with a bomber which could strike Essen and other German cities where war materials were being manufactured.

As bomber casualties began to rise with the appearance of armed German fighters over the front, Breguet decided to mount cannons on some of his bombers for use as escort fighters. The escort version was designated the BR.5 and could equip either a bomb load or a 37 mm (1.46 inch) Hotchkiss cannon in the forward cockpit. The BR.5s, however, were not successful in stemming the loss of French Bombers.

The BR.5 had a gondola-like fuselage with a bombardier/gunner in the forward cockpit with the pilot's cockpit behind. Its engine, completely encased in a metal housing, drove a pusher propeller located at the gondola's rear. The rest of the fuselage was of open-strut construction with a maze of bracing wires. Varnished plywood veneer covered the gondola while fabric covered its wings and tail surfaces. The machine included a number of unique features for an aircraft of the time. It had a narrow box-like bomb bay mounted under each lower wing root just outboard of the fuselage. Each bay carried up to 20 fifteen pound bombs. The aircraft also had two cylindrical gravity-feeding fuel tanks suspended beneath its upper wing. Its tricycle landing gear, gave the machine a level horizontal stance when resting on the ground and during takeoff and landing. 

After trials in October of 1915 the aircraft was placed into production with the first machines reaching units of the Aviation Militaire in early 1916. From the beginning the aircraft exhibited two serious design problems: its engine was underpowered for the size and weight of the machine, hindering maneuverability, and the pilot had terrible visibility. This led to multiple accidents during takeoff and landing. Worse, it impeded the pilot's ability to see attacking enemy fighters thus denying him the opportunity to take what little evasive action his sluggish machine might allow. 

After mounting combat losses and an exceptionally disastrous raid on Oberndorf, Germany in October of 1916, all BR.5 aircraft were withdrawn from daytime operations and shifted to nighttime sorties where enemy interception was less of a problem. But the lack of pilot visibility led to numerous crashes during night time landings. Casualities became unacceptable. In early 1917 the Avaition Militaire gave up on the BR.5 and removed all remaining aircraft from service.
deployment: This model represents and aircraft of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, October, 1916.
