title: Sopwith Camel F.1
history:
Herbert Smith designed the Camel aircraft for the Sopwith Aviation Company. The aircraft evolved from the successful Sopwith Pup and retained many features of its predecessor. Its construction incorporated a wood frame, wire bracing and fabric covering, common among WWI aircraft. Many other companies in addition to Sopwith manufactured the Camel for both the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Navy Air Service. These companies included Boulton Paul; British Caudron; Clayton and Shuttleworth; Hooper; March, Jones and Cribb; Nieuport and General; Portholme Aerodrome; and Ruston and Proctor. Deliveries of the aircraft commenced in May 1917. Eventually, 5,490 were delivered. 

The Camel acquired its distinct name from the hump over the forward fuselage area. This area protected the craft's two machine guns from intense cold that could freeze the ammunition belts and jam the guns. When flown, the Camel incurred a huge amount of torque from its rotary engine and, consequently, could be difficult to fly. The number of fatalities during training on this aircraft equaled its combat fatalities. Experienced pilots, however, achieved great results with this fighter. Late in the War, the Sopwith Snipe replaced most of the Camels.
deployment: This model represents the aircraft flown in combat over Northern Italy by Major W. C. Barker of No. 139 Squadron of the Royal Flying Corps against aircraft of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

title: Fokker D.VII
history: The Fokker D.VII began arriving on the Western Front at the end of March, 1918. The immediate successor of the famous Fokker Dr.I triplane, the D.VII shared many characteristics of its predecessor. Both aircraft exhibited the same basic construction of wooden cantilever wings without bracing wires and a welded steel fuselage. The D.VII also retained the unique "one-piece" lower wing which slid through a cutout in the lower longerons allowing the wing's frame to pass all the way through the fuselage. The most obvious difference between the D.VII and its predecessor is that the Dr.I had three wings to the D.VII's two. The intra-wing struts also show some variation between the two aircraft. Prior to the end of the War in November of 1918, some 775 machines reached 30 German fighter units. More than 3000 Fokker D VIIs were produced during the aircraft's entire production run both during and after World War I. The D.VII proved so formidable in combat that, after the War, the Treaty of Versailles specified that all of Germany's Fokker D.VII's be surrendered to the Allied Air Forces. The United States military sent many of these aircraft to the United States for analysis and they continued to fly in the United States throughout the 1920s. Builder Anthony Fokker continued to build and sell them in Holland after the conclusion of the war and more that 3000 were built during and after the war. This model of the Fokker D.VII replicates the aircraft flown by German World War I ace, Bruno Loerzer who scored 44 victories in combat over the Western Front. Model Builder's Comments: The aircraft of Bruno Loerzer upon which this model is based was painted in an unusual pattern of black and white stripes -certainly not a camouflage scheme by any stretch of the imagination.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 26, Western Front, June, 1918.

title: Lebed XII
history:
The Lebed XII and its immediate predecessor, the Lebed XI, were designed by Vladimir A. Lebedev, founder of the Russian firm Aktzionernoe Obshchestvo Vozdukhoplavania V.A. Lebedeva (V.A. Lebedev Joint-Stock Aeronautics Company). Both aircraft were largely based on a captured German Albatros B.II. Russian officials felt that it was more efficient to replicate proven designs than to develop all new aircraft.

The Lebed XII was a single-engine, two-seat biplane constructed of a plywood-covered wooden frame. While this construction method resulted in a very strong structure, it added considerable weight to the airframe. The aircraft utilized a French Salmson liquid-cooled radial engine- a very unique power plant. The Salmson was the only radial liquid-cooled engine used during the War. Liquid cooling of a radial engine was soon abandoned in favor of air cooling since experience revealed that coolant added weight to the radiator and imposed a needless drag on performance. 

After successful test flights in January of 1916, the Central Military Technical Board placed an order for 225 machines, which began replacing the Voisin as the standard corps aircraft. Unfortunately, operational Lebed XIIs proved problematic. The exhaust pipes were situated in such a way that the exhaust threatened to asphyxiate the observer in the rear cockpit. Furthermore, the pilots reported that it was difficult to pull out of a dive, and the aircraft was also prone to catch fire while in flight. Nevertheless, the Lebed XII was considered superior to the Voisins it was designed to replace.

Records indicate that Lebed XIIs were still active with the Imperial Russian Air Force at the time of the Russian Revolution and the country's withdrawal from World War I. Following the Revolution, a few remained flying for the Bolshevik controlled "Red Air Force" and some even participated in the 1919 Russian Civil War between White and Red Russian factions.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft from an unidentified unit of the Imperial Russian Air Force, Eastern Front, November 1916.

title: Sopwith Snipe (7.F.1)
history:
The Sopwith Snipe was the last in Sopwith's lineage of fighters to see combat in World War I. Originally designated the Sopwith 7.F.1, the machine acquired the nickname "Snipe" which stuck and was subsequently officially adopted. Sopwith's senior engineer, Herbert Smith, designed the Snipe, which was intended to replace his earlier design, the ubiquitous ubiquitous Sopwith Camel. The Snipe was built around the powerful new 230 hp (171.5 kW) Bentley B.R.2 rotary engine. Its external appearance was very similar to the Camel; Both aircraft shared the same rounded fuselage, the same raised hump in front of the cockpit, which housed two machine guns, the same two-bay wing bracing (though the Snipe had a slightly longer wing span), and the same tail plane. 

After very successful flight trials in the autumn of 1917, the British Air Ministry designated the Snipe as Great Britain's new standard fighter and ordered it into mass production. In face of the urgent need for the new machine, manufacture of the Snipe was also licensed to Boulton & Paul, Coventry Ordnance Works, Napier and Ruston, Proctor in England, and Nieuport in France. The first production aircraft began equipping operational fighter units of the Royal Air Force on the Western Front in the early summer of 1918. Although the Snipe did not possess exceptional speed, it was highly maneuverable and had a very high rate of climb. Further, it was sturdy and capable of withstanding a great deal of punishment. Many authorities, then and now, regard the Snipe as the best Allied fighter in combat service at the end of World War I. 

In April of 1918, the Royal Flying Corps was merged with the Royal Naval Flying Service. The new combined service was renamed the Royal Air Force (RAF). The Snipe remained its principle fighter. Production continued into the early 1920s with over 1,100 built and the Snipe remained in service until 1926. This model replicates a "factory fresh" Snipe flown on the Western Front during the last days of World War I by Victoria Cross recipient Major W.G. Barker.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 201 Squadron, Royal Air Force, Western Front, October 1918.

title: Otto B
history: When World War I broke out in August of 1914, Bavaria (the southern region of Germany) had its own air force. Although a part of the overall German air service, the Royal Bavarian Flying Corps had a surprising degree of autonomy. Bavaria also had its own aircraft manufacturing industry, which included the Munich-based company, Flugmaschinen-Werke Gustav Otto. In early 1913 the firm designed the biplane modeled here. In addition to marketing the new machine to wealthy sportsmen desiring to fly, Otto also sold several to the Royal Bavarian Flying Corps, which designated the aircraft the Otto B. With the onset of war, Bavaria deployed the aircraft on reconnaissance sorties in support of ground forces. The aircraft's construction was typical for the era -wood framing throughout with doped fabric covering its wings and tail surfaces and varnished plywood veneer covering its fuselage nacelle. An open strut framework supported the Type B's tail structures. The aircraft was configured as a "pusher", with its engine and propeller mounted on a steel framework at the rear of the fuselage. This was a design feature favored by Otto at a time when most other German firms considered pusher aircraft to be old fashioned. Unarmed, Otto's biplanes were confined largely to reconnaissance duties and artillery spotting, though some records suggest a few participated in at least one night raid on Dunkirk. The Type B's service period was brief. As the War progressed it became abundantly clear that the open-framed pusher aircraft, such as this one, were hopelessly obsolete. By early 1916 Otto Bs were no longer listed on Bavarian Flying Corps manifests. It is presumed that by that time they had all been struck from service. When Germany retired older combat aircraft from active service it often sent them to its ally, Bulgaria. Otto Type Bs may well have been among these, but, there is inadequate historical evidence to definitively confirm this. Model Builder's Comments: This model depicts an aircraft equipped with an Argus engine. Other sources indicate that Otto Bs were outfitted with Mercedes engines of similar horse-power.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Flieger-Abteilung 2, Royal Bavarian Flying Corps, Eastern Front, August, 1914.

title: Sopwith Triplane
history:
The Sopwith Triplane initiated an intense but brief vogue in fighter aircraft. Though its three-wing design was radical for the time, its fuselage had been derived from the craft's immediate predecessor, the Sopwith Pup. Both aircrcraft were designed by Herbert Smith, chief engineer of the Sopwith Aviation Company. By adding a third wing to his design, Smith increased the aircraft's lift and gave it greater maneuverability and a higher rate of climb.

The new triplane first flew in May of 1916. After successful pre-production test flights, 400 machines were immediately ordered. The British Royal Flying Corps, however, favored other fighter types and displayed little interest in the triplane. As a result, only pilots of the Royal Navy flew the Sopwith Triplane. With its allocation to only this single service, its total production was limited to just 144 machines. 

The Sopwith Triplane began operations in February of 1917. It achieved great initial success on the Western Front and briefly shifted air superiority to the Allies. Canadian ace Raymond Collishaw, among others, flew the Sopwith Triplane. In May and June of 1917, Collishaw shot down seven enemy aircraft and damaged another seventeen in this machine. 

To compete with this new British fighter, no less than fourteen different German aircraft manufacturers designed and built triplane prototypes. Of these, the Fokker Dr.I performed best in competitive flight trials and became the direct German response to the Sopwith Triplane. The Fokker Dr.I achieved fame through the exploits of German's Baron Manfred von Richthofen, the highest scoring ace of World War I. He flew a Fokker Dr.I during the last months of his life. 

Although their careers were brilliant, the triplanes of both sides were built in relatively small numbers and served in active combat for only a brief period. As early as the summer of 1917, Sopwith Camels succeeded the British triplanes. The German triplanes were also replaced by better and more modern Albatros and Fokker fighters.

This particular model exemplifies the Sopwith Triplane flown by Lt. C.D. Booker of the Royal Navy between April and August of 1917. He achieved 17 air victories during this time.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of No. 8 Squadron, Royal Naval Flying Service, St. Eloi, France, August 1917.

title: SPAD A.2 (SA.2)
history:
The SPAD SA.1 and its immediate successor, the SA.2 (modeled here) presented a unique solution to the problem for early fighting aircraft of providing a clear field of forward fire. Rather than resort to the common solution of configuring the machine in a pusher configuration, the SA.1 and SA.2 instead placed the gunner's position in a nacelle mounted in front of the propeller.

It is not surprising that this unique configuration was not popular with the men who flew the aircraft. Evaluations indicated that the aircraft's engine suffered from inadequate cooling and that the gunnery nacelle suffered from excessive vibration. Pilots also complained that their field of view was obstructed by the forward nacelle, and the gunners feared they would be crushed by the engine in the event of a crash.

Despite its failings, nearly 100 SPAD SA.2s were built with some 57 being sent to the Imperial Russian Air Force (such as the machine modeled here). The remainder went to the Aviation Militarie. SA.2s had a brief career and by mid 1916 they were being replaced by improved machines. The unique forward gun pulpits were rendered unnecessary by the development of propeller synchronized machine guns.

title: Rumpler Typ 6BI Single-Seat Combat Floatplane
history:
In June of 1916, the German Naval Air Service placed a specification with the German aircraft industry for a seaplane fighter capable of engaging British fighters and flying boats. The German aircraft manufacturing firm Rumpler-Werke A.G. responded with a single-seat seaplane designated the 6BI (modeled here). 

The 6BI utilized the same airframe as the land-based Rumpler C.I modified with floats. Its construction was typical for the time -wood framing with a doped fabric covering except for metal sheet surrounding the forward fuselage. The 6BI was powered by a 160 hp Mercedes DIII engine equipped with a distinctive "rhino horn" exhaust stack. The aircraft was armed, though sources are unclear as to whether the standard armament was one or two guns.

The first prototype 6BI flew in the late summer of 1916 and was deemed adequate for production. By the end of the year, production aircraft began equipping units of the German Naval Air Service at seaplane bases along the Baltic and North Sea coasts. Further modification of the Rumpler seaplane resulted in the 6BII, which looked similar to the 6BI save for a slightly longer wing span and a different horizontal tail. 
Fifty of the 6BII variants were delivered between May 1917 and January 1918 when Rumpler discontinued all 6B manufacture. 

By 1918 Germany had handed off most of its Rumpler 6B seaplane fighters to its ally Turkey where they served in the Black Sea Theater. Less intense allied air patrols in the region allowed the 6Bs to continue in operation when they were rendered obsolete by improved aircraft flying over the North Sea.

title: Caproni Ca.42 (Military Ca.4)
history:
The Italian firm Societ Ingegneri Caproni e Faccanoni built a line of progressively larger bombers during World War I, culminating with the Ca.42. The Ca.42 represents one of the largest aircraft of the Great War, second in wingspan to only three other machines: two massive Soviet Sikorsky bombers and the even larger Zeppelin Staaken R.VI German heavy bomber. 

The Ca.42 featured a separate bomb bay compartment attached to the lower wing of the craft. This compartment was mounted directly beneath the gondola-like central fuselage containing the pilot, a nose gunner and a third "pusher" engine. To support its long, thin wings, the machine required a maze of struts and bracing wires. Despite these structures, the aircraft's wings drooped when taking-off, landing and sitting on the ground. Skids placed beneath the tips of the lower wings prevented damage should the wing tips hit the ground. During flight, the lift of the wings reversed this drooping and the wings took on a slight upward or "dihedral" angle. 

The Ca.42 primarily carried out bombing raids on the larger cities of the Austro-Hungarian Empire during World War I. These missions often required clear weather, as this enabled the crew to visually navigate through the peaks of the Alps; these peaks rose higher than the Ca.42's operational ceiling of just over 9,800 feet (3,000 m). Ca.42s also carried out a few night bombing missions, but did not fly over the Alps for these missions. Ca.42s also saw action in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto and six of the aircraft were loaned to the British Royal Naval Air Service for use as maritime reconnaissance aircraft. 

Overall, the Ca.42s performed well, but they were complex, time-consuming and expensive to construct. Only 23 were produced before the war's end, and none were manufactured afterward. Italian aeronautical designers, however, continued to favor its three-engine design until after World War II.

title: Lohner C.I
history:
During World War I there were more different types of reconnaissance aircraft designed and placed into service than fighter and bomber types combined. Although fighters and bombers captured the imagination of the public, their impact on the outcome of the War has been questioned by some historians. On the other hand, the information provided to military leaders by reconnaissance aircraft had a significant impact on many major battles. Knowing the numbers, position and movement of enemy troops and supplies proved vital to the successful outcome of some land battles. It is not, therefore, surprising that the generals of both sides kept constant pressure on their respective aviation industries to provide new and better reconnaissance aircraft. 

One of the earliest reconnaissance types to enter service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force was the Lohner C.I, modeled here. It was designed by the pioneer Austrian aeronautical engineer, Jacob Lohner, the founder and owner of a firm which was famous for building naval flying boats. The Lohner C.I's construction was of wood framing throughout with a varnished wood veneer covering the fuselage. Its wings and tail structures were covered with a doped fabric. Painted aluminum sheeting completely enclosed the engine and the top of the forward fuselage and the radiator was mounted in front of the upper wing. 

The Lohner C.I first flew in late 1915 and production aircraft began equipping combat units on the Western, Italian, Balkan and Eastern Fronts in the first weeks of 1916. The machine proved sluggish in flight. It lacked agility and had a poor rate of climb, which made it easy prey for the machineguns of Allied fighters. The C.I fared better on the Balkan Front where there was less fighter opposition. On the Western Front, even when accompanied by a fighter escort, its losses became prohibitive. After barely a year in service Lohner C.I aircraft were withdrawn from active reconnaissance roles and were replaced by better performing machines, primarily the much superior Hansa-Brandenburg C.I. The Lohner C.I aircraft were relegated to Austro-Hungarian flight schools where they were employed as two-seat trainers.

title: Breguet Bre.14 B2
history:
Some World War I historians consider the Breguet Bre.14 to be the most successful French bomber of the war. Designed by the Société des Avions Louis Breguet, the frame of the Bre.14 was constructed from duralumin (aluminum) tubing. The use of aluminum gave the aircraft great strength and was advanced for a time when aircraft of wood and cloth construction were more common. 

Prototypes for two variants, the Bre.14 A2 armed reconnaissance version and the Bre.14 B2 light bomber (modeled here), flew for the first time in November, 1916 and entered service with the Aviation Militaire on the Western Front early in the summer of 1917. The machines proved to be fast and maneuverable with a good rate of climb. Breguet produced 5,500 of both variants during the war and an additional 2,500 before 1926. The United States purchased 376 Bre.14 B2 aircraft for service in the last year of the war on the Western Front. Although they could carry only a small bomb load, this aircraft was among the more successful light bombers during World War I.

title: Rumpler C.I (Typ 5A2)
history:
The Rumpler C.I occupies a special place in military aviation history. It represents the first airplane to fly photographic reconnaissance missions. It also claims one of the longest terms of active employment of any World War I aircraft. Because of its success, it remained deployed in an active combat role from early 1915 until February of 1918.

Design of the machine began shortly after the outbreak of the war by E. Rumpler Flugzeugwerke GmbH. Designed to be an armed reconnaissance craft, the C.I performed well from its introduction. It proved to be tough, well-armed, possessed of great endurance and, most importantly, difficult to shoot down. Over 2000 were built from mid 1915 until June of 1917 when production was terminated. 

In addition to flying for the German Air Force, Rumpler C.Is were employed by the Ottoman (Turkish) Air Force in Palestine and Macedonia. They provided great service during the battles for Gaza. Numbers of these machines remained in civilian service as light transports for several years after the war. Compared to its success, the Rumpler C.I has received little note in the history of World War I.

title: LFG Roland Pfeil (Arrow) Biplane
history: First constructed in 1913, the Roland Arrow biplane included a very unusual feature in early aircraft design -swept back wings. At the time, the wings of most aircraft were fitted perpendicular to the aircraft's fuselage. Only a few rare models, often referred to as Pfeilen (arrows) featured swept wings. In fact, swept wings would not become the norm until the advent of jet-powered aircraft in the 1950s. The Roland Arrow was constructed by the Berlin-based manufacturing firm, Luftfahrzeug Gesellschaft (L.F.G.), which used the trade name, "Roland" to avoid confusion with another German firm, L.V.G. Aside from the unconventional wing configuration, L.F.G. utilized typical materials and construction methods when creating the Arrow. The aircraft was a two-seater consisting of a wood-framed fuselage covered in doped fabric and powered by a 100 h.p. Mercedes or Argus engine. Like most pre-World War I aircraft, the Roland Arrow had been built for the civilian market. However, the type was counted among the aircraft in the German Air Service's inventory when World War I broke out in August of 1914. Like most of the earliest aircraft adopted for military use, the Roland Arrow was likely employed as a reconnaissance platform. Records are silent as to the operational achievements of the Arrow biplane during World War I. Just before the War, however, a specially fitted Roland Arrow piloted by Bruno Langer made a non-stop flight of 16 hours duration. While the aircraft possessed excellent qualities for a pre-war design, its slow speed and lack of armament must surely have made military use untenable by 1915 when armed Allied fighters appeared in the skies over the Western Front.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, August, 1914.

title: Curtiss Model H-16
history:
The Curtiss line of flying boats was one of only two American built aircraft-types to play a significant role in World War I -The other being the Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny" trainer. The predecessor of the H-16 flying boat was developed in 1914 at the request of Rodman Wanamaker, who was planning to attempt a transatlantic flight. The order for the aircraft, originally named America was cancelled at the outbreak of World War I. However, in 1916, the U.S. Navy ordered a number of flying boats based on the design. The new aircraft were designated H-12s and were the immediate predecessor of the H-16 modeled here.

The Curtiss flying-boats set many of the standards which would be used in flying-boat aircraft throughout the decades to come. The aircraft featured a v-shaped hull, which diverted water away from the cockpit during takeoff and landing and greatly reduced the drag on the underside of the aircraft while on the water. The H-12 and H-16 were twin-engine biplanes, which utilized a "tractor" configuration with forward-facing propellers. This differed from many flying boats of the time, which were configured as "pushers".

The United States Navy initially ordered 19 production H-12s and the British Royal Naval Air Service (R.N.A.S.) ordered an additional 50. In Britain, the aircraft were referred to as "Large Americas" to distinguish them from the smaller Curtiss H.4 flying boats -called "Small Americas"- already in R.N.A.S. service. 

The H-12 proved highly successful as a maritime patrol aircraft. In May of 1917, British H-12s successfully downed a Zeppelin, damaged another and sunk a German U-boat. Similar success stories continued throughout the year and prompted the development of a larger, improved version of the H-12, which became the H-16.

The first H-16s began appearing in the spring of 1918, but production delays meant that only 15 reached operational service before the Armistice. Nevertheless, The United States Navy eventually acquired 274 Curtiss H-16s, some of which remained in service until 1928.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the United States Naval Air Station, North Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada, October, 1918.

title: Macchi L.1
history:
On May 27th, 1915, shortly after Italy entered World War I, the Italian Navy captured a stranded Austro-Hungarian Lohner flying boat. The Italian Naval Air Service commissioned the firm, Societa Anonima Nieuport-Macchi to create a similar aircraft based on the captured Lohner. Italy's first flying boat, the Macchi L.1 was the result. 

The L.1 was almost and exact copy of its Lohner predecessor. The term "flying boat" was very appropriate for the L.1 since its wood veneer fuselage closely resembled the hull of a boat. The aircraft's wings and tail planes utilized wood framing but were covered with doped fabric and were decorated with the green, white and red markings of Italy. The machine's tail surfaces were raised high on a delicate metal frame to avoid sea spray during take-off and landing. The L.1's single engine, driving a "pusher" propeller, was in an elevated position between the wings. The Macchi L.1 was armed with a single machine gun mounted on the starboard side of the cockpit roof. 

Macchi produced a total of 139 L.1s, which were employed in reconnaissance, bombing and maritime patrol missions over the Mediterranean and Adriatic seas. An improved version dubbed the L.2 was produced in small numbers beginning in 1916, The L.1 and L.2 were eventually phased out with the arrival of the improved Macchi M.3.

title: Deperdussin Type TT (1914 Monoplane) Epervier (Sparrowhawk)
history:
Deperdussin Type TT aircraft were manufactured by the French aviation firm Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés (S.P.A.D.). First flying in 1912, the machine was a shoulder-wing monoplane, built with wood framing covered by doped fabric. Metal sheeting surrounded the engine and forward fuselage. The Deperdussin Type TT employed wing warping for lateral control, which required extensive wire bracing and control cables on the upper and lower wing surfaces.

When World War I broke out in August of 1914, the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force) had 138 airworthy aircraft in its inventory. Among this mixed bag of "flying machines" were two escadrilles equipped with Deperdussin Type TT aircraft such as the one modeled here. Most of France's 138 aircraft had originally been intended for sale on the civilian market, but were acquired and modified by the Aviation Militaire for use as reconnaissance platforms in support of French Army ground forces. French military leaders, like the leaders of all the combatant nations of the War, were initially skeptical about the usefulness of aircraft as weapons. Their potential as reconnaissance platforms was, however, universally recognized and early World War I aircraft were used solely in this capacity. 

Deperdussin Type TT aircraft proved frail and unsuited to the rigors and stresses intrinsic to wartime conditions. The slow, poorly maneuverable and unarmed machines often did not survive operational sorties once German and Austro-Hungarian fighter aircraft arrived over the Western Front in mid 1915. In an effort to give the Deperdussin Type TT some armament, a machine gun was mounted on a stand atop the forward fuselage with the gun firing over the propeller arc. This experimental arrangement proved unstable and the gun was impossible to reload. The concept was abandoned. Unacceptable losses coupled with the availability of more modern and armed reconnaissance machines allowed the Aviation Militaire to withdraw all of its Deperdussin Type TT aircraft by the end of 1915. The machine is, however, historically significant as one of the first aircraft to be deployed in military service.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified reconnaissance escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, August, 1914.

title: Brandenburg D.I (KD)
history:
The Brandenburg D.I was designed by the German aeronautical engineer, Ernst Heinkel, who would later go on to head the famous aviation firm bearing his name. Although designed in Germany, all production of the D.I was carried out in Austria by two separate Austrian firms,  Phonix-Flugzeug-Werke AG and Ungarische Flugzeugfabrik AG. Germany and the Austro-Hungarian Empire were allies during World War I, so this convergence of effort between the two countries is not totally surprising. However, historical records are unclear as to why the design and manufacture of this aircraft took place in different countries. 

Deployed exclusively by the Austro-Hungarians, the D.I was of conventional construction for a fighter of its time -wood framing throughout, with fabric covering of its wings and tail surfaces and a fuselage covered with a varnished plywood veneer. A thin metal alloy covered the forward fuselage around the engine. However, the Hansa-Brandenburg D.I was unique in one aspect of its design; instead of the usual arrangement of vertical intra-wing struts and bracing wires, the Hansa-Brandenburg D.I utilized a complicated single intra-wing "strut complex". The eight half struts comprising this single strut complex were joined into triangles at a central point between its wings. These triangles created the aircraft's entire intra-wing support. There were no bracing wires. The intent of this design was to eliminate the aerodynamic drag created by multiple struts and wires. 

The new machine first flew in the summer of 1916 and entered service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force the following autumn. From the start, the aircraft was sluggish, relatively slow, marginally maneuverable and unstable in flight. Further, its deep fuselage provided the pilot with limited visibility. Worse, it was plagued by a series of accidents which earned it the nickname, "the flying coffin". Despite these shortcomings, 122 D.Is were produced and they labored on in active combat service with the Austro-Hungarian Air Force until mounting losses forced their retirement in late 1917.
deployment: This model represents a fighter of the Austro-Hungarian Air Force, Western Front, March, 1917.

title: Breguet Type A-G.4 (Gnôme 140 or 160 hp)
history:
In 1912 the pioneering French aeronautical engineer, Louis Bréguet, began designing the A-G.4 -an aircraft specifically intended to serve France as a military reconnaissance platform. Bréguet's new machine included three very unique features: a machine gun positioned in the rear cockpit, which could be manually operated by an observer; protective steel armor plating around the cockpit and a four-wheeled undercarriage, which gave the machine a level horizontal stance when sitting on the ground. 

The A-G.4 first flew in the summer of 1913 and began equipping units of the Aviation Militaire the following autumn, where it saw immediate service over the Western Front upon the outbreak of hostilities. At the beginning of World War I, the A-G.4 was the only aircraft in the French inventory which was not originally built for sale on the pre-war civilian market. French military leaders of the time had little confidence in the value of "flying machines" as weapons of war. They did, however, recognize their potential in the area of reconnaissance and acquired several available civilian aircraft types which they modified for use in battlefield reconnaissance.

The Bréguet A-G.4 had a brief career. The machine gun and its ammunition coupled with the armor plating made the machine seriously over weight. This, in turn, adversely impacted its operational ceiling, speed and maneuverability. When faster and more agile German and Austro-Hungarian fighters armed with machine guns began appearing over the Western Front in the autumn of 1915, unacceptable losses forced the withdrawal of the A-G.4 in favor of faster and more capable reconnaissance aircraft. A few A-G.4s labored on as trainers after their retirement from front line service, their machine guns and armor plating having been removed. Although its operational contribution to the Allied War effort was marginal due to its brevity, the Bréguet A-G.4 is historically noteworthy as the first aircraft to see action during wartime while being both armed with a machine gun and protected by armor plating.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, August, 1914.

title: Pfalz D.XII
history:
The Pfalz D.XII represents one in a line of fighters built by Pfalz Flugzeugwerke, a Bavarian aviation company formed by three brothers of the Evertbusch family before World War I. This firm acquired the rights to build aircraft from the French company, Morane-Saulnier and later from the firm LFG Roland. With the experience gleaned from these early efforts, Pfalz Flugzeugwerke began to design and manufacture its own fighter aircraft after the outbreak of World War I. 

The Pfalz D.XII, modeled here, improved upon its immediate predecessor, the D.III. Like its predecessor, the new D.XII was also a biplane. It possessed all wood construction with a thin plywood veneer over its fuselage. The D.XII's wings, tail surfaces and all of its control surfaces were fabric covered. Because of its sturdy construction, the D.XII could dive faster and steeper than most all of its contemporaries. After competitive trials with other new fighter designs in mid 1918, the German military contracted for 500 D.XIIs to be built. 

The D.XII did have a drawback. It was not able to make a tight turn in flight and was far more sluggish in combat than the other new German fighter to arrive in mid 1918-the Fokker D.VII. The poor control response made the new Pfalz D.XIIs unpopular with German fighter pilots, who preferred the new Fokker D.VIIs. 

Notwithstanding their shortcomings, by the end of the War nearly 800 Pfalz D.XIIs had been built and placed into front-line service on the Western Front.  Following World War I, numbers of these Pfalz D.XIIs were taken in hand by the victorious Allied air services. After evaluation, they deemed these aircraft to be inferior to other German fighters and the most modern Allied fighters. Four Pfalz D.XII aircraft have survived into the 21st Century and are on display in air museums in the United States, Australia and France.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 77, Bavarian Air Service, Western Front, October 1918.

title: Fokker Dr.I Triplane (F.I)
history: The Fokker Dr.I ('Dr.' standing for Dreidecker-or triplane) is perhaps the most famous aircraft of World War I. Inspired by the success of the the British Sopwith Triplane, German military leaders commissioned several aviation firms to construct a comparable triplane aircraft. The Dr.I represents Fokker Flugzeug-Werke's response to this call. The Fokker Dr.I went into production and entered service in the skies of the Western Front in late 1917. The design proved very successful, achieving 21 victories during its first three weeks of operation. Some speculate that a number of these early victories occurred when allied pilots and gunners confused the new Dr.I for a British Sopwith Triplane, which it closely resembled. By the time the Dr.I was recognized as an enemy German fighter, it was too late. The Fokker Dr.I Triplane's fame doubtless comes from its association with World War I's leading air ace, Baron Manfred von Richthofen -better known as the "Red Baron". Although he achieved the majority of his eighty air victories while flying in Albatros D. IIs, IIIs and Vs, it was while flying the Fokker Dr.I, during the last months of his career, that he garnered his greatest fame. The Baron commanded Jagdstaffel 1, Germany's best and most feared fighter unit. Because the unit painted their aircraft in a variety of bright colors, it become known as the 'Flying Circus". Von Richthofen earned the nickname "Red Baron" from his Fokker Dr.I, which was painted a vivid red. While flying this red Fokker Dr.I (Nr. 425/17), he was shot down and killed over Sailly-le-Sec in the Somme Valley of France on the morning of April 21, 1918. It remains unclear whether he was killed by a bullet from an opposing Allied fighter aircraft with which he was engaged or by fire from Australian ground forces known to have been shooting at his low flying Dr.I. Despite its operational success, the Dr.I was plagued by structural problems throughout its career; problems which modifications in construction and retrofitting of existing machines did not totally correct. Approximately 320 Dr.I's were built, far less than several other German fighter types. The "heyday" of the Dr.I was short - perhaps from February to June 1918 and the machine's overall impact on the air war over the Western Front was minimal. In the end, Dr.Is were replaced in German fighter units by the far superior Fokker D.VII aircraft. Nonetheless, the fame of the Fokker Dr.I lives on in the imagination of the public.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 1, Western Front, April, 1918.

title: Siemens-Schuckert Steffen R.I
history:
Just four months after the outbreak of World War I, German aircraft manufacturer, Siemens-Schuckert (SSW) began construction on a series of seven highly unusual three-engine bombers designed by Bruno and Franz Steffen. The biplane aircraft incorporated an unconventional "forked" tail configuration designed to allow a clear field of fire to the rear. The planes were driven by two propellers mounted between the wings and powered by a series of three engines mounted in the fuselage. The machines also featured an enclosed cabin -another unusual feature for the time- giving the nose a distinctly bus-like appearance.

The first in the series, designated R.I (modeled here), took its maiden flight on May 24, 1915 and, after testing, arrived on the Eastern Front by October of that year. Unfortunately, it soon became apparent that the R.I was unfit for frontline service, and the machine was re-assigned as a trainer for future R-type crews. The following six versions of the aircraft, designated R.II-VII, featured improved engines and a redesigned forward fuselage. These aircraft also required modification after delivery before they were fit for combat. Like their predecessor, R.II and III were relegated to training duties but RIV-VII saw active duty on the Eastern Front with Riesenflugzeug-Abteilung 501 (Giant Aircraft Division 501), where they conducted bombing raids against Russian military and industrial targets.

In August of 1917, Rfa 501 was reassigned to the Western Front and re-equipped with the larger Zeppelin Staaken heavy bomber. The SSW R-series remains noteworthy as some of the first heavy bombers in aviation history.
deployment: This model represents the prototype of the SSW R-series bombers. It served with a training unit of the German Air Force at Doeberitz, Germany, 1915.

title: Nieuport 28 C1
history: Built by the Société Anonyme des Etablissments Nieuport, The Nieuport 28 C1 was the first fighter flown by United States pilots in support of United States ground forces in World War I. Designer, Gustav Delage radically departed from the wing design of earlier Nieuport fighters when he designed the 28 C1. He abandoned his unique sesquiplane lower wing used in previous models in favor of standard biplane wings. He did, however, retain the narrow chord and single spar from his earlier wing designs. Unfortunately, a poor upper wing design caused structural failures and fabric separations at high speed -a process called "losing the laundry." Engine fires were also a regular occurrence and some pilots lost confidence in the aircraft because of these problems. The United States purchased 298 Nieuport 28s for service in the United States Air Service. American ace Eddie Rickenbacker and James Norman Hall, author of Mutiny on the Bounty, flew this aircraft over the Western Front during the 28 C1's short career in the last months of the War. By the summer of 1918, the SPAD XIII C1 replaced most of these aircraft, but some Nieuport 28s continued to fly until the end of the war. When World War I concluded, many Nieuport 28s returned to the United States. The United States Navy employed twelve of the aircraft on early battleships in experimental flights off improvised platforms. The Museum of Flight example is thought to be one of these Navy models.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the 94th Aero Squadron, Western Front, France, May, 1918

title: Anatra Model DS Anasal (Anatra-Salmson)
history: While the Imperial Russian Air Service began World War I with more aircraft than France or Germany, many of the machines were imported models already considered obsolete by the other nations. Furthermore, The Russian aviation industry was underdeveloped compared to those of the War's other major combatant nations. Recognizing the situation as a business opportunity, Russian banker, Artur Antonovich Anatra founded the Anatra Aircraft Company in Odessa. It was this firm that designed and produced the Anatra DS modeled here. The Anatra DS developed from the earlier Anatra D and appeared very similar to its predecessor. The primary difference between the DS and the earlier aircraft was the inclusion of a 150 hp liquid-cooled Salmson radial engine. The inclusion of this engine led to the plane's nickname, "Anasal" -a combination of "Anatra" and "Salmson". The radial engine was unique at a time when virtually all aircraft had either rotary air-cooled engines or inline liquid-cooled engines. Aside from this, the Anasal was of standard construction for the era -wood framing, plywood veneer over the fuselage, metal sheeting about its engine and fabric covering of its wings and tail surfaces. Approximately 70 production Anasals were built and delivered to the Imperial Russian Air Force before the end of hostilities. Little is recorded about the operational history of these machines but it is known that at the time of the Russian Revolution and the overthrow of the Imperial government that Anatra DS aircraft were listed on the rosters of the Imperial Russian Air Force. While the chaotic events of the Russian Civil War, which began in 1917 are still being sorted out by historians, it is thought that some of these aircraft remained operational with both the "White" and "Red" air forces. The aircraft modeled here bears post-revolution Bolshevik markings.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Russian Bolshevik "Red Air Force", Western Russia, Summer 1918.

title: Albatros D.V (L24)
history:
Albatroswerke developed the D.V in an effort to improve upon its predecessors, the Albatros D.II and D.III. The D.V featured a semi-monocoque wooden fuselage with wings built of a wood frame and doped fabric covering. Though it looked similar to the Albatros D.II and D.III, the D.V had a strengthened wing structure and an improved Mercedes D.IIIa engine. Despite its reinforced wing, the machine still suffered from wing failure during steep dives. This resulted in several fatal accidents and needless combat losses. Investigations eventually found that the wing spar was placed too far aft, resulting in excessive vibration and eventual breakage during prolonged dives. In a continuing effort to address this problem, Albatros-Werke added a supplemental strut to later model D.Vs.

The D.V entered combat service on the Western Front in May of 1917. Operations of the Albatros D.V reached a peak in May of 1918 when 1,059 machines were in active service with 37 German Jasta. At that time, the D.V and a variant, the D.Va, constituted 48% of all German fighters deployed with combat units. After May of 1918, the Albatros machines were gradually replaced by Fokker D.VII fighter aircraft. 

The Albatros D.V modeled here was flown on the Western Front by Vizefeldwebel (Staff Sergeant) Barth, a member of Jasta 10, in the late autumn of 1917.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of Jagdstaffel (squadron) 10, German Air Force, Western Front, November 1917.

title: Albatros C.I (L6)
history:
The Albatros C.I was the first in a series of "C"reconnaissance aircraft built by the German aviation firm Albatros Werke GmbH. Albatros's aircraft distinguished themselves and were widely deployed during the entirety of the conflict. The C.I, which was designed by famous German aeronautical engineer Ernst Heinkel, utilized conventional wood & fabric construction with thin sheet metal surrounding the engine and forward fuselage. 

The C.I entered service with Germany in early 1915, but despite its success, was replaced by the improved Albatros C.III beginning in early 1916. Rather than retire the design, Germany then began supplying its C.Is to the Ottoman Empire. The Ottomans Empire, which had controlled the Middle East for generations, was disintegrating. The Turks desperately needed aircraft with which to patrol the vast desert areas of the empire and to conduct aerial attacks against a British-supported Arab insurrection. The Germans shipped numbers of their redundant Albatros C. I aircraft to Turkey in order to ensure that the Ottoman Empire remained an effective ally. 

The Turkish C.Is required modification to function in the desert environment. The aircraft's radiators were enlarged to allow for greater heat exchange and metal shutters were fitted over the radiators to keep out desert sand. The usual single forward firing machine gun was augmented with a second weapon and a light bomb load was provided for ground attack. Modified C.Is remained in service with the Turkish Air Force throughout the Middle East theater until the War's end. The aircraft modeled here is one of these modified Albatros C.Is in service with the Ottoman Empire.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the Ottoman (Turkish) Air Force, Palestine, Middle East Theater, July, 1917.

title: Royal Aircraft Factory F.E.8
history:
This model represents an aircraft that was the first single seat fighter designed by the Royal Aircraft Factory (R.A.F.) The open-framed rear-boom fuselage and pusher engine evolved from earlier R.A.F. designs. The F.E.8 utilized the pusher configuration because aircraft engineers had not yet developed the interrupter mechanism that would eventually allow pilots to fire through a plane's propeller arc. 

Although the F.E. 8 first flew in October of 1915, the 270 production aircraft built by Darracquot Motors Engineering at Fulham and Vickers Aircraft at Weybridge did not become operational until August, 1916. By this time more advanced German tractor-type fighters with superior performance made the "pusher" configuration aircraft ineffective. Some F.E.8s remained in service for another year before their final withdrawal and a number were subsequently assigned to serve with Britain's Portuguese allies in East Africa. There they served as ground support and reconnaissance aircraft. This model represents one of these Portuguese aircraft.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit if the Portuguese Air Force, Portuguese East Africa, December, 1917.

title: Pfalz E.I
history: The design of the German Pfalz E.I fighter was largely based on the French Morane-Saulnier type L. In early 1914, before the outbreak of World War I, the German aviation company Pfalz Flugzeug-Werke began building the French-designed Morane-Saulnier type L monoplane under license. With the onset of war, Pfalz took the experience gleaned from building the type L and designed and built its own aircraft, the Pfalz E.I (modeled here). The Pfalz E.I retained many of the features of its French predecessor including its shoulder-wing monoplane design, wooden frame, fabric covering, metal engine cowling, and its single machine gun. Derived from a similar French fighter, the Pfalz E.I signified an important advance in aviation technology in its own right. The Pfalz E.I represents one of the first aircraft to include a propeller-synchronized machine gun system. A synchronized rod allowed the aircraft's machine gun to fire only when its propeller was not in the gun's line of fire. This represented a significant improvement over the Morane-Saulnier type L, which utilized steel plates fixed to its propeller to deflect any bullets which might strike it. The Pfalz E.I first joined German Air Force units on the Western Front in October 1916 where it primarily served as an escort fighter for German reconnaissance aircraft flying over the Allied lines. The Pfalz E.I also served in the German and Ottoman Air Forces in 1916 during the Sinai desert campaigns in the Middle East. The Bavarian Air Force employed several of these fighters as unarmed reconnaissance aircraft as well. The E.I performed marginally compared to other German fighters of the era and a maximum of only 27 remained in service with the German Air Force at any one time. By 1917, the Pfalz E.I was replaced by more advanced biplane fighters in the Central Powers' Air Services. None are known to have survived the war. Model Builder's Comments: The prototype for this model was painted in a very interesting and unusual black and white color scheme.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft from an unidentified unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, 1916.

title: Halberstadt D.II
history:
Designed by engineer, Karl Theis, the Halberstädt D. II was built by the German company Halberstädter Flugzeug-Werke GmbH as well as under license by Aviatik and Hannoversche Waggonfabrik AG. 

The Halberstädt D.II entered service on the Western Front in September 1916 where it served successfully until the arrival of the higher performing Albatros and Fokker fighters in the spring of 1917. 

Once the D.II had been retired from the Western Front, Germany retained a few to use as advanced single-seat trainers, while the rest were equipped with radiators to adapt them for a desert environment. The modified D.IIs served in Turkey with various units of the Ottoman Air Force until the end of the war. The lack of significant opposition in this area contributed to the D.II's success.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified squadron of the German Air Force.

title: Thomas-Morse S-4C
history:
The Thomas-Morse S-4C was one of the few World War I aircraft independently designed and manufactured in the United States without the assistance or influence of French, British or Italian engineers. While otherwise purely American, it did have a French-designed power plant. A very sturdy aircraft built of wood framing with a fabric covering painted with aluminum colored dope, it had a circular metal cowling surrounding its engine. Built by the Thomas-Morse Aviation Company, the small, compact and aerodynamically sophisticated aircraft was intended to be an advanced trainer for the development of American fighter pilots. 

The S-4C was developed as an alternative to the American built Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny". While the Jenny was probably the finest elementary trainer of its era, its flight characteristics were "tame" compared to those of the French S.P.A.D.s, Nieuports and the British Sopwith fighters the American airmen flew in Europe. The United States Army Air Force needed a trainer with properties more closely resembling those of an actual combat fighter. The Thomas-Morse trainer was created to fill this need and began being deployed at flight schools in June of 1917. Since the young airmen who would be flying it had successfully completed their primary training and were certified pilots, the Thomas-Morse trainer had no instructor's cockpit. While not quite possessing the speed and maneuverability of a combat fighter, it approached that degree of performance thus giving the pilot the necessary transitional experience needed before flying "the real thing" over the Western Front. 

The machine proved so successful in its role as a transitional advanced trainer that production continued past the end of World War I and was not finally terminated until 1920. A total of 497 S-4Cs were built. and remained in active service at United States Army Air Force flight training schools until the late 1920s. Following their military careers a number of the former trainers were sold on the civilian market where their racy appearance and outstanding performance made them very popular with aerial sportsman. Many hobbyists continued to fly a number of them into the 1950s. While their airframes remained unchanged, those machines flying after the mid 1930s usually had their original rotary engines replaced with more modern radial power plants.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of the United States Army Air Force Flight Schools, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, November, 1918.

title: Sopwith Camel 2.F.1 Ship Camel
history: This aircraft was the naval variant of the famous Sopwith Camel. The aircraft received the name "Camel" because of the hump-backed area of its forward fuselage, which housed its machine gun. The 2.F.1 Ship Camel differed from the land-based variant in several ways. It had an abbreviated center wing section with a correspondingly shorter lower wing. The 2.F.1 also had only one machine gun mounted in the fuselage instead of the two guns of its land-based counterpart. The Ship Camel's second machine gun was mounted atop its upper wing and fired above the propeller arc. The 2.F.1 also had a more powerful engine, was equipped with arresting gear for landing on an aircraft carrier deck and featured a detachable rear fuselage section to facilitate storage aboard ship. Production versions of the 2.F.1 aircraft were built by Sopwith and William Beardmore & Company, which began equipping units of the Royal Naval Air Service in the autumn of 1917. While the "Naval" Camel was also deployed from some shore-based facilities, it primarily served aboard the British aircraft carriers Argus, Furious, Pegasus and Eagle, all of which operated with the Grand Fleet. Given that Britain was the only World War I combatant nation to field ship-based aircraft, the 2.F.1 Camels, although fighters, faced little aerial opposition during their time at sea. Thus, their role became largely that of reconnaissance aircraft. A squadron of 2.F.1 Camels was also used to launch the first carrier strike in history when seven of the planes, launched from the HMS Furious, attacked the German airship base at Tondern, Germany. Several hundred 2.F.1s were manufactured during the War and remained in active service with the British Royal Navy as carrier-borne fighters for several years after. Some, which were purchased by Canada, remained in shore based service until the late 1920s. The Sopwith 2.F.1 can justly be called the successful forerunner of all shipboard naval aircraft.

title: SPAD VII (S.7)
history: The first SPAD VII appeared over Europe in 1916 and shifted the balance of airpower in favor of the Allied Forces. The aircraft is part of a lineage of fighters designed by Louis Bechereau, the chief engineer of the French firm Société Anonyme Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés (SPAD). With its heavy 150 hp (112 kW) inline engine, the SPAD VII was less maneuverable than its opponents. Its robust design, however, allowed it to escape enemy fighters by entering a high speed dive which the Central Powers' lighter built rotary engine fighters could not match. Soon, a more powerful 180 hp (134 kW) engine was added to the SPAD VII's design, improving its performance. This improved version was designated the SPAD VII C1. More than 3,800 SPAD VIIs were built in France during the war. England and the Russia constructed hundreds more under license. Most French fighter Escadrilles flew S.VIIs at one time or another from 1916-1917, and many French aces achieved their air victories during World War I while flying a SPAD VII. The air services of England, the United States, Italy, Russia, Poland and Belgium also employed the S.7s. By late 1917, Louis Bechereau had again redesigned his machine and produced the improved SPAD XIII. While similar externally to the S.7, the S.13 incorporated a more powerful engine, a slightly greater wingspan, a longer fuselage, and a second machine gun mounted on the nose. The new SPAD XIIIs began replacing the S.7s by the summer of 1917. After World War I, both the S.7s and S.13s remained in active service through the mid 1920s in the air forces of various countries. Model Builder's Comments: The prototype of this model was the SPAD VII C1 flown by the French ace Sgt. Georges Guynemer on the Western Front in late 1916.
deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified escadrille, Aviation Militaire (French Air Force), Western Front, September 1916.
